§ 10.01 INTERPRETATION.
   (A)   The provisions of this and subsequent chapters in this volume shall
constitute and be designated and cited as the “Middlesboro Code of Ordinances”.
   (B)   Unless otherwise provided herein, or by law or implication required,
the same rules of construction, definition, and application shall govern the
interpretation of this code as those governing the interpretation of the
Kentucky Revised Statutes.
   (C)   Statutory footnotes, cross-references, and other comments are by way
of explanation only and should not be deemed a part of the text of any section.
   (D)   All provisions of this code are limited in application to the
territorial boundaries of the municipal corporation although the same may not
be so limited specifically.
(Prior Code, § 10.01)
§ 10.02 APPLICATION TO FUTURE LEGISLATION.
   All of the provisions of Title I, not incompatible with future legislation,
shall apply to ordinances hereafter adopted amending or supplementing this code
unless otherwise specifically provided.
(Prior Code, § 10.02)
§ 10.03 CAPTIONS.
   Title headings, chapter headings, and section headings, are employed for
reference purposes only and shall not be deemed a part of the text for any
section.
(Prior Code, § 10.03)
§ 10.04 DEFINITIONS.
   In the construction of this code and of all ordinances of the city, the
following definitions and rules of construction shall be observed, unless they
are inconsistent with the intent of the Council or the context clearly requires
otherwise:
   ACTION. Includes all proceedings in any court of this state.
(KRS 446.010(1))
   AND or OR. Includes the other as if written AND/OR if the sense requires it.
   ANIMAL. Includes every warm-blooded living creature except a human being.
(KRS 446.010(2))
   AVIS. The Automated Vehicle Information System established and maintained by
the Transportation Cabinet to collect tilting and registration information on
vehicles and boats and information on holders of motor vehicle operator’s
licenses and personal identification cards.
(KRS 446.010(55))
   CITY, MUNICIPAL CORPORATION, or MUNICIPALITY. The municipality of
Middlesboro irrespective of its population or legal classification.
   CLERK and TAX COLLECTOR. Whenever this term appears throughout this code of
ordinances it shall be interpreted to mean City Clerk.
   CODE or CODE OF ORDINANCES. A reenactment of the body of positive municipal
law, read and interpreted as a whole, with the text arranged by subject matter
and properly indexed.
(KRS 83A.010(2))
   COMPANY. May extend and be applied to any corporation, company, person,
partnership, joint stock company, or association.
(KRS 446.010(9))
   COMPOSITE INDEX. A loose-leaf compilation of all ordinances listed by date
of passage, arranged by subject matter of the contents and indexed
alphabetically.
(KRS 83A.010(4))
   CORPORATION. May extend and be applied to any corporation, company,
partnership, joint stock company, or association.
(KRS 446.010(10))
   COUNCIL or CITY COUNCIL. The legislative body of the City of Middlesboro
organized and governed under the Mayor-Council Plan.
(KRS 83A.010(5))
   CRUELTY. As applied to animals, includes every act or omission whereby
unjustifiable physical pain, suffering, or death is caused or permitted.
(KRS 446.010(12))
   DIRECTOR OF FINANCE. Whenever this term appears throughout this code of
ordinances it shall be interpreted to mean chief financial officer.
   DIRECTORS. When applied to corporations, includes managers or trustees.
(KRS 446.010(13))
   DOMESTIC. When applied to a corporation, partnership, business trust, or
limited liability company, means all those incorporated or formed by authority
of this state.
(KRS 446.010(14))
   DOMESTIC ANIMAL. Any animal converted to domestic habitat.
(KRS 446.010(15))
   EXECUTIVE AUTHORITY. The Mayor of the City of Middlesboro.
   EXECUTIVE ORDER. An order issued by the Mayor which is binding upon the
officers and employees of the city and any governmental agency over which the
city has jurisdiction.
(KRS 83A.010(7))
   FEDERAL. Refers to the United States.
(KRS 446.010(17))
   FOREIGN. When applied to a corporation, partnership, limited partnership,
business trust, statutory trust, or limited liability company, includes all
those incorporated or formed by authority of any other state.
(KRS 446.010(18))
   KEEPER or PROPRIETOR. Includes all persons, whether acting by themselves or
as a servant, agent, or employee.
   KRS. Kentucky Revised Statutes.
   LAND or REAL ESTATE. Includes lands, tenements, and hereditaments and all
rights thereto and interest therein, other than a chattel interest.
(KRS 446.010(23))
   LEGISLATIVE BODY. The City Council.
(KRS 91A.010(8))
   LEGISLATIVE BODY MEMBER. A Council member.
(KRS 83A.010(8))
   LIVESTOCK. Cattle, sheep, swine, goats, alpacas, llamas, buffaloes, or any
other animals of the bovine, ovine, porcine, caprine, equine, or camelid
species.
(KRS 446.010(25))
   MAY. Is permissive.
(KRS 446.010(26))
   MISDEMEANOR. An offense for which the criminal fine can not exceed the
amount set forth in KRS 534.040(2)(a), or a term of imprisonment not to exceed
the periods set forth in KRS 532.090(1), or both.
(KRS 83A.065)
   MONTH. A calendar month.
(KRS 446.010(27))
   MUNICIPAL ORDER. An official act of Council which is binding upon the
officers and employees of the municipality and any governmental agency over
which the municipality has jurisdiction.
(KRS 83A.010(9))
   MUNICIPALITY. The City of Middlesboro, Kentucky.
   OATH. Includes AFFIRMATION in all cases in which an affirmation may be
substituted for an oath.
(KRS 446.010(28))
   OFFICER. Any person elected to a position by the voters or any person
appointed to a position which:
      (1)   Is created by the Constitution, the General Assembly, or the city;
      (2)   Possesses a delegation of a portion of the sovereign power of
government;
      (3)   Has powers and duties to be discharged which are conferred directly
or by implication by the city;
      (4)   Has duties performed independently and without control of a
superior power other than law;
      (5)   Has some permanency;
      (6)   Requires an official oath;
      (7)   Is assigned by a commission or other written authority; and
      (8)   Provides for an official bond if required by proper authority.
(KRS 83A.010(10))
   ORDINANCE. An official action of a Council, which is a regulation of a
general and permanent nature and enforceable as a local law or is an
appropriation of money.
(KRS 83A.010(11))
   OWNER. Applied to a building or land shall include any part owner, joint
owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant of the whole or a
part of such building, or land, either alone or with others.
   PARTNERSHIP. Both general and limited partnerships.
(KRS 446.010(30))
   PERSON or WHOEVER.
      (1)   May extend and be applied to bodies politic and corporate,
societies, communities, the public generally, individuals, partnerships, and
joint stock companies, and limited liability companies.
(KRS 446.010(33))
      (2)   Whenever used in any clause prescribing and imposing a penalty, the
term PERSON or WHOEVER as applied to any unincorporated entity, shall mean the
partners or members thereof, and as applied to corporations, the officers
thereof.
   PERSONAL PROPERTY. Every species of property except real property.
   PREMISES. As applied to property, includes land and buildings.
   PROPERTY. Includes real and personal property.
   PUBLIC AUTHORITY. Includes boards of education; the municipal, county,
state, or federal government, its officers or an agency thereof; or any duly
authorized public official.
   PUBLIC PLACE. Includes any street, sidewalk, park, cemetery, school yard,
body of water or watercourse, public conveyance, or any other place for the
sale of merchandise, public accommodation, or amusement.
   REAL PROPERTY. Lands, tenements, and hereditaments and shall embrace all
chattels real.
    REVISED STATUTES or KRS. Refers to the Revised Statutes of Kentucky.
   SHALL. Is mandatory.
(KRS 446.010(39))
   SIDEWALK. The portion of the street between the curb line and the adjacent
property line intended for the use of pedestrians.
   STATE. The Commonwealth of Kentucky.
   STREET. Includes alleys, avenues, boulevards, lanes, roads, highways,
viaducts, and all other public thoroughfares within the city.
   SUMMARY. A brief narrative prepared under the supervision of an attorney
succinctly covering the main points of an official statement, ordinance, or
rule in a way reasonably calculated to inform the public in a clear and
understandable manner as to its meaning.
(KRS 83A.010(12))
   TENANT or OCCUPANT. As applied to premises, includes any person holding a
written or oral lease, or who actually occupies the whole or any part of such
premises, alone or with others.
   TREASURER. Whenever this term appears throughout this code of ordinances it
shall be interpreted to mean chief financial officer.
   VACANCY IN OFFICE. Such as exists when there is an unexpired part of a term
of office without a lawful incumbent therein, or when the person elected or
appointed to an office fails to qualify according to law, or when there has
been no election to fill the office at the time appointed by law; it applies
whether the vacancy is occasioned by death, resignation, removal from the
state, county, city, or district, or otherwise.
(KRS 446.010(46))
   VIOLATE. Includes failure to comply with.
(KRS 446.010(47))
   VIOLATION. An offense for which the criminal fine can not exceed the amount
set forth in KRS 534.040(2)(c).
(KRS 83A.065)
(Prior Code, § 10.04)
§ 10.05 RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.
   (A)   Singular includes plural. A word importing the singular number only
may extend and be applied to several persons or things, as well as to one
person or thing, and a word importing the plural number only may extend and be
applied to one person or thing as well as to several persons or things.
(KRS 446.020(1))
   (B)   Masculine includes feminine. A word importing the masculine gender
only may extend and be applied to females as well as males.
(KRS 446.020(2))
   (C)   Liberal construction. All sections of this code shall be liberally
construed with a view to promote their objects and carry out the intent of City
Council.
(KRS 446.080(1))
   (D)   Retroactivity. No ordinance shall be construed to be retroactive,
unless expressly so declared.
(KRS 446.080(3))
   (E)   Technical terms. All words or phrases shall be construed according to
the common and approved usage of language, but technical words and phrases and
such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law,
shall be construed according to such meaning.
(KRS 446.080(4))
(Prior Code, § 10.045)
§ 10.06 RULE OF SEVERABILITY.
   Each chapter, section, or, whenever divisible, part section of this code of
ordinances is hereby declared to be severable, and the invalidity of any
chapter, section or divisible part section, shall not be construed to affect
the validity of any other chapter, section or part section of this code.
(Prior Code, § 10.05)
§ 10.07 REFERENCE TO OTHER SECTIONS.
   Whenever in one section reference is made to another section hereof, such
reference shall extend and apply to the section referred to as subsequently
amended, revised, recodified, or renumbered unless the subject matter be
changed or materially altered by the amendment or revision.
(Prior Code, § 10.06)
§ 10.08 REFERENCE TO OFFICES.
   Reference to a public office or officer shall be deemed to apply to any
office, officer, or employee of the city, exercising the powers, duties, or
functions contemplated in the provision, irrespective of any transfer of
functions or change in the official title of the functionary.
(Prior Code, § 10.07)
§ 10.09 ERRORS AND OMISSIONS.
   If a manifest error be discovered consisting of the misspelling of any word
or words, the omission of any word or words necessary to express the intention
of the provisions affected, the use of a word or words to which no meaning can
be attached, or the use of a word or words when another word or words was
clearly intended to express such intent, such spelling shall be corrected and
such word or words supplied, omitted, or substituted as will conform with the
manifest intention, and the provision shall have the same effect as though the
correct words were contained in the text as originally published. No such
alteration shall be made or permitted if any question exists regarding the
nature or extent of such error.
(Prior Code, § 10.08)
§ 10.10 COMPUTING TIME; FIRST DAY EXCLUDED; LAST DAY INCLUDED; EXCEPTION.
   The time within which an act is required by any provision of this code to be
done shall be computed by excluding the first and including the last day;
except that when the last day falls on a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday,
then the act may be done on the next succeeding day which is not a Sunday or a
legal holiday.
(KRS 446.030) (Prior Code, § 10.09)
§ 10.11 PREVAILING TIME.
   The prevailing time within the city of the transaction of all city business
shall be as established by applicable state and federal law.
(Prior Code, § 10.11)
§ 10.99 GENERAL PENALTY.
   Each act or omission which is prohibited or declared unlawful in this code
of ordinances is a violation, and in case no penalty of fine or imprisonment is
otherwise provided, the offender, upon conviction, shall be fined not less than
$2 nor more than $250 for each offense.
(Prior Code, § 10.99)
CHAPTER 11: CORPORATE BOUNDARIES AND WARDS
Section
   
11.01   Corporate limits
   
11.02   Ward boundaries
§ 11.01 CORPORATE LIMITS.
   (A)   The corporate limits of the city, until otherwise changed by
ordinance, shall remain as established and as follows.
   The County of Bell as is included in the following boundary, to wit:
Beginning at a point in the middle of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad
track, two hundred yards northwardly from the northern crossing of the
Middlesborough Belt Railroad and said Louisville and Nashville Railroad,
running thence parallel to said Middlesborough Belt Railroad and two hundred
yards distant therefrom westwardly, southwardly, and eastwardly, to a point in
the middle of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad track, two hundred yards
southwardly from the southern crossing of said belt and Louisville and
Nashville Railroads; thence due east one mile; thence due north to a point
which is due east from the beginning; thence west to the place of beginning;
courses by magnetic meridian of one thousand eight hundred and ninety,
variation two degree, fifteen seconds east, be, and the same is hereby declared
to be, a city; and the inhabitants thereof are created a body corporate and
politic, with perpetual succession, under the corporate name of “City of
Middlesboro.”
   (B)   Subsequent annexations are shown in the following cross reference.
(Acts of the General Assembly-1889, Chapter 347, page 648)
(Prior Code, § 11.01)
Cross-reference:
   Annexations, see Table of Special Ordinances,
Table I
§ 11.02 WARD BOUNDARIES.
   The City of Middlesboro, Kentucky, shall be divided into two wards, to be
known, respectively, as the North Ward and the South Ward.
   The North Ward is described as follows:
   Beginning with the west corporation line at a point where the centerline of
Cumberland Avenue, extended, intersects same; thence in an easterly direction
with the centerline of Cumberland Avenue to a point where the centerline of
Cumberland Avenue intersects the centerline of 12th street or U.S. 25 E; thence
with the centerline of 12th street or U.S. 25 E in a northerly direction to a
point where the centerline of 12th street or U.S. 25 E intersects the north
boundary line; thence in a general southerly and westerly course with the
corporation line around the northern portion of the city to the beginning.
   The South Ward is described as follows:
   Beginning with the west corporation line at a point where the centerline of
Cumberland Avenue, extended, intersects same; thence in an easterly direction
with the centerline of Cumberland Avenue to a point where the centerline of
Cumberland Avenue intersects with the centerline of 12th street or U.S. 25 E;
thence with the centerline of 12th street or U.S. 25 E in a northerly direction
to a point where the centerline of 12th street or U.S. 25 E intersects the
north boundary line; thence in a general southerly, easterly and westerly
course with the corporation boundary around the southern portion of the city to
the beginning.
(Prior Code, § 11.02)

ELECTED OFFICERS
§ 30.01 ELECTION PROCEDURE.
   (A)   Pursuant to the authority of KRS 83A.050, the manner of election of
city officers shall be under nonpartisan city election laws as provided in KRS
Chapter 83A.
   (B)   The city may change the manner of election of city officers within the
provisions of division (A) of this section by ordinance, except that no change
shall be made earlier than five years from the last change.
   (C)   The city shall pay the costs of city elections only if city elections
are held at a time other than prescribed by law for elections generally.
(KRS 83A.050) (Prior Code, § 30.10) (Minute book HH, page 226, passed 12-20-
1983)
§ 30.02 REMOVAL FOR MISCONDUCT, INABILITY, OR NEGLECT.
   (A)   Any elected officer, in case of misconduct, inability, or willful
neglect in the performance of the duties of his or her office, may be removed
from office by a unanimous vote of the members of Council exclusive of any
member to be removed, who shall not vote in the deliberation of his or her
removal.
   (B)   No elected officer shall be removed without having been given the
right to a full public hearing. The officer, if removed, shall have the right
to appeal to the circuit court of the county and the appeal shall be on the
record. No officer so removed shall be eligible to fill the office vacated
before the expiration of the term to which originally elected.
(KRS 83A.040(9)) (Prior Code, § 30.11)
§ 30.03 ABOLITION OF OFFICE.
   (A)   Each appointed and elected city office existing on July 15, 1980 shall
continue until abolished by ordinance, except that the offices of Mayor and
Council members may not be abolished.
   (B)   No abolition of any elected office shall take effect until expiration
of the term of the current holder of the office.
   (C)   No ordinance abolishing any elected office shall be enacted later than
240 days preceding the regular election for that office, except in the event of
a vacancy in the office.
(KRS 83A.080(4)) (Prior Code, § 30.12)
§ 30.04 CREATION OF ELECTED OFFICES PROHIBITED.
   The city may not create any elected office. Existing elected offices may be
continued under provision of §
30.03, but no existing elected office may be changed.
(KRS 83A.080(5)) (Prior Code, § 30.13)
§ 30.05 MAYOR.
   (A)   Election; term of office. The Mayor shall be elected by the voters of
the city at a regular election. A candidate for Mayor shall be a resident of
the city for not less than one year prior to his or her election. His or her
term of office shall begin on January 1 following his or her election and shall
be for four years until his or her successor qualifies. If a person is elected
or appointed as Mayor in response to a vacancy and serves less than four
calendar years, then that period of service shall not be considered for
purposes of re-election a term of office.
   (B)   Qualifications. The Mayor shall be at least 21 years of age, shall be
a qualified voter in the city, and shall reside in the city throughout his or
her term of office.
(KRS 83A.040(1))
   (C)   Vacancy. If a vacancy occurs in the office of Mayor, Council shall
fill the vacancy within 30 days. If for any reason, any vacancy in the office
of Mayor is not filled within 30 days after it occurs, the Governor shall
promptly fill the vacancy by appointment of a qualified person who shall serve
for the same period as if otherwise appointed.
(KRS 83A.040(2)(a), (6))
      (1)   When voting to fill a vacancy in the office of Mayor, a member of
the City Council shall not vote for himself or herself.
(KRS 83A.040(2)(c))
      (2)   When voting to fill a vacancy created by the resignation of the
Mayor, the resigning Mayor shall not vote on his or her successor.
(KRS 83A.040(3))
      (3)   No vacancy by reason of a voluntary resignation in the office of
Mayor shall occur unless a written resignation which specifies the resignation
date is tendered to the City Council. The resignation shall be effective at the
next regular or special meeting of the City Council occurring after the date
specified in the written letter of resignation.
(KRS 83A.040(7))
      (4)   If a vacancy occurs in the office of Mayor which is required by law
to be filled temporarily by appointment, the City Council shall immediately
notify in writing both the County Clerk and the Secretary of State of the
vacancy.
(KRS 83A.040(8))
      (5)   The City Council shall elect from among its members an individual
to preside over meetings of the City Council during any vacancy in the office
of the Mayor in accordance with the provisions of KRS 83A.130 to 83A.150.
(KRS 83A.040(2)(d)) (Prior Code, § 30.14)
§ 30.06 COUNCIL MEMBERS.
   (A)   Composition. The Middlesboro Common Council shall consist of nine
individuals.
   (B)   Election; term of office. Each Council member shall be elected at-
large by the voters of the city at a regular election. A candidate for Council
shall be a resident of the city for not less than one year prior to his or her
election. His or her term of office shall begin on January 1 following his or
her election and shall be for two years and until his or her successor
qualifies, except as provided by §
30.01.
   (C)   Qualifications. A member shall be at least 18 years of age, shall be a
qualified voter in the city, and shall reside in the city throughout his or her
term of office.
   (D)   Vacancies. If one or more vacancies on Council occur in a way that one
or more members remain seated, the remaining members shall within 30 days fill
the vacancies one at a time, giving each new appointee reasonable notice of his
or her selection as will enable him or her to meet and act with the remaining
members in making further appointments until all vacancies are filled. If
vacancies occur in a way that all seats become vacant, the Governor shall
appoint qualified persons to fill the vacancies sufficient to constitute a
quorum. Remaining vacancies shall be filled as provided in this section.
      (1)   No vacancy by reason of a voluntary resignation of a member of the
City Council shall occur unless a written resignation which specifies a
resignation date is tendered to the City Council. The resignation shall be
effective at the next regular or special meeting of the city legislative body
occurring after the date specified in the written letter of resignation.
(KRS 83A.040(7))
      (2)   If a vacancy occurs on the City Council which is required by law to
be filled temporarily by appointment, the City Council shall immediately notify
in writing both the County Clerk and the Secretary of State of the vacancy.
(KRS 83A.040(8))
   (E)   Failure to fill vacancies. If for any reason, a vacancy on Council is
not filled within 30 days after it occurs, the Governor shall promptly fill the
vacancy by appointment of a qualified person who shall serve for the same
period as if otherwise appointed.
(KRS 83A.040(4), (5), (6))
(Prior Code, § 30.15) (Ord. FY 95-96, #9, passed 2-7-1996)
§ 30.07 ELECTED OFFICIALS CONDUCTING BUSINESS WITH THE CITY.
   (A)   It shall be improper and illegal for any elected official of the city
who represents any corporation, or who is an officer therein, or who represents
any business or owner thereof, or for any city official who is an employee or
agent of any business or corporation operating in a capacity whose prime
interest is making a profit therein, to enter into any contract, to secure any
service, to make any purchase, or avail itself of the facilities or
professional services with the city if such an act violates KRS 45A.330 to
45A.340. The penalty for violating this division shall be the same as the
penalty set forth in KRS 45A.990(2), for violation of KRS 45A.330 to KRS
45A.340.
   (B)   It shall be permissible for an elected official or his or her company,
employer, business, or firm to conduct business with the city if the service or
product offered by the elected official, company, employer, business, or firm
is the only reasonable outlet the city has for such service or product and
would provide for the orderly operation of the city, or if his or her company,
employer, business, or firm is the successful low bidder in response to an
invitation to bid by the city so long as this action does not conflict with
state law with and receives prior permission from the Common Council at one of
their open meetings.
(Prior Code, § 30.16) (Minute book FF, page 117, passed 3-2-1982; Minute book
FF, page 158, passed 4-20-1982)
Cross-reference:
   Code of Ethics, see
Ch. 41
NONELECTED OFFICERS
§ 30.20 CREATION OF OFFICES.
   All nonelected city offices shall be created by ordinances which shall
specify:
   (A)   Title of office;
   (B)   Powers and duties of office;
   (C)   Oath of office; and
   (D)   Bond, if required.
(KRS 83A.080(1)) (Prior Code, § 30.20)
§ 30.21 APPOINTMENT AND REMOVAL.
   (A)   All nonelected city officers shall be appointed by the Mayor and all
such appointments shall be with approval of Council.
   (B)   The officers may be removed by the Mayor at will unless otherwise
provided by statute or ordinance. Upon removal of a nonelected officer at will,
the Mayor shall give the officer a written statement setting forth the reason
or reasons for the removal. However, this requirement shall not be construed as
limiting in any way the at will dismissal power of the Mayor.
(KRS 83A.080(3)) (Prior Code, § 30.21)
Cross-reference:
   Abolition of appointed office, see §
30.03
§ 30.23 CITY ATTORNEY.
   (A)   There is hereby created the nonelected office of City Attorney.
   (B)   Qualifications for this office are:
      (1)   That any such person be duly licensed to practice law in this
state; and
      (2)   That any such person be a resident of this city.
   (C)   The powers and duties of this office are hereby established as:
      (1)   Attend to all civil cases and proceedings in which the city is
interested or involved;
      (2)   Conduct all legal business pertaining to the city’s interest
touching rights or interests of the city; and
      (3)   Give legal advice to the Mayor, City Council, and any other city
officers in all matters concerning any city business within their respective
jurisdiction upon written request.
   (D)   The City Council and the Mayor may employ independent counsel to
represent the city where, in their collective reasonable judgment, the City
Attorney is not in a position to represent the city fully and completely,
subject to a negotiated hourly rate, plus necessary and reasonable expenses.
   (E)   The oath of office to be executed by the City Attorney shall be that
set forth in § 228 of the State Constitution.
   (F)   Since the City Attorney shall not receive or disburse any city funds,
he or she shall not be required to execute bond to the city.
   (G)   Compensation for this nonelected office shall be at an hourly rate not
to exceed $65 per hour, plus necessary and reasonable expenses as approved by
the City Council.
   (H)   The personnel rules and regulations of the city shall not apply to
this office.
(Prior Code, § 30.22) (Ord. FY 86-87, #11, passed 2-17-1987; Ord. FY 88-89,
#14, passed 2-21-1989; Ord. FY 92-93, #21, passed 6-1-1993)
§ 30.24 CITY CLERK.
   There is hereby created the nonelected office of City Clerk.
   (A)   The powers and duties of the City Clerk shall be as follows.
      (1)   Characteristics of the class. The City Clerk shall be under the
direction of the chief financial officer; serve as Clerk of the Council; act as
official custodian of the public records of the city; maintain possession of
the seal of the city; and report to the chief financial officer as directed.
      (2)   (a)   Examples of duties. The City Clerk shall assist in the
preparation of the agenda for and attend regular and special meetings of the
Council; keep full and accurate minutes of Council proceedings; prepare copies
for each Council member of all reports from the various departments and any
other correspondence relative to items on the agenda for Council consideration;
act as custodian of the seal of the city and of all records and papers not
properly belonging to some other officer; advertise ordinances; serve as
immediate supervisor of other clerical personnel in the city administrative
office; and be subject to the direction of the chief financial officer.
         (b)   Under supervision of the chief financial officer. Under
supervision of the chief financial officer, the City Clerk shall direct the
preparation and mailing of notices relating to various taxes, licenses, fees,
receipts, and the balancing of cash drawers; accept and process occupational
licenses, and miscellaneous bills; order supplies, maintain office equipment,
and issue purchase orders within established guidelines; collect delinquent
taxes and fees; prepare cash reports and maintain records relating to same;
answer complaints and assist with their resolution; and does related work as
required. The Clerk shall also participate in and maintain record keeping for
the collection of taxes, building permits, license fees, insurance premium
taxes, police fines, parking fines, and other receipts and perform any other
duties set forth in KRS 83A.085 which are not otherwise provided for herein.
   (B)   (1)   Minimum qualifications: training and experience. Graduation from
high school, or hold a G.E.D. supplemented by at least two years of business
school and considerable experience in responsible administrative work.
      (2)   Special knowledge, skills, and abilities. Thorough knowledge of the
regulations, procedures, and practices relating to the proceedings of the
Council and the custody and publication of public documents; thorough knowledge
of modern business office procedures; considerable knowledge of the laws and
regulations governing municipal government, state legislation as it affects
local taxes and tax collections and local procedures and policies that apply to
collection of current and delinquent taxes; and the ability to establish and
maintain effective working relationships with the general public and with other
municipal officials and employees.
   (C)   The oath of office to be executed by the City Clerk shall be that set
forth in § 228 of the State Constitution.
   (D)   Bond shall be required of the City Clerk in the amount of $100,000,
the premium of which shall be paid by the city.
   (E)   The compensation for this nonelected office shall be an annual salary
within the parameters of pay grade 28 as provided under class code 1002 on page
III-3 and class code 1002 on page 111-5 of the Personnel Policy as adopted by
reference in §
35.01, which provisions are incorporated herein by reference and made a part
hereof, subject to any pay increases approved generally.
   (F)   The City Clerk may not be removed by the Mayor at will, but rather may
only be removed for cause; cause including, but not being limited to one or
more of the disciplinary infractions in § 5.4(B) of the Personnel Policy as
adopted by reference in §
35.01.
   (G)   The City Clerk shall not be subject to the provisions of § 5.1 of the
Personnel Policy as adopted by reference in §
35.01 which stipulates that all personnel shall be on a probationary status for
six months; rather, the City Clerk shall be deemed a permanent employee from
the date upon which he or she executes the oath of office required herein.
(Prior Code, § 30.23) (Ord. FY 90-91, #10, passed 10-2-1990)
§ 30.25 CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER.
   There is hereby created the nonelected office of chief financial officer.
   (A)   Powers and duties. The powers and duties of the chief financial
officer shall be as follows.
      (1)   Characteristics of the class. The chief financial officer shall be
under direct supervision of the Mayor. The position is responsible for all
financial affairs of the city including management control of bookkeeping and
accounting functions, coordination and reporting of financial activities among
all departments; reporting financial affairs to the Mayor and Council;
supervising directly all department heads with respect to financial-related
activities; and supervise indirectly all city employees with respect to
financial-related activities.
      (2)   Examples of duties. The chief financial officer is directly
responsible for the financial operation of every city department and reports
the financial operation to the Mayor and Council; and takes appropriate actions
pertaining to department financial operation as may be directed by the Council:
         (a)   Responsible for all books and records of all revenues and
expenditures of the city and directly supervises the recording of financial
operation as may be directed by the Council;
         (b)   Advises the Mayor and Council as to financial matters of the
city;
         (c)   Must know of and take advantage of all opportunities for state
and federal grants and loans;
         (d)   Directly responsible for implementation and management of all
state and federal grant programs;
         (e)   Stays abreast of all state and federal regulations, policies,
and executive orders relating to grant programs and administration procedures;
         (f)   Supervises the maintenance of records for all property belonging
to the city;
         (g)   Coordinates city budgets from various department heads;
         (h)   Answers correspondence and questions concerning the city’s
financial status;
         (i)   Works with the City Attorney at the direction of the Mayor and
Council in all legal matters pertaining to city business related to financial
administration;
         (j)   Responsible for the management and safeguarding of city funds
and other assets, to include responsibility for bank accounts and other
investments;
         (k)   Responsible for supervision of all city purchases and
administers procurement policies in accordance with local ordinances and state
law;
         (l)   Responsible for developing specifications for procurement of
equipment and supplies;
         (m)   Responsible for supervising all accounts payable in relation to
purchase orders and requisitions, and makes recommendations for processing;
         (n)   Supervises maintenance of all records relating to business and
privilege licenses for the city including issuance and revenue collections;
         (o)   Supervises record keeping for the collection and verification of
ad valorem taxes from and with the appropriate agencies;
         (p)   Responsible for the prompt reporting of all areas of
responsibilities to the City Auditor when requested;
         (q)   Maintains a complete and current knowledge relating to all
revenue sources of the city;
         (r)   Supervises the operation of computer hardware and software for
financial record keeping of governmental units; and
         (s)   Performs any other duties relating to this position as required.
   (B)   (1)   Minimum qualifications: training and experience. Candidate
should be either a graduate from a four-year college or university, preferably
with specialization in accounting/finance administration areas, or have the
equivalent of extensive experience in public or business administration.
Education or experience background in supervision of accounting records and
financial statement preparation is required.
      (2)   Special knowledge, skills, and abilities. Must be able to deal
effectively with private citizens, commissions, committees, consultants,
contractors, and all other types of people and organizations having contact
with the city, and have expertise in the operation of computer hardware and
software for financial record keeping of governmental units.
   (C)   Oath. The oath of office to be executed by the chief financial officer
shall be that set forth in § 228 of the State Constitution.
   (D)   Bond. Bond shall be required of the chief financial officer in the
amount of $100,000, the premium of which shall be paid by the city.
   (E)   Compensation. The compensation for this nonelected office shall be an
annual salary within the parameters of pay grade 32 as set forth in the
Personnel Policy and as adopted by reference in §
35.01.
   (F)   Removal. The chief financial officer may not be removed by the Mayor
at will, but rather may only be removed for cause; cause including, but not
limited to, one or more disciplinary infractions stipulated in § 5.4(B) of the
Personnel Policy as adopted by reference in §
35.01.
   (G)   The chief financial officer shall not be subject to the provisions of
§ 5.1 of the Personnel Policy as adopted by reference in §
35.01.
(Prior Code, § 30.24) (Ord. FY 90-91, #9, passed 10-2-1990)
Cross-reference:
   Responsibility to enforce city finance regulations, see §
34.01
§ 30.26 POLICE CHIEF.
   There is hereby created the nonelected office of Police Chief.
   (A)   The powers and duties of the Police Chief shall be those set forth on
page II-17 of the Personnel Policy (Ord. FY 87-88, #12) adopted by reference in
§
35.01, which was enacted on March 28, 1988, and is of record in Minute Book PP

56 and 57, the same being incorporated by reference in §
35.01.
   (B)   The oath of office to be executed by the Police Chief shall be that
set forth in § 228 of the State Constitution.
   (C)   No bond shall be required of the Police Chief.
   (D)   The compensation for this nonelected office shall be that provided
under class code 2001 on page III-3 and class code 2001 on page III-5 of the
Personnel Policy (Ord. FY 87-88, #12) which was enacted on March 28, 1988, and
is of record in Minute Book PP on page 207, and which was amended on December
7, 1989, by Ord. FY 89-90, #7, which is of record in Minute Book QQ on page
148, and which are incorporated by reference in §
35.01.
   (E)   The Police Chief may not be removed by the Mayor at will, but rather
may only be removed in the event that the Mayor, or other appropriate person,
prefers charges against the Police Chief as provided in KRS 95.450, which is
incorporated herein by reference and made a part hereof. A due process hearing
before the Council is provided to the Police Chief in connection therewith as
provided in KRS95.450, and the Council fixes the punishment of the Police Chief
by dismissal from the service in accordance with the terms of KRS 95.450(7).
   (F)   The Police Chief shall not be subject to the provisions of § 5.1 of
the Personnel Policy as adopted by reference in §
35.01 which stipulates that all personnel shall be on a probationary status for
six months; rather, the Police Chief shall be deemed a permanent employee from
the date upon which he or she executes the oath of office required herein.
(Prior Code, § 30.25) (Ord. FY 89-90, #15, passed 5-1-1990)
§ 30.27 EQUAL OPPORTUNITY OFFICER.
   (A)   The duties of the equal opportunity officer shall be those outlined in
the city’s affirmative action plan for equal employment opportunity, as it
appears in its entirety in Minute book DD, page number 586, Addendum “A”, dated
October 21, 1980.
   (B)   The equal opportunity officer shall work to implement the provisions
of the affirmative action plan not less than 20 hours per week.
   (C)   The compensation for this office shall be fixed at $400 per month.
   (D)   The position of equal opportunity officer shall have the status of
part-time city employee in relation to benefits and compensations.
(Prior Code, § 30.26) (Ord. FY 86-87, #10, passed 2-3-1987)

OTHER CITY EMPLOYEES
§ 30.40 RECREATION SUPERVISOR.
   (A)   There is hereby created the non-permanent position of city recreation
supervisor.
   (B)   The recreation supervisor will serve as a subordinate to the
recreation director and will have the primary day-to-day responsibility of
administering city programs provided in connection with organized softball
activities, including, but not limited to, the supervision of the operation of
concession stands, and other related activities thereto.
   (C)   Compensation for the non-permanent position of the recreation
supervisor shall be $200 per week.
   (D)   No person shall hold the office of recreation supervisor who does not
possess a certificate of completion from an accredited high school.
   (E)   The Mayor is hereby authorized to hire such non-permanent employees as
may be necessary to staff the concession stand and related activities,
provided, however, that such employees shall be paid by either outside sources
or by the revenues on deposit in the separate checking account which has been
established on current date by municipal order. In the event that such
employees are not paid from outside sources, they shall be entitled to
compensation at the prevailing minimum wage rate.
(Prior Code, § 30.30) (Ord. FY 88-89, #22, passed 5-2-1989)
COMPENSATION OF OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
§ 30.55 ELECTED OFFICERS.
   Council shall by ordinance fix the compensation of every elected city
officer not later than the first Monday in May in the year in which the officer
is elected. An elected officer’s compensation shall not be changed after his or
her election or during his or her term of office.
(KRS 83A.070(1)) (Prior Code, § 30.40)
§ 30.56 CITY EMPLOYEES.
   Council shall fix the compensation of city employees and nonelected city
officers in accordance with a personnel and pay classification plan which shall
be adopted by ordinance.
(KRS 83A.070(2)) (Prior Code, § 30.42)
§ 30.57 FEES AND COMMISSIONS.
   All fees and commissions authorized by law shall be paid into the city
treasury for the benefit of the city and shall not be retained by any officer
or employee.
(KRS 83A.070(3)) (Prior Code, § 30.43)
CHAPTER 31: MAYOR-COUNCIL PLAN

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 31.01 FORM OF GOVERNMENT.
   The form of government provided in this chapter shall be known as the
“Mayor-Council Plan”.
(KRS 83A.130(1)) (Prior Code, § 31.01)
§ 31.02 GOVERNING OFFICERS.
   (A)   The city shall be governed by an elected executive who shall be called
Mayor and by an elected legislative body which shall be called the City
Council, and by such other officers and employees as may be provided for by
statute or city ordinance.
(KRS 83A.130(2))
   (B)   The city shall have a Mayor and a City Council composed of seven
members to be elected from within the city limits at large.
(KRS 83A.030(1)) (Prior Code, § 31.02) (Minute book EE, page 37, passed 3-3-
1981; Ord. FY 93-94, #6, passed 12-9-1993)
MAYOR
§ 31.15 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (A)   The executive authority of the city shall be vested in and exercised
by the Mayor. The Mayor shall enforce the Mayor-Council Plan, city ordinances
and orders, and all applicable statutes. He or she shall supervise all
departments of city government and the conduct of all city officers and
employees under his or her jurisdiction and shall require each department to
make reports to him or her required by ordinance or as he or she deems
desirable.
   (B)   The Mayor shall maintain liaison with related units of local
government respecting interlocal contracting and joint activities.
   (C)   The Mayor shall report to the Council and to the public on the
condition and needs of city government as he or she finds appropriate or as
required by ordinance, but not less than annually. He or she shall make any
recommendations for actions by the Council he or she finds in the public
interest.
(KRS 83A.130(3)) (Prior Code, § 31.10)
Cross-reference:
   Right to review statements submitted to Council pursuant to investigations,
see §
31.39
§ 31.16 PROMULGATION OF ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES.
   Subject to disapproval of the Council, the Mayor shall promulgate procedures
to ensure orderly administration of the functions of city government and
compliance with statute or ordinance. Upon promulgation or upon revision or
rescission of the procedures, copies shall be filed with the person responsible
for maintaining city records as provided under §
32.017.
(KRS 83A.130(4)) (Prior Code, § 31.11)
§ 31.17 PARTICIPATION IN COUNCIL PROCEEDINGS.
   (A)   (1)   The Mayor shall preside at meetings of the Council.
      (2)   The Council may set by ordinance the manner in which one of its
number may be selected to preside at meetings of the Council in place of the
Mayor.
   (B)   The Mayor may participate in Council proceedings, but shall not have a
vote except that he or she may cast the deciding vote in case of a tie.
(KRS 83A.130(5)) (Prior Code, § 31.12)
§ 31.18 APPROVAL OR DISAPPROVAL OF ORDINANCES.
   (A)   All ordinances adopted by the Council shall be submitted to the Mayor
who shall within ten days after submission either approve the ordinance by
affixing his or her signature or disapprove it by returning it to the Council
together with a statement of his or her objections.
   (B)   No ordinance shall take effect without the Mayor’s approval unless he
or she fails to return it to the legislative body within ten days after
receiving it or unless the Council votes to override the Mayor’s veto, upon
reconsideration of the ordinance not later than the second regular meeting
following its return, by the affirmative vote of one more than a majority of
the membership.
(KRS 83A.130(6)) (Prior Code, § 31.13)
§ 31.19 DELEGATION OF DUTIES BY EXECUTIVE ORDER.
   Any delegation of the Mayor’s power, duties, or responsibilities to
subordinate officers and employees and any expression of his or her official
authority to fulfill executive functions shall be made by executive order.
Executive orders shall be sequentially numbered by years and kept in a
permanent file.
(KRS 83A.130(7)) (Prior Code, § 31.14)
§ 31.20 EXECUTION OF BONDS, NOTES, AND CONTRACTS.
   All bonds, notes, contracts, and written obligations of the city shall be
made and executed by the Mayor or his or her agent designated by executive
order.
(KRS 83A.130(8)) (Prior Code, § 31.15)
§ 31.21 APPOINTMENT OF CITY EMPLOYEES.
   The Mayor shall be the appointing authority with power to appoint and remove
all city employees, including police officers, except as tenure and terms of
employment are protected by statute, ordinance, or contract and except for
employees of the Council.
(KRS 83A.130(9)) (Prior Code, § 31.16)
§ 31.22 PROCEDURE UPON DISABILITY; VACANCY.
   (A)   The Mayor shall provide for the orderly continuation of the functions
of city government at any time he or she is unable to attend to the duties of
his or her office by delegating responsibility for any function to be
performed, in accordance with §
31.19, provided that the Mayor shall not delegate the responsibility of
presiding at meetings of the Council and that approving ordinances or
promulgating administrative procedures may only be delegated to an elected
officer. With approval of the Council, the Mayor may rescind any action taken
in his or her absence under this section within 30 days of the action.
   (B)   If for any reason the disability of the Mayor to attend to his or her
duties persists for 60 consecutive days, the office of Mayor may be declared
vacant by a majority vote of the Council and the provisions of §
30.05 shall apply.
(KRS 83A.130(10)) (Prior Code, § 31.17)
COUNCIL
§ 31.35 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The legislative authority of the city shall be vested in and exercised by
the elected Council of the city. The Council shall not perform any executive
functions except those functions assigned to it by statute.
(KRS 83A.130(11)) (Prior Code, § 31.30)
§ 31.36 MEETINGS.
   (A)   Regular meeting of the Council shall be held at least once each month
at such times and places as are fixed by ordinance.
   (B)   Special meetings of the Council may be called by the Mayor of upon
written request of a majority of the Council. On the call, the Mayor or Council
shall designate the purpose, time, and place of the special meeting with
sufficient notice for the attendance of Council members and for compliance with
KRS Chapter 61. The City Clerk shall be responsible for notification pursuant
to KRS Chapter 65A and any other applicable statutes. The City Clerk’s
responsibility shall be the same, whether the meeting is called by the Mayor or
the members of the City Council.
   (C)   At a special meeting no business may be considered other than that set
forth in the designation of purpose.
   (D)   The minutes of every meeting shall be signed by the person responsible
for maintaining city records provided under §
32.017 and by the officer presiding at the meeting.
(KRS 83A.130(11)) (Prior Code, § 31.31) (Ord. FY 84-85, #1, passed 8-7-1984)
Cross-reference:
   Public meetings, see
Ch. 40
§ 31.37 ESTABLISHMENT OF APPOINTIVE OFFICES.
   The Council shall by ordinance establish all appointive offices and the
duties and responsibilities of those offices and codes, rules, and regulations
for the public health, safety, and welfare.
(KRS 83A.130(12)) (Prior Code, § 31.32)
§ 31.38 MANAGEMENT OF CITY RESOURCES.
   The Council shall provide, by ordinance, for sufficient revenue to operate
city government and shall appropriate the funds of the city in a budget which
provides for the orderly management of city resources.
(KRS 83A.130(12)) (Prior Code, § 31.33)
§ 31.39 INVESTIGATION OF CITY GOVERNMENT ACTIVITIES.
   (A)   The Council shall have the right to investigate all activities of city
government. The Council may require any city officer or employee to prepare and
submit to it sworn statements regarding his or her performance of his or her
official duties.
   (B)   Any statement required by the Council to be submitted or any
investigation undertaken by the Council, if any office, department, or agency
under the jurisdiction of the Mayor is involved, shall not be submitted or
undertaken unless and until written notice of the Council’s action is given to
the Mayor. The Mayor shall have the right to review any statement before
submission to the Council and to appear personally or through his or her
designee on behalf of any department, office, or agency in the course of any
investigation.
(KRS 83A.130(13)) (Prior Code, § 31.34)
§ 31.40 PRESIDING OFFICER AT MEETINGS.
   The Council may set by ordinance the manner in which one of its number may
be selected to preside at meetings of the Council in place of the Mayor.
(Prior Code, § 31.35) (Minute book FF, page 83, passed 1-19-1982)
§ 31.41 ATTORNEY FOR THE CITY COUNCIL.
   (A)   There is hereby created the non-elected office of Attorney for the
City Council, to be appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the City Council.
The Attorney for the City Council shall be under the sole direction and
authority of the City Council.
   (B)   The powers and duties of the Attorney for the City Council shall be as
follows:
      (1)   To attend to all civil cases and proceedings in which the City
Council is interested or involved;
      (2)   To attend all Council meetings and provide advice and counsel to
the City Council regarding legal business before it; and
      (3)   To perform any and all other duties directed by the Council.
   (C)   The oath of office for the Attorney for the City Council shall be that
set forth in § 228 of the Constitution of the commonwealth.
   (D)   The Attorney for the City Council shall not receive or disburse any
city funds and shall not be required to execute bond to the city.
   (E)   The compensation of the Attorney for the City Council shall be $1,000
per month, plus reasonable and necessary expenses are approved by the Council.
   (F)   The personnel rules and regulations of the city shall not apply to the
office of the Attorney for the City Council.
(Prior Code, § 31.36) (Minute book FF, page 83, passed 1-19-1982)
