PARKS, PLAYGROUNDS, AND RECREATION BOARD
§ 32.001 PARKS, PLAYGROUNDS, AND RECREATION BOARD REPEALED.
   (A)   The city hereby repeals in its entirety its ordinance establishing and
creating a Parks, Playgrounds and Recreation Board.
   (B)   All books, correspondence, records, and the like of the Board shall be
returned to the City Council who will hereby operate, maintain, and provide
recreational facilities in the city, as recommended by previous audits.
   (C)   The present Recreation Board is commended for a job well done and such
present Board shall become an advisory board to the present City Council.
(Prior Code, § 32.01) (Minute Book GG, page 3, passed 9-21-1982)
ELECTRIC BOARD
§ 32.015 ELECTRIC BOARD ESTABLISHED.
   The Mayor, as the chief executive officer of the municipality, shall, in
compliance with KRS 96.550 through 96.900, appoint a board subject to the
approval of the Council, which board shall be named the “Electric Plant Board
of the City of Middlesboro”.
(Prior Code, § 32.05)
§ 32.016 CITY TO OPERATE ELECTRIC PLANT.
   The city desires to acquire and operate its own electric plant under the
provisions of KRS 96.550 through 96.900 and accepts and agrees to all the
provisions of these sections and to all of the provisions as they may be from
time to time amended by the acts of the General Assembly of Kentucky.
(Prior Code, § 32.06)
§ 32.017 EXPENDITURES.
   (A)   The city shall not be liable for the payment of any salaries,
compensations, or expenses of any of the members of the Electric Plant Board of
the city or for the payment of salaries, compensations, or expenses of any
person or persons employed by the Board.
   (B)   Such salaries, compensations, expenses, and any and all liabilities of
whatever kind or character incurred by the Board, or any officer or employee
thereof, shall be payable solely and only out of revenue obtained by the Board
under the provisions of KRS 96.550 through 96.900, and the liabilities shall
then be so limited.
(Prior Code, § 32.07)
PENSION BOARD
§ 32.030 PENSION FUND FOR POLICE OFFICERS AND FIREFIGHTERS ESTABLISHED.
   There is created in the city a Policemen’s and Firemen’s Pension Fund.
(Prior Code, § 32.10) (Minute book T, page 330, passed 12-20-1966)
Statutory reference:
   Policemen’s and Firemen’s Pension Fund, KRS 95.621 through 95.629
§ 32.031 BOARD OF TRUSTEES ESTABLISHED.
   (A)   The Board of Trustees of the Policemen’s and Firemen’s Pension Fund
shall be composed of the Mayor, City Treasurer, Chief of Police, Chief of the
Fire Department, and one retired member each from the Police and Fire
Departments shall be elected by the retired respective members of those
Departments annually by ballot, who shall serve one year or until their
successors are elected and qualified. The Board shall select from their number
a President and a Secretary. If there are six or more active members of the
Fund, there shall be two additional Board members who shall be one active
member of the Fund from each Department elected by the active members of the
Fund from the respective Departments and who shall serve for one year and until
their successors are elected and qualified. If all of the six or more active
members or all of the retired members are from one Department, then both of the
active member Board members or both of the retired members, as the case may be,
shall be elected from that Department. The Board of Trustees shall be the
trustees of the Pension Fund and of all moneys donated or paid for the relief
or pensioning of members of the Police and Fire Departments. The Board may do
all things necessary to protect the Fund.
   (B)   The Board of Trustees may draw the Pension Fund from the treasury and
invest it, in whole or in part, in the name of the board or nominee name as
provided by KRS 16.642, as the Board deems most advantageous for the objects of
the Fund, in a local government pension investment fund created pursuant to KRS
95.895 or in any other securities in which trustees are permitted to invest
trust funds under the laws of this state. The securities shall be subject to
the order of the Board.
(Prior Code, § 32.11) (Minute book T, page 330, passed 12-20-1966)
Statutory reference:
   Pension fund created, see KRS 95.622
§ 32.032 POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE BOARD.
   (A)   The Board of Trustees of the pension fund may make all necessary rules
for its government in the discharge of its duties, and shall hear and decide
all applications for benefits or pensions. Its decisions on these applications
shall be conclusive, and not subject to revision or reversal, except by the
Board as provided in §
32.035. A record shall be kept of the meetings and proceedings of the Board.
   (B)   The Board of Trustees of the pension fund shall make an annual report
on the condition of the pension fund to the Common Council at its first meeting
in May of each year.
(KRS 95.623) (Prior Code, § 32.12) (Minute book T, page 330, passed 12-20-1966)
§ 32.033 CITY ATTORNEY TO ADVISE AND REPRESENT BOARD OF TRUSTEES.
   The City Attorney shall, if requested, advise the Board of Trustees of the
Policemen’s and Firemen’s Pension Fund in all matters pertaining to its duties
and to the management of the Fund. He or she shall represent and defend the
Board in all actions that may be brought against it, and bring all actions in
its behalf that may be requested by the Board.
(KRS 95.623) (Prior Code, § 32.13) (Minute book T, page 330, passed 12-20-1966)
§ 32.034 PENSIONS OR BENEFITS PAID FOR DISABILITY OR DEATH.
   The pensions or benefits paid for disability or death from the Policemen’s
and Firemen’s Pension Fund shall be as follows.
   (A)   If any member of the Police and Fire Department becomes temporarily
totally disabled, physically or mentally, the Board of Trustees of the pension
fund shall order paid to him or her monthly, during his or her disability,
until he or she has recovered and returned to active duty a sum of not more
than one-half his or her salary per month, the amount to be determined by the
Board. This provision shall not apply if a salary is paid during the same
period.
   (B)   If any member of the Police or Fire Department becomes permanently
disabled, physically or mentally, so as to render his or her retirement from
service in the Department necessary, the Board of Trustees shall retire him or
her from service and order paid to him or her monthly 50% of his or her monthly
salary at the time of his or her retirement.
   (C)   If any member of the Police or Fire Department is killed or dies as
the result of an injury received in the performance of duty, or dies of any
disease contracted by reasons of his or her occupation, or dies while in the
service from any cause as a result of his or her service in the Department, or
dies in service or while on the retired list from any cause after one year of
service in the Department and leaves a widow or a child under 18 years of age,
the Board of Trustees shall order a pension paid to the widow, while unmarried,
of one-half of the deceased’s salary per month and for each child until he or
she reaches the age of 18 years, $24 per month. If the deceased member was
unmarried and childless, a pension shall be paid to his or her dependent father
and mother of one-fourth of his or her salary per month. If one parent is dead,
the other shall receive the entire one-fourth salary.
(KRS 95.624(3)) (Prior Code, § 32.14) (Minute book T, page 330, passed 12-20-
1966)
§ 32.035 PETITION FOR RETIREMENT.
   (A)   All service in the Police and Fire Departments shall be treated on a
cumulative basis, and not consecutive, for purposes of qualification of members
of those Departments for pension benefits hereunder. Any member of either
Department, having cumulatively served 20 years or longer, may petition the
Board of Trustees for retirement, and, upon approval of the petition, upon
retirement the member shall be paid in accordance with the following schedule:
 
20 to 25 years     50% of salary at time of retirement plus 2% of salary for
                   each year in excess of 20
25 to 30 years     60% of salary at time of retirement plus 3% of each year in
                   excess of 25
30 years or longer Maximum of 75% of salary at time of retirement
 
   (B)   With respect to members of the Police and Fire Departments not
specifically listed by ordinance, §§
32.030 through
32.041 shall be applicable in all respects with the exception that pension fund
benefits, although vested, may not be paid or disbursed to any individual until
he or she has attained the age of 65 years.
(Prior Code, § 32.15) (Minute book T, page 330, passed 12-20-1966; Minute book
CC, page 109, passed 9-15-1978)
Statutory reference:
   Pension payment amounts, see KRS 95.624(2)
§ 32.036 EFFECT OF SERVICE IN THE ARMED FORCES OF THE UNITED STATES ON PENSION
STATUS.
   Any member of the Police or Fire Department, who, while a member of the
Police or Fire Department, entered the armed forces of the United States, and
who was honorably discharged therefrom shall upon his or her return to that
Police or Fire Department be entitled to the same pension or benefits provided
by this subchapter as if the member had remained on active duty with that
Police or Fire Department, and his or her time served in the armed forces shall
be added to his or her previous service and shall be construed for purposes of
eligibility for pensions or benefits, either for himself or herself or his or
her beneficiaries, as a part and continuation of his or her consecutive years
of service with that Police or Fire Department; except this section shall apply
only to those members who served in World War II or any emergency conflict
called by the President of the United States, who apply for reinstatement
within 90 days after the date on which the member first received or could have
received an honorable discharge, and shall not apply to those members re-
enlisting in the armed forces of the United States.
(Prior Code, § 32.16) (Minute book T, page 330, passed 12-20-1966)
Statutory reference:
   Military service of member, see KRS 95.625
§ 32.037 FUNERAL EXPENSES.
   When an active or retired member of the Police or Fire Department dies under
the conditions set out in §
32.034(C) the Board of Trustees of the pension fund may pay from the fund to
the widow, or widower or family a sum of not more than $200 for funeral
expenses.
(KRS 95.570) (Prior Code, § 32.17) (Minute book T, page 330, passed 12-20-1966)
§ 32.038 THE FINANCING OF THE PENSION FUND.
   (A)   The Policemen’s and Firemen’s Pension Fund shall consist of:
      (1)   Revenues of the city authorized by the Council, which shall be not
less than the amount contributed by the members of the Police and Fire
Departments. Police officers and firefighters shall contribute the same rate as
social security from their salary; and
      (2)   All rewards, fees, gifts, and emoluments paid or given on account
of extraordinary service of any member of the Police or Fire Department.
   (B)   Both the principal and interest of the pension fund shall be
applicable to the payment of pensions.
(Prior Code, § 32.18) (Minute book T, page 330, passed 12-20-1966)
Statutory reference:
   Sources of pension fund, see KRS 95.627
§ 32.039 TREASURER OF FUND, DUTIES.
   (A)   The City Treasurer shall be ex officio treasurer of the Board of
Trustees of the Pension Fund, and custodian of the Pension Fund.
   (B)   The Treasurer, as custodian, shall securely keep the fund, subject to
the control of the Board, and shall keep his or her books and accounts
concerning the Fund in such manner as may be prescribed by the Board. The books
and accounts shall always be subject to the inspection of the Board or any
Board member.
   (C)   The Treasurer shall, within ten days after his or her election,
execute a bond to the city with good surety, in such penal sum as the Board of
Trustees directs, to be approved by the Board, conditioned for the faithful
performance of the duties of his or her office, and that he or she will safely
keep and well and truthfully account for all money and properties that come
into his or her hands as Treasurer of the Pension Fund, and that upon the
expiration of his or her term of office he or she will deliver to his or her
successor all securities, unexpended moneys, and other properties that come
into his or her hands as Treasurer of the Fund. The bond shall be filed in the
office of the Treasurer, and suit may be filed thereon in the name of the city
for the use of the Board or any person injured by its breach.
(KRS 95.628) (Prior Code, § 32.19) (Minute book T, page 330, passed 12-20-1966)
§ 32.040 PAYMENT WHEN FUND IS INSUFFICIENT.
   (A)   In case of insufficient funds the city will be held responsible for
the payment of the monthly payments of the Pension Fund after the entire
proceeds of the Pension Fund have been transferred to the General Fund of the
city.
   (B)   Revenues of the city authorized by the Council to support the Pension
Fund shall be computed by determining the amount needed to meet the monthly
requirements of this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 32.20) (Minute book T, page 330, passed 12-20-1966)
Cross-reference:
   Taxation, see
Ch. 38
Statutory reference:
   City’s obligation as to funding, see KRS 95.629
§ 32.041 POLICE OFFICERS OR FIREFIGHTERS NOT WISHING TO PARTICIPATE IN FUND.
   Any member of the Police or Fire Department serving at the time of the
passage of this subchapter and not desiring to participate in the Fund and its
benefits may be excluded by notifying the Board of Trustees of the Pension Fund
in writing of his or her desire not to participate.
(Prior Code, § 32.21) (Minute book T, page 330, passed 12-20-1966)
Statutory reference:
   Members excluded, see KRS 95.621
§ 32.042 PARTICIPATION IN COUNTY EMPLOYEES RETIREMENT SYSTEM.
   (A)   The pension plan established for its employees under KRS 95.621 is
hereby frozen effective August 1, 1988, to participation by those existing
employees who are then participating therein and who file with the city on or
before October 31, 1988, a written election to continue participating therein
in lieu of participating in CERS.
   (B)   The city hereby elects to participate in CERS effective August 1,
1988, and authorizes the Mayor to execute the appropriate instruments to
effectuate such election.
   (C)   All employees now participating in said existing city pension plan are
hereby authorized to terminate such participation and transfer to CERS.
   (D)   The city shall continue to fund and manage its existing pension plan
for the benefit of any employees electing to continue therein and those who are
entitled to benefits in the existing pension plan.
   (E)   Employees hired after August 1, 1988 who are otherwise eligible to
participate in the city pension plan shall participate only in CERS.
   (F)   The city hereby adopts the terms and provisions of the CERS under KRS
78.510 through 78.852, elects the alternate participation plan under KRS 78.530
(3), and declares its intention to enter into an agreement with the Board of
Trustees for the amortization of the cost of such prior service credit over a
30-year period commencing on or about August 1, 1988.
   (G)   The individual employee accounts in the existing city pension plan
shall be transferred to CERS for credit to the respective employee’s individual
account in CERS, pursuant to KRS 78.531(1) and (2), upon the election of such
employees to participate in CERS.
   (H)   The Mayor is hereby directed to certify to the Board of Trustees the
names of all employees deemed to be working in a hazardous position for
purposes of KRS 61.592, and all police officers and firefighters employed after
August 1, 1988, shall, if otherwise qualified, be eligible for CERS hazardous
position coverage.
(Prior Code, § 32.22) (Ord. FY 88-89, #2, passed 7-19-1988)
HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION
§ 32.055 HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION ESTABLISHED.
   (A)   There is established a City Commission on Human Rights.
   (B)   The Commission shall be composed of 25 members. The members shall be
appointed by the Mayor and approved by the Council, who shall select persons
who are nearly as possible representatives of the several social, economic,
religious, cultural, ethnic, and racial groups which comprise the population of
the city.
   (C)   No elected or appointed official of the city may be a member of the
Commission.
   (D)   Initially the members of the Commission shall be appointed to serve
for a term of one, two, and three years, and members appointed after the
original appointment shall serve for a term of three years each, except if a
vacancy occurs on the Commission other than as a result of the expiration of
the term of an appointment, the Mayor shall appoint a successor for the
unexpired term. Members may be eligible for reappointment for additional terms.
   (E)   A quorum shall consist of 13 members.
   (F)   Members shall serve without compensation.
(Prior Code, § 32.25)
§ 32.056 FUNCTION OF COMMISSION.
   (A)   The Commission shall endeavor to promote and secure mutual
understanding and respect among all economic, social, religious, ethnic, and
racial groups in the city, and shall act as conciliator in controversies
involving intergroup and interracial relations. The Commission shall cooperate
with federal, state, and other city agencies in an effort to develop harmonious
intergroup and interracial relations and shall endeavor to enlist the support
of civic, religious, labor, industrial, and commercial groups and civic leaders
dedicated to the improvements of intergroup and interracial relations and the
elimination of discriminatory practices.
   (B)   The Commission shall receive complaints, conduct investigations, hold
hearings, make studies, and have such studies made as will enable the
Commission to carry out the purpose of this section.
   (C)   The Commission shall recommend to the Mayor and to the Council such
legislation as may be necessary to accomplish the purposes of this section.
   (D)   The Commission shall submit an annual report on March l, of each year
to the Mayor and to the Common Council.
   (E)   The Commission, on behalf of the city, may accept grants and donations
from foundations and others for the purpose of carrying out its functions.
(Prior Code, § 32.26)
§ 32.057 EXPENDITURES.
   All expenditures shall be authorized by the Commission which shall elect one
of its members as Treasurer. The Treasurer shall approve operational
expenditures, and he or she shall make a semiannual financial report to the
Commission. Copies of such semiannual financial report shall be sent to the
Mayor and Common Council.
(Prior Code, § 32.27)
§ 32.058 ORGANIZATION; MEETINGS.
   (A)   The Commission shall have the power to adopt rules to govern its
proceedings. The regular monthly meetings of the Commission shall be open to
the public at a designated time and place.
   (B)   The Commission shall meet as often as it deems necessary, but it shall
not meet less than once each month.
   (C)   The Commission shall elect a Chairperson, a Vice-Chairperson, a
Secretary-Treasurer, and such other officers as it shall deem necessary. The
Chairperson of the Commission shall appoint such committees as the rules of the
Commission shall provide and such other special committees from time to time as
the Commission may deem necessary in order to carry out the purposes of §§
32.055 through
32.058.
(Prior Code, § 32.28)
CITY PLANNING COMMISSION
§ 32.070 PLANNING COMMISSION ESTABLISHED.
   The Planning Commission shall consist of seven members, all of which shall
be residents of the city. At least five of the members shall be citizen
members. The Planning Commission as constituted at the time of adoption of this
subchapter shall continue in office. Future appointments shall be in keeping
with §
32.072.
(Prior Code, § 32.30) (Ord. FY 91-92, #2, passed 9-3-1991)
§ 32.071 APPOINTING AUTHORITY.
   The Mayor of the city shall appoint seven members of the Planning Commission
with the approval of the City Council.
(Prior Code, § 32.31) (Ord. FY 91-92, #2, passed 9-3-1991)
§ 32.072 MEMBERSHIP.
   (A)   Term of office. The term of office of all elected public officials
shall be the same as their official tenure in office. The terms of office for
other members shall be four years, but the term of office of members first
appointed shall be staggered so that a proportional number serve one, two,
three, and four years respectively, and later appointments or reappointments
shall continue that staggered pattern.
   (B)   Vacancies. Vacancies shall be filled within 60 days by the Mayor. If
the Mayor fails to act within that time, the Planning Commission shall fill the
vacancy. When a vacancy occurs other than through expiration of the term of
office, it shall be filled for the remainder of that term.
   (C)   Oath of office. All members of the Planning Commission shall, before
taking office qualify by taking the oath of office prescribed by § 228 of the
Constitution of the commonwealth before any judge, notary public, clerk of a
court, or justice of peace within the city.
   (D)   Removal. Any member of the Planning Commission may be removed by the
Mayor with approval of the appropriate governmental body for inefficiency,
neglect of duty, malfeasance, or conflict of interest.
(Prior Code, § 32.32) (Ord. FY 91-92, #2, passed 9-3-1991)
§ 32.073 MEETINGS, PROCEDURES.
   (A)   The Planning Commission shall elect a Chairperson and Vice-Chairperson
and adopt rules necessary to the conduct of its affairs in keeping with the
provisions of this chapter. Regular meetings shall be held at least six times
annually. Special meetings shall be held at the call of the Chairperson and at
such other times as the Commission may determine. All meetings shall be open to
the public. The Commission shall keep minutes of its procedures, including
regulations, transactions, findings, and determinations, and the number of
votes for and against each question, and if any member is absent or
disqualifies from voting, indicating the fact.
   (B)   A simple majority of the total membership of the Commission (four)
shall constitute a quorum. A member having a financial interest in the outcome
of any application before the commission shall disclose the nature of the
interest and shall disqualify himself or herself from voting on the question,
and shall not be counted for the purpose of a quorum. If it is discovered that
a member failed to properly excuse himself or herself, his or her vote on an
issue in question will be void. A simple majority vote of all members present
where there is a properly constituted quorum shall be necessary to transact any
official business except that a vote of a simple majority of the total
membership shall be necessary for the adoption or amendment of the Commission’s
bylaws, or for elements of the comprehensive plan or regulations.
(Prior Code, § 32.33) (Ord. FY 91-92, #2, passed 9-3-1991)
§ 32.074 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Planning Commission shall:
   (A)   Prepare a comprehensive plan;
   (B)   Review and amend the comprehensive plan as necessary; and
   (C)   Review all proposed amendments to this chapter and make
recommendations to the City Council.
(Prior Code, § 32.34) (Ord. FY 91-92, #2, passed 9-3-1991)
§ 32.075 EMPLOYMENT OF STAFF.
   The Planning Commission may employ a staff or contract with planners or
other persons as it deems necessary to accomplish its assigned duties.
(Prior Code, § 32.35) (Ord. FY 91-92, #2, passed 9-3-1991)
§ 32.076 FINANCES.
   The City Council may appropriate out of general revenues for the expenses
and accommodations necessary for the work of the Planning Commission. The
Planning Commission shall have the right to receive, hold, and spend funds
which it may legally receive from any and every source both in and out of the
commonwealth, including the U.S. government, for the purposes of carrying out
its duties.
(Prior Code, § 32.36) (Ord. FY 91-92, #2, passed 9-3-1991)
HOUSING COMMISSION
§ 32.090 HOUSING COMMISSION ESTABLISHED.
   A Housing Commission is created for the city. The name of the commission
shall be the “City of Middlesboro Municipal Housing Commission”. The members of
the municipal Housing Commission shall serve without pay but shall be entitled
to necessary expenses incurred in the discharge of their duties.
(Prior Code, § 32.40)
INDUSTRIAL COMMISSION
§ 32.105 INDUSTRIAL COMMISSION ESTABLISHED.
   (A)   There is hereby created an agency of city government to be known as
the Middlesboro Industrial Commission, which shall exist and operate for the
public purposes of alleviating unemployment and furthering the utilization of
natural and human-made resources by the promotion, encouragement, and
development of industrial and manufacturing enterprises in the city.
   (B)   The Commission shall be composed of seven members to be selected as
follows:
      (1)   The Mayor shall be a member;
      (2)   The Mayor shall, subject to approval of the City Council, appoint
two members from the City Council; and
      (3)   The Mayor shall, subject to approval of the Common Council, appoint
four persons from the public at large with industrial and state related
contacts.
   (C)   Three members shall be appointed for terms of one year, three members
shall be appointed for terms of two years. All members shall serve for the term
appointed and until their successors are duly appointed and qualified. The
Mayor shall designate the term of each member at the time of appointment. The
member selected from the City Council will serve during appointee’s term of
office as Council member. Their successors shall each be appointed for a term
of two years, except that any person appointed to fill a vacancy shall serve
only for the unexpired term. Any appointed member of the Commission shall be
eligible for reappointment.
   (D)   Members of the Industrial Commission shall be paid no compensation for
their services, but may be reimbursed for expenses incurred in discharging
their duties as members of the Commission.
(Prior Code, § 32.50) (Ord. FY 94-95, #19, passed 12-20-1994)
§ 32.106 QUORUM, VOTING.
   (A)   A majority of the Commission members shall constitute a quorum for the
purpose of organizing the Commission and conducting the business thereof, and,
except in the instance of application for financial assistance, all action may
be taken by a vote of a majority of the members present.
   (B)   Approval or rejection of loan applications shall be by a two-thirds
vote of the full membership of the Commission, and no contract shall be
submitted to the City Council for final approval passage, which would require
the issuance of any city industrial building bonds, until it has been approved
by the fiscal agent and the Department of Economic Development of the
commonwealth.
(Prior Code, § 32.51)
§ 32.107 POWERS OF COMMISSION.
   The Commission shall have all necessary and proper power for the successful
carrying out of its purpose of attracting industrial and commercial prospects
to the city, and it may use part or all of the sums annually received from any
source to do anything expedient to advertise and promote the resources and
advantages of the city as a business and industrial center.
(Prior Code, § 32.52)
§ 32.108 EXPENDITURES.
   Funds appropriated by the city shall be spent for industrial promotion to
create additional jobs for the citizens of the city, and shall be spent in a
manner to be determined by the Industrial Commission which will further the
industrial development of the city.
(Prior Code, § 32.53)
§ 32.109 CERTIFICATION OF FUNDS; APPROPRIATIONS.
   The Commission shall by resolution adopted semiannually, direct the
Secretary and Treasurer of the Commission to certify to the City Council the
amount of funds on hand and available for the ensuing six months. The City
Council will, at the beginning of each fiscal year, appropriate from the
General Fund moneys for Industrial Commission purposes subject to availability
of the funds.
(Prior Code, § 32.54) (Minute book T, page 205, passed 5-17-1966; Minute book
U, page 238, passed 4-2-1968; Ord. FY 94-95, #16, passed 12-20-1994)
§ 32.110 DEPOSIT OF FUNDS.
   The Treasurer shall receive all funds belonging to the Commission, including
all appropriations of the city governing body. He or she shall pay out the same
on bills allowed by the Commission and certified by the Chairperson and
Secretary of the Commission.
(Prior Code, § 32.55)
§ 32.111 SURETY BOND FOR TREASURER.
   The Treasurer shall give bond, the amount to be fixed by the Commission at
not less than the sum likely to come into his or her hands.
(Prior Code, § 32.56)
§ 32.112 SEMI-ANNUAL FINANCIAL STATEMENT.
   The Secretary and Treasurer shall, at the close of each semiannual period,
file with the Commission an accurate detailed report of all receipts and
disbursements of the Commission, showing the source of such receipts, to whom
paid and for what purpose. The report shall be sworn to by the Secretary and
Treasurer, and a copy shall be filed with the City Clerk.
(Prior Code, § 32.57)
OFFICE OF COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT
§ 32.125 PURPOSE.
   It is declared that there exists in the city slum areas or blighted areas;
that there is a need in the city for the exercise of the powers, functions, and
duties authorized by KRS 99.330 through 99.510; that there is a need for
designation of an office to make application for, receive, and administer
grants for community development for the United States Department of Housing
and Urban Development (HUD) and other sources; and that a city department
established pursuant to KRS 99.490 is the most effective office for meeting
these needs.
(Prior Code, § 32.60) (Minute book BB, pages 459 and 465, passed 2-21-1978;
Minute book DD, page 368, passed 2-19-1980)
§ 32.126 ESTABLISHMENT; DUTIES.
   (A)   There is created and established a department of the city to be known
as the Middlesboro Office of Community Development.
   (B)   The Office is authorized to exercise all of the powers, functions, and
duties set forth in KRS 99.330 through 99.510.
   (C)   The Office shall make any applications for grants or other funds from
the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) or any
other state or federal agency which makes funds available to cities for
community development activities and shall receive and administer such funds
and any other community development funds on behalf of the city.
(Prior Code, § 32.61) (Minute book BB, pages 459 and 465, passed 2-21-1978;
Minute book DD, page 368, passed 2-19-1980)
§ 32.127 ADMINISTRATION.
   There is created the “Middlesboro Office of Community Development” to
exercise the powers of KRS 99.360 through 99.510, administered by a director,
as a city officer.
   (A)   Special committee.
      (1)   The Council shall elect five of its members to serve as a special
committee, to be called the “Middlesboro Office of Community Development
Committee”.
      (2)   Each member of the Committee shall be appointed to serve during his
or her term of office as a Council member. The Committee shall elect a
Chairperson from among its members.
   (B)   Director.
      (1)   The director of the Office of Community Development shall be
appointed by the City Council upon recommendation of the Committee.
      (2)   The director shall report to the Committee periodically as required
regarding the community development activities and shall maintain all records
required by law or directed by the Committee. The Committee shall, in turn,
report to the Mayor and Council all activities and progress of the office and
exercise such oversight functions as may be required by the Council and Mayor.
      (3)   The director shall employ, assign, supervise, and discipline such
employees as are provided for the office.
(Prior Code, § 32.62) (Minute book, DD, page 368, approved 2-19-1980)

112.15 and
112.16.

TREE BOARD
§ 32.155 ESTABLISHMENT.
   A Tree Board, the members of which are to be appointed by the Mayor and
approved by the City Council, with the exception of the permanent members
provided for herein, shall be and hereby is established for the city.
(Prior Code, § 32.80) (Ord. FY 89-90, #9, passed - -)
§ 32.156 MEMBERSHIP.
   The Tree Board shall consist of seven members, at least four of whom shall
be concerned and interested citizens of the city. Two members shall be
professionals in the tree field, one of whom shall be a landscape specialist
and the other a person actively engaged in horticulture. The sanitation
supervisor, the recreational director of the city, and the Superintendent of
the Street Department or their representatives shall be permanent members of
the Tree Board. The terms of the Tree Board members, excepting the sanitation
supervisor, the recreation director, and the Superintendent of Street
Department or their representatives, shall be four years. The first Board shall
include four members appointed for the following terms: one member for four
years; one member for three years; one member for two years; and one member for
one year. In the event that a vacancy shall occur during the term of any
appointed member, a successor shall be appointed by the Mayor and approved by
the City Council to serve the unexpired portion of said member’s term. All
members of the Tree Board shall serve without pay.
(Prior Code, § 32.81) (Ord. FY 89-90, #9, passed - -; Ord. FY 89-90, #11,
passed 2-20-1990)
§ 32.157 RULES AND REGULATIONS; MEETINGS.
   The first Tree Board shall establish the Board’s initial rules, regulations,
and procedures, and arrange for the holding of meetings on a regular basis,
with not less than four meetings per calendar year. The Tree Board may
thereafter modify the rules, regulations, and procedures by majority vote.
(Prior Code, § 32.82) (Ord. FY 89-90, #9, passed - -)
§ 32.158 DUTIES.
   The duties of the Tree Board shall be to advise appropriate municipal
agencies and officials on matters of care, preservation, planting, removal,
replacement, or disposition of trees in parks, along streets and in public
areas as needed, as well as to assist the city in obtaining and/or
administering related grants as needed, subject to the approval of the Mayor
and the City Council.
(Prior Code, § 32.83) (Ord. FY 89-90, #9, passed - -)
LABOR MANAGEMENT BOARD
§ 32.170 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   EMPLOYEE. Any person employed by the City of Middlesboro, Kentucky, or any
person terminated from employment who grieves such termination.
   GRIEVANCE. Any work-related matter which the employee believes to be unfair
or not in compliance with the Middlesboro personnel policy.
(Prior Code, § 32.90) (Ord. FY 91-92, #7, passed 11-6-1991)
§ 32.171 ESTABLISHMENT.
   The Labor Management Board of the city (the “Board”), the members of which
are to be appointed by the Mayor and approved by the City Council, shall be and
hereby is established for the city.
(Prior Code, § 32.91) (Ord. FY 91-92, #7, passed 11-6-1991)
§ 32.172 MEMBERSHIP, TERM, VACANCY, COMPENSATION.
   (A)   The Board shall consist of three members. The terms of the Board
members shall be three years. The first Board shall have members appointed for
the following terms: one member for three years; one member for two years; and
one member for one year. Non-supervisory/management employees of the city will
submit three names to the Mayor, and the Bell County Chamber of Commerce will
submit three names to the Mayor. The Mayor will select one from each panel. The
third member of the Board shall be the Chairperson of the Board and shall be
selected from three names of professors at the University of Kentucky,
Lexington, who are experienced in labor management matters.
   (B)   Each member after the first Board shall serve a one-year term.
   (C)   In the event that a mid-term vacancy shall occur during the term of
any appointed member, a successor shall be appointed by the Mayor from a panel
of three applicants furnished by the Labor Management Board and such selection
shall be subject to approval by the City Council to serve the unexpired portion
of said member’s term.
   (D)   All members of the Board shall serve without pay, with the exception
of the Chairperson who shall be entitled to a negotiated fee plus reasonable
travel-related expenses.
(Prior Code, § 32.92) (Ord. FY 91-92, #7, passed 11-6-1991)
§ 32.173 MEETINGS.
   (A)   The Board shall conduct proceedings according to the rules of the
American Arbitration Association. However, the Board may administer oaths.
There shall be no public transcript of the proceedings. All meetings shall be
open to the public unless adjournment to closed session is made in accordance
with the provisions of the Kentucky Open Meetings Act, being KRS 61.805 et seq.
   (B)   The Board shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote of
each member upon each question; or if absent or failing to vote indicating such
fact, and shall keep records of its examinations and other official actions,
all of which shall be public record unless disclosure is prohibited by law and
be immediately filed in the office of the City Clerk.
(Prior Code, § 32.93) (Ord. FY 91-92, #7, passed 11-6-1991)
§ 32.174 POWERS AND DUTIES; PROCEDURES.
   The Board shall have the exclusive authority to adjudicate employee
grievances as follows.
   (A)   In the event that any employee of the city believes that he or she has
a grievance against the city arising from the employment relationship, he or
she may file a written grievance with the City Clerk on forms provided setting
forth the alleged grievance. Such grievance must be filed within five days of
when the employee was advised that his or her department head had rejected the
grievance or taken the action which is the subject of the grievance. The
grieving employee must certify that he or she has raised the subject of the
grievance with each level of supervision and/or management within his or her
department, including the Mayor; provided, however, that upon the failure of
management to resolve the matter within three working days from the date of the
initial written notification by the employee of the grievance, the employee
shall be deemed to have fully satisfied this requirement. If the grievance
concerns a termination or suspension greater than five work days, the
requirement that the employee certify that he or she has raised the subject of
the grievance with each level of supervision or management is waived. Said
grieving employee may file the written grievance directly as provided herein.
In those cases, a hearing will be scheduled within seven days of the receipt of
the grievance as set forth in division (B) of this section.
   (B)   Upon receipt of the grievance, the City Clerk shall immediately
contact the Chairperson of the Board who shall call a meeting of the Board
within a period not to exceed seven days following the date of receipt of the
grievance. The City Clerk shall simultaneously transmit a copy of the grievance
to the Mayor and serve a copy upon the grieving employee by certified mail
(return receipt requested) to the last address the employee has furnished to
the city advising the employee of the hearing date.
   (C)   At the meeting of the Board during which the grievance is to be heard,
the employee shall present any and all evidence which he or she believes
substantiates the grievance. The Mayor or appropriate executive officer may
appear on behalf of the city to present evidence counter to the grievance.
Parties shall be limited to one hour each and may call persons to support the
grievance and/or present any documents which they believe support the
grievance. Neither the Kentucky Rules of Civil Procedure or the Kentucky Rules
of Evidence shall apply to the conduct of the hearing. Either party may be
represented by counsel.
   (D)   Within five days following the hearing, the Board shall announce its
finding of facts in writing surrounding the underlying grievance. In the event
the Board sustains the employee’s grievance, it shall direct the Mayor to take
specified remedial action immediately. The Mayor shall proceed to take the
specified corrective or remedial action immediately, which may include the
award of back pay. There shall be no other monetary damages allowable.
   (E)   The decision of the Board shall be the final procedure for the
grieving employee at the local level. Furthermore, any such grieving employee
shall be required to exhaust all administrative remedies set forth herein prior
to initiation of any litigation concerning the underlying grievance.
(Prior Code, § 32.94) (Ord. FY 91-92, #7, passed 11-6-1991)
§ 32.175 APPLICABILITY TO POLICE, FIRE DEPARTMENTS.
   While the procedure set forth in this subchapter relating to grievances
shall apply to the Police and Fire Departments, the procedure shall not apply
to members of either Department in the event that disciplinary action is
initiated by the Mayor, the department head, or other executive department
supervisory officers or employees. Rather, such procedure shall be governed by:
   (A)   KRS 95.450 for members of the Fire Department; and
   (2)   KRS 95.450 and 15.520 for members of the Police Department.
(Prior Code, § 32.95) (Ord. FY 91-92, #7, passed 11-6-1991)

CODE ENFORCEMENT BOARD
§ 32.205 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ABATEMENT COSTS. A city’s necessary and reasonable costs for and associated
with clearing, preventing unauthorized entry to, or demolishing all or a
portion of a structure or premises, or taking any other action with regard to a
structure or premises necessary to remedy a violation and to maintain and
preserve the public health, safety, and welfare in accordance with any city
ordinance.
   CODE ENFORCEMENT BOARD. An administrative body created and acting under the
authority of the Local Government Code Enforcement Board Act, KRS 65.8801 to
65.8839.
   CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER. A city police officer, safety officer, citation
officer, or other public law enforcement officer with the authority to issue a
citation.
   FINAL ORDER. Any order:
      (1)   Issued by the Code Enforcement Board following a hearing in
accordance with §
32.213(E);
      (2)   Created because a violator neither paid nor contested the citation
within seven days as provided in §
32.212(F); or
      (3)   Created because a violator failed to appear at a hearing the
violator requested to contest the citation as provided in §
32.213(C).
   IMMINENT DANGER. A condition which is likely to cause serious or life-
threatening injury or death at any time.
   ORDINANCE. An official action of the local government body, which is a
regulation of a general and permanent nature and enforceable as a local law and
shall include any provision of a code of ordinances adopted by the city
legislative body which embodies all or part of an ordinance.
   OWNER. A person, association, corporation, partnership, or other legal
entity having a legal or equitable title in real property.
   PREMISES. A lot, plot or parcel of land, including any structures upon it.
(Prior Code, § 32.110) (Ord. FY 17-18, #1, passed 8-15-2017)
§ 32.206 CREATION AND MEMBERSHIP.
   There is hereby created within the city pursuant to KRS 65.8801 to 65.8839,
a Code Enforcement Board which shall be composed of no fewer than seven
members, all of whom shall be residents of the city for a period of at least
one year prior to their appointment and shall reside there throughout the term
in office.
(Prior Code, § 32.111) (Ord. FY 17-18, #1, passed 8-15-2017)
§ 32.207 ENFORCEMENT POWERS.
   (A)   The Code Enforcement Board shall have the power to issue remedial
orders and impose civil fines as a method of enforcing city ordinances when a
violation of the ordinance has been classified as a civil offense.
   (B)   The Code Enforcement Board shall not have the authority to enforce any
ordinance regulating conduct which would also, under any provision of the
Kentucky Revised Statutes, constitute a criminal offense or a moving motor
vehicle offense.
(Prior Code, § 32.112) (Ord. FY 17-18, #1, passed 8-15-2017)
§ 32.208 APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS; TERM OF OFFICE; REMOVAL FROM OFFICE; OATH;
COMPENSATION.
   (A)   Members of the Code Enforcement Board shall be appointed by the
executive authority of the city, subject to the approval of the legislative
body.
   (B)   The initial appointment to the Code Enforcement Board shall be as
follows:
      (1)   One-third of the membership or one-third of the membership and one
member of the Board shall be appointed for a term of one year;
      (2)   One-third of the membership or one-third of the membership and one
member of the Board shall be appointed for a term of two years; and
      (3)   One-third of the membership or one-third of the membership and one
member of the Board shall be appointed for a term of three years.
   (C)   All subsequent appointments shall be for a term of three years. A
member may be reappointed, subject to the approval of the legislative body.
   (D)   The executive authority may appoint, subject to the approval of the
legislative body, two alternate members to serve on the Code Enforcement Board
in the absence of regular members. Alternate members shall meet all of the
qualifications and shall be subject to all of the requirements that apply to
regular members of the Code Enforcement Board.
   (E)   Any vacancy on the Board shall be filled by the executive authority,
subject to approval of the legislative body, within 60 days of the vacancy. If
the vacancy is not filled within that time period, the remaining Code
Enforcement Board members shall fill the vacancy. A vacancy shall be filled for
the remainder of the unexpired term.
   (F)   A Board member may be removed from office by the executive authority
for misconduct, inefficiency, or willful neglect of duty. The executive
authority shall submit a written statement to the member and the legislative
body setting forth the reasons for removal. The member so removed shall have
the right of appeal to the Circuit Court.
   (G)   All members of the Code Enforcement Board shall, before entering upon
the duties of their office, take the oath of office prescribed by § 228 of the
Kentucky Constitution.
   (H)   No member of the Code Enforcement Board shall hold any elected or
nonelected office, paid or unpaid, or any position of employment with the city.
(Prior Code, § 32.113) (Ord. FY 17-18, #1, passed 8-15-2017)
§ 32.209 ORGANIZATION OF BOARD; MEETINGS; QUORUM.
   (A)   The Code Enforcement Board shall annually elect a Chair from among its
members. The Chair shall be the presiding officer and a full voting member of
the Board. In the absence of the Chair, the remaining members of the Board
shall select a member to preside in place of and exercise the powers of the
Chair.
   (B)   Regular meetings of the Code Enforcement Board shall be held on the
first Tuesday at 1:00 p.m. of every month. Meetings other than those regularly
scheduled shall be special meetings or emergency meetings held in accordance
with the requirements of the Kentucky Open Meetings Act, being KRS 61.805 et
seq.
   (C)   All meetings and hearings of the Code Enforcement Board shall be
public meetings held in accordance with the requirements of KRS 65.8815(5) and
the Kentucky Open Meetings Act.
   (D)   The presence of at least a majority of the Board’s entire membership
shall constitute a quorum. The affirmative vote of a majority of a quorum of
the Board shall be necessary for any official action to be taken.
   (E)   Minutes shall be kept for all proceedings of the Code Enforcement
Board and the vote of any member on any issue decided by the Board shall be
recorded in the minutes. Minutes shall be submitted to the City Council at the
Council meeting in the month following the Board meeting for approval by the
City Council.
(Prior Code, § 32.114) (Ord. FY 17-18, #1, passed 8-15-2017; Ord. FY 19-20, #3,
passed 8-20-2019)
§ 32.210 CONFLICT OF INTEREST.
   Any member of the Code Enforcement Board who has any direct or indirect
financial or personal interest in any matter to be decided shall disclose the
nature of the interest, shall disqualify himself or herself from voting on the
matter in which he or she has an interest, and shall not be counted for
purposes of establishing a quorum.
(Prior Code, § 32.115) (Ord. FY 17-18, #1, passed 8-15-2017)
§ 32.211 POWERS OF THE CODE ENFORCEMENT BOARD.
   The city’s Code Enforcement Board shall have the following powers and
duties:
   (A)   To adopt rules and regulations to govern its operations and the
conduct of its hearings consistent with this subchapter;
   (B)   To conduct hearings to determine if there has been a violation of an
ordinance over which it has jurisdiction;
   (C)   To subpoena alleged violators, witnesses and evidence to its hearings.
Subpoenas issued by the Code Enforcement Board may be served by any Code
Enforcement Officer;
   (D)   To take testimony under oath. The Chairperson shall have the authority
to administer oaths for the purpose of taking testimony;
   (E)   To make findings of fact and issue orders necessary to remedy any
violation of a city ordinance or code provision which the Board is authorized
to enforce; and
   (F)   To impose civil fines, as authorized, on any person found to have
violated an ordinance over which the Board has jurisdiction.
(Prior Code, § 32.116) (Ord. FY 17-18, #1, passed 8-15-2017)
§ 32.212 ENFORCEMENT PROCEEDINGS.
   The following requirements shall govern all enforcement proceedings before
the Code Enforcement Board.
   (A)   Enforcement proceedings shall only be initiated by the issuance of a
citation by a Code Enforcement Officer.
   (B)   Except when immediate action is necessary pursuant to §
32.220, if a Code Enforcement Officer believes, based on his or her personal
observation or investigation, that a person has violated a city ordinance, he
or she shall issue a notice of violation allowing the alleged violator a
specified period of time to remedy the violation without incurring a fine. If
the alleged violator fails or refuses to remedy the violation within the time
specified, the Code Enforcement Officer is authorized to issue a citation.
   (C)   The Code Enforcement Officer shall issue a citation by one of the
following methods:
      (1)   Personal service to the alleged violator;
      (2)   Leaving a copy of the citation with any person 18 years of age or
older who is on the premises, if the alleged violator is not on the premises at
the time the citation is issued;
      (3)   Mailing a copy of the citation by regular first-class mail to the
last known recorded mailing address of the alleged violator; or
      (4)   If, in the exercise of reasonable diligence, the issuance of a
citation using the methods set out in divisions (C)(1), (C)(2), or (C)(3) of
this section is not possible, then the citation is properly served by posting a
copy of the citation in a conspicuous place on the premises.
   (D)   The citation issued by the Code Enforcement Officer shall contain the
following information:
      (1)   The date and time of issuance;
      (2)   The name and address of the person to whom the citation is issued;
      (3)   The physical address of the premises where the violation occurred;
      (4)   The date and time the offense was committed;
      (5)   The facts constituting the offense;
      (6)   The section of the code or the number of the ordinance violated;
      (7)   The name of the Code Enforcement Officer;
      (8)   The civil fine that may be imposed for the violation, including, if
applicable:
         (a)   The civil fine that will be imposed if the person does not
contest the citation; and
         (b)   The maximum civil fine that may be imposed if the person elects
to contest the citation.
      (9)   The procedure for the person to follow in order to pay the civil
fine or to contest the citation; and
      (10)   A statement that if the person fails to pay the civil fine set
forth in the citation or contest the citation within the time allowed: the
person shall be deemed to have waived the right to a hearing before the Code
Enforcement Board to contest the citation; the determination that the violation
was committed shall be final; the citation as issued shall be deemed a final
order determining that the violation was committed and imposing the civil fine
as set forth in the citation; and the person shall be deemed to have waived the
right to appeal the final order to District Court.
   (E)   After issuing a citation to an alleged violator, the Code Enforcement
Officer shall notify the Code Enforcement Board by delivering the citation to
all Board members.
   (F)   (1)   The person to whom the citation is issued shall respond to the
citation within seven days of the date of issuance by either paying the civil
fine or requesting, in writing, a hearing to contest the citation. If the
person fails to respond to the citation within seven days, the person shall be
deemed to have waived the right to a hearing and the determination that a
violation was committed shall be considered final. In this event, the citation
as issued shall be deemed a final order determining that the violation was
committed and imposing the civil fine as set forth in the citation, and the
person shall be deemed to have waived the right to appeal the final order to
District Court.
      (2)   Notice of a final order shall be provided to the cited violator by
regular first-class mail; certified mail, return receipt requested; personal
delivery; or by leaving the notice at the person’s usual place of residence
with any individual residing therein who is 18 years of age or older and who is
informed of the contents of the notice.
(Prior Code, § 32.117) (Ord. FY 17-18, #1, passed 8-15-2017)
§ 32.213 HEARING; NOTICE AND FINAL ORDER.
   (A)   When a hearing has been requested, the Code Enforcement Board or its
administrative staff shall schedule a hearing.
   (B)   Not less than seven days before the date of the hearing, the Code
Enforcement Board shall notify the requester of the date, time, and place of
the hearing. The notice may be given by regular first-class mail; certified
mail, return receipt requested; personal delivery; or by leaving the notice at
the person’s usual place of residence with any individual residing therein who
is 18 years of age or older and who is informed of the contents of the notice.
   (C)   (1)   Any person requesting a hearing who fails to appear at the time
and place set for the hearing shall be deemed to have waived the right to a
hearing to contest the citation, and the determination that a violation was
committed shall be final. In this event, the citation as issued shall be deemed
a final order determining the violation was committed and imposing the civil
fine set forth in the citation, and the alleged violator shall be deemed to
have waived the right to appeal the final order to District Court.
      (2)   Notice of a final order shall be provided to the cited violator by
regular first-class mail; certified mail, return receipt requested; personal
delivery; or by leaving the notice at the person’s usual place of residence
with any individual residing therein who is 18 years of age or older and who is
informed of the contents of the notice.
   (D)   All testimony at the hearing shall be taken under oath and recorded.
Testimony shall be taken from the Code Enforcement Officer, the alleged
violator, and any witnesses to the violation offered by the Code Enforcement
Officer or alleged violator. Formal rules of evidence shall not apply, but
fundamental due process shall be observed and shall govern the proceedings.
   (E)   The Code Enforcement Board shall, based on the evidence, determine
whether a violation was committed. If it is determined that no violation was
committed, an order dismissing the citation shall be entered. If it is
determined that a violation was committed, an order may be issued upholding the
citation. The Board may impose a fine up to the maximum authorized by
ordinance, or require the offender to remedy a continuing violation to avoid a
fine, or both.
   (F)   (1)   Every final order following a hearing shall be reduced to
writing, which shall include the findings and conclusions reached and the date
the order was issued. A copy shall be furnished to the person named in the
citation.
      (2)   If the person named in the citation is not present when the final
order is issued, the order shall be delivered to the person by regular first-
class mail; certified mail, return receipt requested; personal delivery; or by
leaving the notice at the person’s usual place of residence with any individual
residing therein who is 18 years of age or older and who is informed of the
contents of the notice.
(Prior Code, § 32.118) (Ord. FY 17-18, #1, passed 8-15-2017)
§ 32.214 PRESENTATION OF CASES.
   Each case before the Code Enforcement Board shall be presented by an
attorney selected by the city, a Code Enforcement Officer for the city, or by a
member of the city’s administrative staff. The City Attorney may either be
counsel to the Code Enforcement Board or may present cases before the Code
Enforcement Board, but shall in no case serve in both capacities.
(Prior Code, § 32.119) (Ord. FY 17-18, #1, passed 8-15-2017)
§ 32.215 APPEALS; FINAL JUDGMENT.
   (A)   An appeal from a final order of a Code Enforcement Board following a
hearing conducted pursuant to §
32.213(E) may be made to the Bell County District Court within 30 days of the
date the order is issued. The appeal shall be initiated by the filing of a
complaint and a copy of the final order in the same manner as any civil action
under the Kentucky Rules of Civil Procedure.
   (B)   If no appeal from a final order of the Code Enforcement Board is filed
within the time period set in division (A) of this section, the Code
Enforcement Board’s order shall be deemed final for all purposes.
(Prior Code, § 32.120) (Ord. FY 17-18, #1, passed 8-15-2017)

§ 32.217 LIEN; FINES, CHARGES AND FEES.
   (A)   The city shall possess a lien on property owned by the person found by
a nonappealable final order as defined by §
32.205, or by a final judgment of the court, to have committed a violation of a
city ordinance. The lien shall be for all civil fines assessed for the
violation and for all charges and fees incurred by the city in connection with
the enforcement of the ordinance, including abatement costs. An affidavit of
the Code Enforcement Officer shall constitute prima facie evidence of the
amount of the lien and regularity of the proceedings pursuant to KRS 65.8801 to
65.8839.
   (B)   The lien shall be recorded in the office of the County Clerk. The lien
shall be notice to all persons from the time of its recording and shall bear
interest until paid. The lien shall continue for ten years following the date
of the nonappealable final order or final court judgment.
   (C)   Subject to §
32.219, the lien shall take precedence over all other liens, except state,
county, school board, and city taxes, and may be enforced by judicial
proceedings, including a foreclosure action.
   (D)   In addition to the remedy prescribed in division (A) of this section,
the person found to have committed the violation shall be personally
responsible for the amount of all civil fines assessed for the violation and
for all charges, fees, and abatement costs incurred by the city in connection
with the enforcement of the ordinance. The city may bring a civil action
against the person and shall have the same remedies as provided for the
recovery of a debt.
(Prior Code, § 32.122) (Ord. FY 17-18, #1, passed 8-15-2017)
§ 32.218 LIENHOLDER NOTIFICATION SYSTEM.
   The city shall obtain and maintain priority over previously filed liens, as
provided in §
32.217, in accordance with the following provisions.
   (A)   Individuals and entities, including, but not limited to, lienholders,
may register with the city to receive electronic notification of final orders
entered pursuant to this subchapter.
   (B)   In order to receive the notification, the registrant shall submit the
following information to the City Clerk or code enforcement staff:
      (1)   Name;
      (2)   Mailing address;
      (3)   Phone number; and
      (4)   Electronic mailing address.
   (C)   A registrant may use the electronic form provided on the city web site
to submit the information required by division (B) of this section. It shall be
the responsibility of the registrant to maintain and update the required
contact information with the city. The city shall inform a registrant of any
evidence received that the electronic mailing address is invalid or not
functional so that the registrant may provide an updated electronic mailing
address.
   (D)   Once per month/once per week/once every two weeks/and the like, the
city shall send electronic mail notification of all final orders entered
pursuant to this subchapter since the last date of notification to each party
registered pursuant to this section. The notification shall provide an
electronic link to the city code enforcement database located on the city web
site. The database shall include the following information regarding each final
order:
      (1)   The name of the person charged with a violation;
      (2)   The physical address of the premises where the violation occurred;
      (3)   The last known mailing address for the owner of the premises where
the violation occurred; if, in the exercise of reasonable diligence, it is
ascertainable;
      (4)   A copy of the full citation;
      (5)   A copy of the full final order; and
      (6)   The status of the final order regarding its ability to be appealed
pursuant to this subchapter.
   (E)   If an appeal is filed on a final order pursuant to this subchapter,
the city shall send electronic mail notification to all registrants.
   (F)   The city shall update its code enforcement database to reflect the
issued final order, and shall post the notification required by division (D) of
this section containing an updated link to the code enforcement database on the
city web site.
   (G)   The city shall maintain the records created under this section for ten
years following their issuance.
(Prior Code, § 32.123) (Ord. FY 17-18, #1, passed 8-15-2017)
§ 32.219 LIENS.
   (A)   A lienholder of record who has registered pursuant to §
32.218(B) may, within 45 days from the date of issuance of notification under §
32.218(D):
      (1)   Correct the violation, if it has not already been abated; or
      (2)   Pay all civil fines assessed for the violation, and all charges and
fees incurred by the city in connection with enforcement of the ordinance,
including abatement costs.
   (B)   Nothing in this section shall prohibit the city from taking immediate
action if necessary under §
32.220.
   (C)   The lien provided by §
32.217 shall not take precedence over previously recorded liens if:
      (1)   The city failed to comply with the requirements of §
32.218 for notification of the final order; or
      (2)   A prior lienholder complied with division (A) of this section.
   (D)   A lien that does not take precedence over previously recorded liens
under division (C) of this section shall, if the final order remains partially
unsatisfied, continue to take precedence over all other subsequent liens except
liens for state, county, school board and city taxes.
   (E)   The city may record a lien before the 45-day period established in
division (A) of this section expires. If the lien is fully satisfied prior to
the expiration of the 45-day period, the city shall release the lien in the
County Clerk’s office where the lien is recorded within 15 days of
satisfaction.
   (F)   Failure of the city to comply with §
32.218 or this section, or failure of a lien to take precedence over previously
filed liens as provided in division (C) of this section, shall not limit or
restrict any other remedies the city has against the property of the violator.
(Prior Code, § 32.124) (Ord. FY 17-18, #1, passed 8-15-2017)
§ 32.220 IMMEDIATE ACTION.
   Nothing in this subchapter shall prohibit the city from taking immediate
action to remedy a violation of its ordinances when there is reason to believe
that the violation presents a serious threat to the public health, safety, and
welfare, or if in the absence of immediate action, the effects of the violation
will be irreparable or irreversible.
(Prior Code, § 32.125) (Ord. FY 17-18, #1, passed 8-15-2017)

shall be a maximum of four full-time civilian dispatchers within the Police
Department and part-time dispatchers as needed, as reflected on Page III-5 of
the Personnel Policy.

   The maximum number of firefighters in the city shall not exceed a Fire Chief
and 25 firefighters.
(Prior Code, § 33.10) (Ord. FY 87-88, #10, passed 11-2-1987; Ord. FY 88-89,
#23, passed 5-16-1989; Ord. FY 13-14, #6, passed 10-15-2013)
§ 33.16 COMPENSATION.
   The rate of pay for members of the volunteer Fire Department shall be $5 for
responding to each fire, and $5 for each hour or part of an hour spent working
at each fire.
(Prior Code, § 33.11) (Ord. FY 87-88, #8, passed 9-1-1987)
§ 33.17 STAFFING LEVELS.
   (A)   Whenever Fire Department personnel are needed to transport a patient
beyond the city limits, the Fire Chief or other appropriate supervising officer
shall immediately call the number of personnel deemed necessary by the officer
in charge of off duty EMT certified firefighters into work to replace the
personnel handling the ambulance run, until they return. This procedure shall
be followed for each ambulance run made to properly ensure that the Fire
Department is properly and adequately staffed at all times to provide service
to the citizens of the city.
   (B)   In the event of a non-emergency ambulance call, Fire Department
personnel called to transport the patient shall not leave the station until the
replacement firefighters have arrived and reported for duty. In the event of an
emergency ambulance call, the ambulance crew may proceed to take the call prior
to the arrival of the replacement firefighters.
   (C)   A sign-in sheet for each pay period will be provided on the ambulance
service checkoff clipboard, and each replacement firefighter called into duty
as provided herein shall be required to sign in and out in his or her own
handwriting and to put the date the overtime was worked.
   (D)   Any firefighter summoned to replace ambulance personnel as provided in
this section shall report for duty as soon as possible after being called, and
shall be in full uniform.
   (E)   A list of firefighters to be called to work this extra duty shall be
rotated in order to fairly apportion the work to be performed.
(Prior Code, § 33.12) (Ord. FY 94-95, #23, passed 3-7-1995)
§ 33.18 EMT CERTIFICATION.
   (A)   All firefighters who are currently employed in the city’s Fire
Department and are certified as emergency medical technicians (EMT) must
maintain said certification for the duration of their employment as a member of
the city’s Fire Department. Firefighters licensed as paramedics must maintain
the paramedic license for the duration of their employment. Failure to maintain
EMT certification or paramedic license shall result in termination of
employment.
   (B)   No application for employment with the city’s Fire Department shall be
taken without the applicant having first presented a valid EMT certification or
a paramedic license.
   (C)   All firefighters who are currently employed with the city’s Fire
Department who are not certified as an EMT shall not receive any promotion
until such time as they receive said certification. Said promotions shall not
be retroactive but shall begin accrual from date of receipt of EMT
certification.
(Prior Code, § 33.13) (Ord. FY 05-06, #4, passed 9-6-2005; Ord. FY 13-14, #6,
passed 10-15-2013)
RESIDENCY REQUIREMENTS
§ 33.30 RESIDENCY REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   All police officers hereinafter employed by the city’s Police
Department shall reside within a 30-mile radius of the city. Newly hired police
officers shall be granted a six-month grace period to relocate within a 30-mile
radius of the city.
   (B)   All firefighters, fire captains, and fire lieutenants shall reside
within a 40-mile radius of the city. Newly hired employees shall be granted a
six month grace period to relocate within a 40-mile radius of the city.
(Prior Code, § 33.15) (Ord. FY 96-97, #8, passed 11-5-1996; Ord. FY 13-14, #6,
