CHAPTER 34: CITY FINANCE
Section
   
34.01   Budget preparation
   
34.02   Fiscal policies
   
34.03   Procurement procedures for city purchases
   
34.04   Annual audit of city funds
§ 34.01 BUDGET PREPARATION.
   The following standards shall apply to the form and detail in which the
annual budget proposal of the city is to be prepared.
   (A)   Purpose. The annual budget proposal shall detail the raising of
revenue from all sources, including grants and transfers, and the spending of
money for specified programs, functions, activities, or objectives of the city,
including all principal and interest due on debt, for the budget year. The
total of anticipated revenues shall equal or exceed the total of proposed
expenditures.
   (B)   Form. The form of the annual budget proposal shall be consistent in
form, to the extent practical, with the accounting system of the city.
   (C)   Contents. The annual budget proposal shall provide a complete program
and financial plan for all funds for the budget year. It shall contain:
      (1)   A budget message, as specified in KRS 91A.030(7); and
      (2)   A budget summary, as specified in division (D) of this section,
supported by:
         (a)   An estimate of fund balance carry-forward, as specified in
division (E) of this section;
         (b)   An estimate of all anticipated revenues of the city compared to
previous years, as specified in division (F) of this section;
         (c)   Proposed expenditures compared to previous years, as specified
in division (G) of this section; and
         (d)   An estimate of anticipated transfers, as specified in division
(H) of this section.
   (D)   Budget summary. At the head of the annual budget proposal there shall
appear a summary of the budget, which need not be itemized further than by
principal sources of anticipated revenue, and proposed expenditures by program,
function, activity, or objectives of the city, in such a manner as to present a
simple and clear summary of the detailed estimates of the budget components.
   (E)   Fund balance carry-forward. Each fund balance available for
appropriation shall be limited to the amount by which assets are estimated to
exceed liabilities at the beginning of the budget year.
   (F)   Anticipated revenues; comparison with other years. In parallel columns
opposite the several items of anticipated revenue there shall be placed:
      (1)   The amount of each such item actually received during the next
preceding fiscal year;
      (2)   The total of the amount of each item actually received to the time
of preparation of the annual budget proposal, plus anticipated receipts for the
remainder of the current fiscal year estimated as accurately as possible; and
      (3)   The amount of each item anticipated to be received during the
budget year, estimated as accurately as possible.
   (G)   Proposed expenditures; comparison with other years. In parallel
columns, opposite the several items of proposed expenditures, there shall be
placed:
      (1)   The amount of each such item actually expended during the next
preceding fiscal year;
      (2)   The total of the amount actually expended to the time of
preparation of the annual budget proposal plus the expenditures for the
remainder for the current fiscal year estimated as accurately as possible; and
      (3)   The amount of each item to be appropriated for the budget year.
   (H)   Anticipated transfer from other funds. Any anticipated excess
revenues, if legally available for general purposes and to the extent such
excess is to be used to support other funds, shall be stated as a transfer item
in the annual budget proposal.
   (I)   Effective date. This section shall become effective and shall apply
for fiscal year 1985-86, and all years thereafter, but shall specifically not
apply to fiscal year 1984-85.
(Prior Code, § 34.01) (Minute book LL, page 95, passed 5-7-1985)
Cross-reference:
   Chief financial officer see §
30.26
§ 34.02 FISCAL POLICIES.
   (A)   A new set of procedures shall be adopted pertaining to procurement of
goods and services by sealed bid, negotiated process, and small purchase. Small
purchases are items that cost less than $7,500 in aggregate according to KRS
45A.385. These new procedures will apply to all departments and will ensure the
maximum return for city tax dollars expended.
   (B)   All city expenses will be approved by the Mayor as provided for in KRS
91A.060. The small purchase procedures will ensure the integrity of this
process. Also, this process will provide the following advantages and savings
to the city:
      (1)   Save tremendously on copying costs;
      (2)   Save on clerical staff time;
      (3)   Provide additional time at Council meetings for the City Council to
devote to more important matters; and
      (4)   Permit the city to be current with all vendors. It should be noted
that all city expenses, with or without this process, are open to public
scrutiny and that every Council member would be welcomed to review the monthly
bills (invoices) of the city.
   (C)   Two or three days shall be designated per month for expenses to be
paid (check preparation and signing).
   (D)   A monthly financial report shall be prepared and presented to the City
Council, rather than a quarterly report.
   (E)   Beginning with fiscal year 1990, the Mayor will provide a new and
somewhat modified form for the annual budget ordinance and detailed operating
budget.
   (F)   The city’s privilege license ordinance shall be revised and updated.
The current ordinance is outdated and is not comprehensive.
   (G)   An inventory system for equipment, tools, vehicles, office furniture,
and the like shall be established.
   (H)   The City Council shall consider the possibilities of establishing a
long-range capital improvements program/budget for the replacement of equipment
in the various departments.
   (I)   The elected officials of the city should investigate all possible ways
to enhance revenues and provide a maximum level of service for each dollar
expended. This may include, but not be limited to:
      (1)   Revising all revenue generating ordinances;
      (2)   Establishing a cash management and investment plan to earn the
maximum interest on idle funds; and
      (3)   Establishing a procurement procedure for professional services.
(Prior Code, § 34.02) (Ord. FY 88-89, #17, passed 4-18-1989)
§ 34.03 PROCUREMENT PROCEDURES FOR CITY PURCHASES.
   (A)   Policy statement. It is the intent of the city to provide the maximum
return from expenditures for commodities and services. The city will strive to
procure all goods and services by and through the competitive process.
   (B)   Responsibility.
      (1)   The Mayor is responsible for performance and administration of the
procurement function of the city.
      (2)   The Mayor hereby delegates to the City Clerk and to each department
head the authority to make small purchases for their respective departments in
accordance with the procedures contained herein.
   (C)   Small purchase procedures.
      (1)   Small purchases are items that cost less than the amount stipulated
in KRS 45A.385.
      (2)   There shall be no requirement for bids to be obtained for purchases
amounting to less than $100. All such purchases will, however, require the
written approval of the appropriate department head.
      (3)   A department head with delegated authority shall obtain three price
quotes from vendors whenever practicable, and the one most advantageous to the
city or the department shall be selected. Where two or more local suppliers
offer the same product at substantially the same price, the person in charge of
procurement should purchase from each on a rotating basis.
      (4)   The department head shall prepare a “purchase order requisition” to
submit to the City Clerk’s office for issuance of a purchase order. The
purchase order requisition should be dated, numbered by department, and contain
the following information:
         (a)   Department making the request;
         (b)   A written description of the item or service to be purchased;
         (c)   The vendors contacted with price quote(s);
         (d)   Budget account to be charged;
         (e)   Signature of requesting department head; and
         (f)   Mayor’s approval, if required.
      (5)   Any small purchase exceeding $200 shall be approved by the Mayor
signing the purchase order requisition; provided, however, that if the purchase
amount exceeds $200 by 10% solely due to the addition of subsequent incidental
charges, the Mayor’s approval shall not be necessary.
      (6)   The department head shall maintain one copy of the purchase order
requisition and one copy of the purchase order.
      (7)   The City Clerk or designee shall issue a purchase order after
ascertaining the available budget amount. The City Clerk will maintain one copy
of the purchase order for the unpaid bills file and one photocopy thereof to be
filed numerically.
      (8)   Emergency small purchases shall require that a purchase order
requisition and purchase order with explanation attached be prepared within
three working days after the purchase. Also, acceptable purchases of this
nature could be for:
         (a)   Establishing evidence and/or maintaining the scene of a crime,
fire, and the like; and
         (b)   Situations where there is only one vendor who can supply the
essential goods or service.
      (9)   Selection of maintenance service on vehicles and equipment must be
both practical and advantageous to the city. Quality work and turn around time
at a reasonable price should be the standard to achieve. However, in reality,
down time and quality work are very important. With these points in mind the
department head should choose a vendor that is most practical and advantageous
to the city.
      (10)   It is understood that this procurement ordinance is to benefit the
city in both price and down time of equipment. The small purchases procedure is
for the convenience of the department head and not to be misused through split
invoicing. Repeated history of billing more than one invoice for essentially
the same job shall be subject to reprimand.
   (D)   Sealed bidding procedures.
      (1)   The department, official or person requiring a contract or purchase
from city funds not covered by small purchase procedures shall submit to the
Mayor a written request containing specifications, quantities, and delivery
desired.
      (2)   The Mayor shall examine the request and approve or reject it based
on the needs of the city and whether such items are provided for in the budget.
If the request is approved, the Mayor shall inform the City Council when
competitive sealed bidding will commence.
      (3)   The City Clerk shall place an appropriate advertisement in the
newspaper and shall open all bids publicly at the time and place stated in the
advertisement.
      (4)   The City Clerk shall submit all responsive bids to the Mayor, who
shall open the bids in the presence of the City Council and shall select the
lowest or the lowest evaluated bid by a qualified bidder, subject to approval
by the City Council, prior to awarding a contract. The City Clerk shall notify
all bidders of the award.
      (5)   The Mayor shall sign a contract with and issue a purchase order to
the bidder receiving the award.
   (E)   Negotiated procedures.
      (1)   Negotiated procedures may be used instead of sealed bids when the
amount exceeds the amount stipulated in KRS 45A.385 for small purchase
procedures and when the Mayor makes a written determination that:
         (a)   An emergency exists which will result in danger to health,
safety, or property;
         (b)   All bids received exceed the amount budgeted, if three or more
bids were received; or
         (c)   The item or project will not be funded with federal funds.
      (2)   One copy of the determination shall be submitted to the City Clerk
and another copy placed in the file.
      (3)   When the prerequisites set out in divisions (E)(1)(a), (E)(1)(b),
or (E)(1)(c) of this section have been met for the use of the negotiated
process, the Mayor or his or her designee shall proceed to negotiate with one
or more suppliers in order to obtain the most advantageous terms.
      (4)   The best negotiated proposal shall be submitted to the Mayor for
approval. The Mayor shall inform the City Council prior to awarding a contract.
The Clerk shall notify the person awarded the contract.
      (5)   The City Clerk shall prepare a record of all negotiated contracts,
showing the items and quantities acquired, name of suppliers, cost, and date of
each contract.
   (F)   Procurement of professional services. The procurement of professional
services shall be by the request for proposals (RFP) method, as more
particularly described in KRS 45A.370, which is incorporated herein by
reference and made a part hereof.
   (G)   Applicability.
      (1)   These procurement policies shall not apply to any federally funded
project. Federal funds shall be considered as those coming from such agencies
as:
         (a)   Appalachian Regional Commission – ARC;
         (b)   Farmers Home Administration – FmHA;
         (c)   Community Development Block Grant – CDBG;
         (d)   Economic Development Administration – EDA; and
         (e0   Environmental Protection Agency – EPA
      (2)   These procurement policies shall apply to all departments, except
as prohibited in division (F) of this section.
(Prior Code, § 34.03) (Ord. FY 88-89, #6, passed 11-27-1989; Ord. FY 90-91, #8,
passed 10-2-1990)
§ 34.04 ANNUAL AUDIT OF CITY FUNDS.
   (A)   Each city shall, after the close of each fiscal year, cause each fund
of the city to be audited by the Auditor of Public Accounts or a certified
public accountant. The audit shall be completed by February 1 immediately
following the fiscal year being audited. The city shall forward an electronic
copy of the audit report to the Department for Local Government for information
purposes by no later than March 1 immediately following the fiscal year being
audited.
   (B)   If a city is required by another provision of law to audit its funds
more frequently or more stringently than is required by this section, the city
shall also comply with the provisions of that law.
   (C)   The Department for Local Government shall, upon request, make
available electronic copies of the audit reports and financial statements
received by it under division (A) of this section to the Legislative Research
Commission to be used for the purposes of KRS 6.955 to 6.975 or to the Auditor
of Public Accounts.
   (D)   Each city required by this section to conduct an annual or biennial
audit shall enter into a written contract with the selected auditor. The
contract shall set forth all terms and conditions of the agreement which shall
include, but not be limited to, requirements that:
      (1)   The auditor be employed to examine the basic financial statements,
which shall include the government-wide and fund financial statements;
      (2)   The auditor shall include in the annual or biennial city audit
report an examination of local government economic assistance funds granted to
the city under KRS 42.450 to 42.495. The auditor shall include a certification
with the annual or biennial audit report that the funds were expended for the
purpose intended;
      (3)   All audit information be prepared in accordance with generally
accepted governmental auditing standards which include tests of the accounting
records and auditing procedures considered necessary in the circumstances.
Where the audit is to cover the use of state or federal funds, appropriate
state or federal guidelines shall be utilized;
      (4)   The auditor shall prepare a typewritten or printed report
embodying:
         (a)   The basic financial statements and accompanying supplemental and
required supplemental information;
         (b)   The auditor’s opinion on the basic financial statements or
reasons why an opinion cannot be expressed; and
         (c)   Findings required to be reported as a result of the audit.
      (5)   The completed audit and all accompanying documentation shall be
presented to the city legislative body at a regular or special meeting; and
      (6)   Any contract with a certified public accountant for an audit shall
require the accountant to forward a copy of the audit report and management
letters to the Auditor of Public Accounts upon request of the city or the
Auditor of Public Accounts, and the Auditor of Public Accounts shall have the
right to review the certified public accountant’s work papers upon request.
   (E)   A copy of an audit report which meets the requirements of this section
shall be considered satisfactory and final in meeting any official request to a
city for financial data, except for statutory or judicial requirements, or
requirements of the Legislative Research Commission necessary to carry out the
purposes of KRS 6.955 to 6.975.
   (F)   Each city shall, within 30 days after the presentation of an audit to
the city legislative body, publish an advertisement in accordance with KRS
Chapter 424 containing:
      (1)   The auditor’s opinion letter;
      (2)   The “Budgetary Comparison Schedules-Major Funds”, which shall
include the General Fund and all major funds;
      (3)   A statement that a copy of the complete audit report, including
financial statements and supplemental information, is on file at City Hall and
is available for public inspection during normal business hours;
      (4)   A statement that any citizen may obtain from City Hall a copy of
the complete audit report, including financial statements and supplemental
information, for his or her personal use;
      (5)   A statement which notifies citizens requesting a personal copy of
the city audit report that they will be charged for duplication costs at a rate
that shall not exceed $0.25 per page; and
      (6)   A statement that copies of the financial statement prepared in
accordance with KRS 424.220, when a financial statement is required by KRS
424.220, are available to the public at no cost at the business address of the
officer responsible for preparation of the statement.
   (G)   Any resident of the city or owner of real property within the city may
bring an action in the circuit court to enforce the provisions of this section.
Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be fined not less
than $50 nor more than $500. In addition, any officer who fails to comply with
any of the provisions of this section shall, for each failure, be subject to a
forfeiture of not less than $50 nor more than $500, in the discretion of the
court, which may be recovered only once in a civil action brought by any
resident of the city or owner of real property within the city. The costs of
all proceedings, including a reasonable fee for the attorney of the resident or
property owner bringing the action, shall be assessed against the unsuccessful
party.
   (H)   In the event of extenuating circumstances that prevent a city from
completing and submitting a required audit or financial statement in compliance
with the applicable deadlines in division (A) of this section, the city may
submit a written request for an extension of time to the Department for Local
Government on a form prescribed by the Department for Local Government. The
Department for Local Government shall approve the request if it is submitted on
or before the applicable deadline and, in the judgment of the Department for
Local Government, the request is warranted by extenuating circumstances beyond
the control of the city. Extensions granted under this division (H) shall not
exceed nine months from the original due date of the audit or financial
statement. If the Department for Local Government approves an extension for a
city and the city fails to complete and submit the required audit or financial
statement in compliance with that extended deadline, then the provisions of
division (I) of this section shall apply.
   (I)   If a city fails to complete an audit or financial statement and submit
it to the Department for Local Government as required in division (A) and (H)
of this section, the Department for Local Government shall notify the Finance
and Administration Cabinet that the city has failed to comply with the audit
requirements of this section, and that any funds in the possession of any
agency, entity, or branch of state government shall be withheld from the city
until further notice. The Department for Local Government shall immediately
notify the Finance and Administration Cabinet when the city complies with the
requirements of divisions (A) and (H) of this section for all prior fiscal
years it has failed to comply with the audit requirements of this section, and
the Finance and Administration Cabinet shall direct the reinstatement of
payments to the city, including any funds that were withheld due to the
noncompliance.
   (J)   Within a reasonable time after the completion of a special audit or
examination conducted pursuant to KRS 43.050, the Auditor shall bill the city
for the actual expense of the audit or examination conducted. The actual
expense shall include the hours of work performed on the audit or examination
as well as reasonable associated costs, including but not limited to travel
costs. The bill submitted to the city shall include a statement of the hourly
rate, total hours, and total costs for the entire audit or examination.
(KRS 91A.040) (Prior Code, § 34.04)
Statutory reference:
   Department for local government to provide assistance, see KRS 91A.050

CHAPTER 36: PASSAGE OF ORDINANCES
Section
   
36.01   Quorum of Council
   
36.02   One subject; title
   
36.03   Introduction; enacting clause
   
36.04   Form of amendment
   
36.05   Reading requirement; exception for emergency
   
36.06   Adoption of standard codes by reference
   
36.07   Official city records

§ 36.01 QUORUM OF COUNCIL.
   Unless otherwise provided by statute, a majority of the Council shall
constitute a quorum and a vote of a majority of a quorum shall be sufficient to
take action.
(KRS 83A.060(6)) (Prior Code, § 36.01)
§ 36.02 ONE SUBJECT; TITLE.
   Each ordinance shall embrace but one subject and shall have a title which
shall clearly state the subject.
(KRS 83A.060(1)) (Prior Code, § 36.02)
§ 36.03 INTRODUCTION; ENACTING CLAUSE.
   Each ordinance shall be introduced in writing and shall have an enacting
clause styled “Be it ordained by the City of Middlesboro”.
(KRS 83A.060(2)) (Prior Code, § 36.03)
§ 36.04 FORM OF AMENDMENT.
   No ordinance shall be amended by reference to its title only, and ordinances
to amend shall set out in full the amended ordinance or section indicating any
text being added by a single solid line drawn underneath it. Text that is
intended to be removed shall be marked at the beginning with an opening bracket
and at the end with a closing bracket. The text between the brackets shall be
stricken through with a single solid line.
(KRS 83A.060(3)) (Prior Code, § 36.04)
§ 36.05 READING REQUIREMENT; EXCEPTION FOR EMERGENCY.
   (A)   Except as provided in division (B) of this section, no ordinance shall
be enacted until it has been read on two separate days. The reading of an
ordinance may be satisfied by stating the title and reading a summary rather
than the full text.
   (B)   In an emergency, upon the affirmative vote of two-thirds of the
membership, the Council may suspend the requirements of second reading and
publication for an ordinance by naming and describing the emergency in the
ordinance. Publication requirements of §
36.09 shall be complied with within ten days of the enactment of the emergency
ordinance.
(KRS 83A.060(4), (7)) (Prior Code, § 36.05)
§ 36.06 ADOPTION OF STANDARD CODES BY REFERENCE.
   The Council may adopt the provisions of any local, statewide, or nationally
recognized standard code and codifications of entire bodies of local
legislation by an ordinance which identifies the subject matter by title,
source, and date and incorporates the adopted provisions by reference without
setting them out in full, provided a copy accompanies the adopting ordinance
and is made a part of the permanent records of the city.
(KRS 83A.060(5)) (Prior Code, § 36.06)
§ 36.07 OFFICIAL CITY RECORDS.
   (A)   Every action of the Council shall be made a part of the permanent
records of the city and on passage of an ordinance, the vote of each member of
the Council shall be entered on the official record of the meeting.
   (B)   The Council shall provide by ordinance for the maintenance and
safekeeping of the permanent records of the city. The person assigned this
responsibility and the presiding officer shall sign the official record of each
meeting.
(KRS 83A.060(8)) (Prior Code, § 36.07)
§ 36.08 INDEXING AND MAINTENANCE REQUIREMENTS.
   All ordinances adopted in the city shall, at the end of each month, be
indexed and maintained in the following manner.
   (A)   The city budget, appropriations of money, and tax levies shall be
maintained and indexed so that each fiscal year is kept separate from other
years.
   (B)   All other city ordinances shall be kept in the minute book or an
ordinance book in the order adopted and indexed in a composite index or
maintained in a code of ordinances.
(KRS 83A.060(8)) (Prior Code, § 36.08)
§ 36.09 PUBLICATION REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   No ordinance shall be enforceable until published pursuant to KRS
Chapter 424.
   (B)   The publication requirements for ordinances, including all bond and
zoning ordinances, may be satisfied by publication in full or in summary as
designated by Council.
   (C)   The requirements for summary publication may be satisfied by
publication of the title, a brief narrative setting forth the main points of
the ordinance in a way reasonably calculated to inform the public in a clear
and understandable manner of the meaning of the ordinance, and the full text of
each section that imposes fines, penalties, forfeitures, taxes, or fees,
prepared or certified by an attorney licensed to practice law in the
commonwealth and shall include the following:
      (1)   The title of the ordinance;
      (2)   A brief narrative setting forth main points of the ordinance in a
way reasonable calculated to inform the public in a clear and understandable
manner of the meaning of the ordinance; and
      (3)   The full text of each section that imposes taxes or fees.
   (D)   Ordinances that include descriptions of real property may include a
sketch, drawing, or map, including common landmarks, such as streets or roads
in lieu of metes and bounds descriptions.
(KRS 83A.060(9)) (Prior Code, § 36.09)
§ 36.10 ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS FOR ADOPTION.
   The city may by ordinance specify additional requirements for adoption of
ordinances in greater detail than contained herein, but a city shall not lessen
or reduce the substantial requirements of this chapter or any other statute
relating to adoption of ordinances.
(KRS 83A.060(10)) (Prior Code, § 36.10)
§ 36.11 PERIODIC REVIEW REQUIRED.
   At least once every five years the city shall cause all ordinances in the
composite index or code of ordinances to be examined for consistency with state
law and with one another and to be revised to eliminate redundant, obsolete,
inconsistent, and invalid provisions.
(KRS 83A.060(11)) (Prior Code, § 36.11)
§ 36.12 MUNICIPAL ORDERS.
   (A)   Council may adopt municipal orders. Orders shall be in writing and may
be adopted only at an official meeting. Orders may be amended by a subsequent
municipal order or ordinance. All orders adopted shall be maintained in an
official order book.
   (B)   In lieu of an ordinance, a municipal order may be used for matters
relating to the internal operation and functions of the city and to appoint or
remove or approve appointment or removal of members of boards, commissions, and
other agencies over which the city has control.
(KRS 83A.060(12), (13)) (Prior Code, § 36.12)
§ 36.13 PROVED BY CLERK; RECEIVED IN EVIDENCE.
   All ordinances and orders of the city may be proved by the signature of the
City Clerk; and when the ordinances are placed in a printed composite index or
code of ordinances by authority of the city, the printed copy shall be received
in evidence by any state court without further proof of the ordinances.
(KRS 83A.060(14)) (Prior Code, § 36.13)
§ 36.14 LEGISLATIVE IMMUNITY.
   For anything said in debate, Council members shall be entitled to the same
immunities and protections allowed to members of the general assembly.
(KRS 83A.060(15)) (Prior Code, § 36.14)
Constitutional reference:
   Privileges of members of general assembly, see Ky. Const. § 43
Statutory reference:
   Privileges of members of general assembly, see KRS 6.050

§ 37.01 CONDUCT OF CITY BUSINESS WITH PERSONS DELINQUENT IN TAX PAYMENTS.
   The city shall not upon proper notice conduct or allow to be conducted city
business with any person, persons, or corporation deemed delinquent in any
taxes due and owing the city until such person, persons, or corporation shall
have paid such taxes to the City Clerk.
(Prior Code, § 37.01) (Minute book GG, page 4, passed 9-21-1982)
GRIEVANCE PROCEDURES RELATION TO
DISCRIMINATION BASED ON DISABILITY
§ 37.15 ADOPTION OF GRIEVANCE PROCEDURES; ADMINISTRATION; AMENDMENTS.
   (A)   The procedures set forth in this subchapter shall be the “grievance
procedures” for anyone who believes he or she has been discriminated against by
the city based on disability status with respect to federally funded programs.
   (B)   The administration of these procedures and related federal and state
regulations shall be the responsibility of a responsible employee (referred to
as program coordinator in the grievance procedure) and a coordinating committee
for persons with disabilities, all to be named by the executive authority, to
coordinate the implementation of the persons with disabilities discrimination
requirements.
   (C)   The grievance procedure is to be incorporated into the city personnel
manual as § 6.11, a copy of the grievance procedure is to be attached to each
application supplied to applicants for employment and a copy distributed to
each city department to be posted in a conspicuous place to ensure employee and
applicant awareness of the grievance procedure.
   (D)   These procedures may be amended by ordinance to comply with court
directives or additional federal and state regulations.
(Prior Code, § 37.10) (Ord. FY 84-85, #10, passed 12-18-1984)
§ 37.16 PROCEDURE FOR PROCESSING A COMPLAINT OR GRIEVANCE.
   (A)   Any person (employee or citizen who believes that he or she has been
subjected to discrimination as prohibited by the Federal Revenue Sharing
program regulations and § 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, being 29
U.S.C. § 794, may personally or by a representative, file a complaint with the
program coordinator of the city. A person who has not personally been subjected
to discrimination may also file a complaint.
   (B)   Any person (citizen, applicant, or employee) who believes he or she
has been adversely affected by an act or decision by the city and that such act
or decision was based on a disability shall have the right to process a
complaint or grievance in accordance with the following procedure.
      (1)   Step one. An aggrieved person must submit a written statement to
the program coordinator setting forth the nature of the discrimination alleged
and facts upon which the allegation is based.
      (2)   Step two. The program coordinator shall contact the complainant no
later than 15 days after receiving the written statement to establish an
informal meeting with the objective of resolving the matter informally.
However, in no case shall the informal meeting be conducted sooner than five
days nor more than 45 days after receiving the written statement. There shall
be prepared a written documentary of the discussions at the informal meeting,
which shall be preserved in the records of the city.
      (3)   Step three. Within 15 days of the informal meeting, if no decision
has been made by the program coordinator or the decision of the program
coordinator does not satisfy the complainant, he or she may request a hearing
with the disability coordinating committee by submitting a written request to
the program coordinator.
      (4)   Step four. In thus discussing the grievance, the complainant may
designate any person of his or her choice to appear with him or her and
participate in the discussion. The disability coordinating committee shall
require the program coordinator to participate in the discussion of the
grievance, when it is brought before the committee. The committee shall issue a
written decision on the matter within 15 days, and the decision shall be the
final procedure for the complainant at the local level. There shall be prepared
a written documentary of the discussion at the hearing, which shall be
preserved in the records of the city.
   (C)   All complaints received by the program coordinator and responses from
the program coordinator and the disability coordinating committee will be kept
by the city for a period of three years. These documents may be requested by
the office of revenue sharing should an investigation into alleged
discrimination on the basis of disability status be initiated.
(Prior Code, § 37.11) (Ord. FY 84-85, #10, passed 12-18-1984)
INTERLOCAL PROGRAM FOR SELF-INSURANCE
§ 37.30 ADOPTION BY CITY.
   (A)   The city hereby approves the joint and cooperative program for self-
insurance, insurance, and the investment of public funds among this city and
the other cities, urban-county governments, and public agencies within the
state which become signatories to the interlocal agreement, including the
financing of said program through the issuance of revenue bonds under the terms
and conditions of the interlocal agreement.
   (B)   The Mayor and the City Clerk are hereby authorized and directed to
execute, acknowledge, and deliver, on behalf of the city, the interlocal
agreement substantially in the form attached to Ord. FY 87-88, #5, passed 8-18-
1987.
   (C)   The city hereby approves and ratifies the articles of association and
by-laws of association, substantially in the form attached as Exhibit A to the
interlocal agreement.
   (D)   It is understood by the city that by executing the interlocal
agreement and thereby becoming a member of the association, the city shall
incur no liability for the payment of any funds and that it shall be necessary
for the city to take further action prior to becoming a “participating member”
in any of the self-insurance, insurance, or investment trusts which may be
created by the association.
(Prior Code, § 37.20) (Ord. FY 87-88, #5, passed 8-18-1987)
§ 37.31 APPROVAL OF STATE REQUIRED.
   The effectiveness of this subchapter is expressly conditioned upon the final
approval of the interlocal agreement by the Attorney General of the state as
required by KRS 65.260(2), and by any other officer or agency of the state as
may be required by KRS 65.300.
(Prior Code, § 37.21) (Ord. FY 87-88, #5, passed 8-18-1987)
CHAPTER 38: TAXATION
Section

§ 38.01 COUNTY ASSESSMENT ADOPTED.
   (A)   In accordance with the provisions of KRS 132.285, the city hereby
elects to use the annual county tax assessment for all property situated within
the city as the basis of ad valorem tax levies ordered or approved by the City
Council.
   (B)   In lieu of the statutory fee set out in KRS 132.285, the city, the
county property valuation administrator, and the commonwealth’s Revenue Cabinet
have mutually determined that the city may provide an in kind payment to the
county property valuation administrator for the use of the county assessments:
namely, the city shall assign the city tax assessor to work in conjunction with
and under the supervision of the county property valuation administrator for
the purpose of adopting and determining assessments of all property situated
within the city. However, the city tax assessor shall at all times remain an
employee of the city, ultimately responsible to the Mayor of the city, with
terms of employment governed by the Personnel Policy of the city. However, in
the event that the current city tax assessor is replaced during the time in
which the county tax assessments are utilized, the city shall thereafter pay to
the county property valuation administrator the fee for the assessments set out
in KRS 132.285 in lieu of the in kind payment.
(Prior Code, § 38.01) (Ord. FY 89-90, #14, passed 4-17-1990)
§ 38.02 AD VALOREM TAXES ON PROPERTY.
   (A)   On every $100 in value of all personal property subject to taxation by
the city for the fiscal year from January 1 to December 31, assessed for the
year by the county property valuation administrator for the city as of January
1, 2019, by the Kentucky Railroad Commission, by the State Board of Valuations,
and by any other assessing authorities, and by statutes of the state, there is
hereby levied and ordered an ad valorem tax at the rate as established by
ordinance on each $100 of assessed valuation for the following purposes:
      (1)   The fixed amount as established by ordinance on each $100 of
assessed valuation of personal property subject to tax for city purposes of
defraying the necessary expenses for general operation of the city government
and services in the city, including payment of salaries and all operating
expenses of the Police and Fire Departments, Clerk, Collector, Assessor, City
Attorney, Treasurer, Mayor, and Council members, and all other employees of the
city, and for supplies and equipment for all departments, traveling expenses,
and for all general operating expenses of every nature; and for the purposes of
paying all general expenses of maintenance and repair of all city property,
including street and rights-of-way, paying for all utility services used by the
city; and for the purposes of expansion of airport facilities, buying rights-
of-way, damages, court costs, and to purchase new pieces of equipment for use
in any of the various departments of the city such as Fire, Police, or Street
Departments, and for any and all general purposes for which such to levy may be
needed in the general operation of the city.
      (2)   The overall tax on personal property as fixed by ordinance is
distributed in its entirety to the General Fund.
   (B)   On every $100 in value of all real property subject to taxation by
said city of the fiscal year beginning July 1 and ending June 30 assessed for
the said year by the Bell County Property Valuation Administrator for the said
city as of January 1, 2019, by the Kentucky Railroad Commission, by the State
Board of Valuations, and by any other assessing authorities, and by the
statutes of Kentucky, there is hereby levied and ordered an ad valorem tax at
the rate of which shall be fixed by ordinance on each $100 of assessed
valuation for the following purposes and in the specified amounts as follows.
      (1)   The fixed amount as established by ordinance is hereby levied on
each $100 of assessed valuation of real property subject to tax for city
purposes of defraying the necessary expenses for general operation of the city
government and services in the city, including payment of salaries and all
operating expenses of the Police and Fire Departments, Clerk, Collector,
Assessor, City Attorney, Treasurer, Mayor, and Council members, and all other
employees of the City, and for supplies and equipment for all departments,
traveling expenses, and for all general purposes of paying all general expenses
of maintenance and repair of all city property, including streets and rights-
of-way, paying for all utility services used by the city; and for the purposes
of expansion of airport facilities, buying rights-of-way, damages, court costs,
and to purchase new pieces of equipment for use in any of the various
departments of the city, such as Fire, Police, or Street Department, and for
any and all general purposes for which such tax levy may be needed in the
general operation of the city.
      (2)   The overall tax on real property fixed as established by ordinance
shall be distributed in its entirety to the General Fund.
      (3)   There has also been imposed a bank franchise and local deposit tax
for year 2019 at a rate as fixed my ordinances shall be collected and paid into
the General Fund.
      (4)   A discount of 2% will be allowed if the total bill is paid through
the month of December.
      (5)   A penalty of 10% and interest of 1% per month shall be attached to
the collections of all taxes levied and not paid before February.
(Prior Code, § 38.02) (Ord. FY 90-91, #13, passed 11-14-1990; Ord. FY 18-19,
#2, passed 10-10-2018; Ord. FY 18-19, #3, passed 10-10-2018; Ord. 19-20, #4,
passed 8-27-2019; Ord. 19-20, #5, passed 8-27-2019)
Cross-reference:
   Policemen’s and Firemen’s Pension Fund, see §
32.040
   Moratorium on reassessment of property values in Historic Main Street
Middlesboro District, §
160.03
§ 38.03 AD VALOREM PROPERTY TAX ON SHARES OF BANK STOCK.
   There is a tax rate as established by ordinance on each $100 of fair cash
value of bank shares for each fiscal year for general purposes of the city.
(Prior Code, § 38.03) (Ord. FY 90-91, #13, passed 11-14-1990)
§ 38.04 DISCOUNTS AND PENALTIES ON AD VALOREM TAX BILLS.
   (A)   A discount of 2% will be allowed if the total bill is paid during the
month of December, or January 31; bills are net in the month of February.
   (B)   A penalty of 10% and interest of 1% per month shall be attached to the
collections on all taxes levied and not paid before March 1.
(Prior Code, § 38.04) (Ord. FY 90-91, #13, passed 11-14-1990)
§ 38.05 COLLECTION OF AD VALOREM TAXES.
   (A)   All taxes levied on personal property and ad valorem taxes, including
delinquent taxes, set forth in an ordinance setting tax rates by the City
Council, shall be billed and collected by the Bell County Clerk and Bell County
Sheriff as of tax year 2019.
   (B)   The Bell County Clerk and Bell County Sheriff shall be compensated for
said tax collections in accordance with terms set forth in an interlocal
agreement between the city and county.
(Prior Code, § 38.05) (Ord. FY 19-20, #2, passed 8-6-2019)
CHAPTER 39: PUBLIC RECORDS
Section
General

Procedures for Requesting Public Records
   
39.15   Initial request with immediate inspection
   
39.16   Referral to proper custodian
   
39.17   Public records not immediately available
   
39.18   Refusal of unreasonable requests
