§ 74.01 MOTORCYCLES; REGULATIONS FOR OPERATING AND RIDING ON.
   (A)   A person shall not operate a motorcycle:
      (1)   Except when that person is in possession of a valid motorcycle
operator’s license;
      (2)   Unless that person uses an approved eye-protective device, in the
manner prescribed by the Secretary of the Department of Transportation, at all
times the vehicle is in motion; and
      (3)   Unless the motorcycle is equipped with a rearview mirror.
   (B)   A person shall not operate or ride as a passenger on a motorcycle:
      (1)   Except on a seat permanently attached to that vehicle and
specifically designed to carry the operator or passenger in a safe manner; and
      (2)   Except when using a footrest permanently attached to that vehicle
and specifically designed to carry that person in a safe manner.
   (C)   The following persons shall be required to wear protective headgear,
in the manner prescribed by the Secretary of the Transportation Cabinet, at all
times the motorcycles they are riding are in motion on a public highway:
      (1)   A person under the age of 21 year who is operating a motorcycle or
who is a passenger on a motorcycle or in a sidecar attachment;
      (2)   A person who possesses a motorcycle instruction permit and who is
operating a motorcycle; and
      (3)   A person who has held a valid motorcycle operator’s license, or
combination motor vehicle-motorcycle operator’s license, for less than one year
and who is operating a motorcycle.
   (D)   A motorcycle operator authorized to drive a motorcycle on an
instruction permit shall not be authorized to carry passengers.
   (E)   The Secretary of Transportation Cabinet shall by regulation fix
minimum standards for approved protective headgear and for approved eye-
protective devices, and prescribe the manner in which they shall be used. The
Secretary shall maintain and cause to be published a list of approved
protective headgear and of approved eye-protective devices. The Secretary may
prescribe by regulation minimum standards for other protective devices and
require the use of those devices.
   (F)   For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
      MOPED. Either a motorized bicycle whose frame design may include one or
more horizontal crossbars supporting a fuel tank so long as it also has pedals,
or a motorized bicycle with a step through type frame which may or may not have
pedals rated no more than two brake horsepower, a cylinder capacity not
exceeding 50 cubic centimeters, an automatic transmission not requiring
clutching or shifting by the operator after the drive system is engaged, and
capable of a maximum speed of not more than 30 mph.
      MOTORCYCLE. Any motor-driven vehicle having a seat or saddle for the use
of the operator and designed to travel on not more than three wheels in contact
with the ground, but excluding tractors and vehicles on which the operator and
passengers ride in an enclosed cab, and excluding a moped as defined in this
division (F).
(KRS 189.285) (Prior Code, § 74.01) Penalty, see §
70.99(D)
§ 74.02 BICYCLE SAFETY REGULATIONS AND STANDARDS.
   The Department of Transportation shall promulgate administrative regulations
pursuant to KRS Chapter 13A to set forth standards for bicycle equipment and
the safe operation of a bicycle. Bicycle riders and bicycles which comply with
the regulations promulgated under this section are exempt from municipal and
other local government regulations concerning safety equipment but not method
of operation. In promulgating the administrative regulations the Department of
Transportation shall permit use of lightweight modern technological substitutes
for lights, reflectors, and bells. The purpose of this section is to encourage
bicycling and bicycle touring in this state by enabling bicycle riders to make
use of modern technology to make their presence known to other users of the
road. The Department of Transportation may consult with organizations of
bicycle riders to aid it in the search for bicycle safety equipment and rules
convenient for long distance bicycle riders.
(KRS 189.287) (Prior Code, § 74.02) Penalty, see §
70.99(T)
§ 74.03 SCHOOL OR CHURCH BUS SIGNALING DEVICE; USE; STOPPING REGULATED.
   No school or church bus shall be licensed or operated for the transportation
of school children unless it is equipped with bus alternating flashing signal
lamps and a stop arm folding sign. The bus body shall be equipped with a system
of four red signal lamps, two on the front and two on the rear of the bus, and
four amber signal lamps. Each amber signal lamp shall be located near each red
signal lamp, at the same level, but closer to the vertical centerline of the
bus. The bus body shall be equipped with a stop arm folding sign on the
driver’s side with letters at least six inches in height displaying the word
“stop” on both sides. Prior to stopping the school bus for the purpose of
receiving or discharging school children, the driver shall activate the amber
flashing signal lamps. Once the bus comes to a complete stop, the driver shall
extend the stop arm and activate the red flashing signal lights prior to
opening the door so it shall be plainly visible to traffic approaching from
both directions that the bus is in the process of receiving or discharging
passengers. No driver shall stop a school or church bus for receiving or
discharging passengers in a no passing zone which does not afford reasonable
visibility to approaching motor vehicles from both directions unless a “School
Bus Stop Ahead” sign has been installed a reasonable distance before that spot
in the roadway. No driver shall stop a school or church bus for the purpose of
receiving passengers from or discharging passengers to the opposite side of the
road on a highway of four or more lanes; provided that this provision does not
prohibit the discharging of passengers at a marked pedestrian crossing.
(KRS 189.375) (Prior Code, § 74.03) Penalty, see §
70.99(V)
§ 74.04 VEHICLES USED FOR TRANSPORTING CHILDREN TO STOP AT RAILROAD CROSSINGS.
   Operators of all buses and motor vehicles used for transporting children
shall stop their vehicles before crossing any railroad when tracks are at the
same level of the roadway. The stop shall be made not less than 15 feet nor
more than 50 feet from the nearest track over which the highway crosses, except
where the crossing is protected by gates or a flagman employed by the railroad.
After making the stop, the operator shall open the service door and carefully
look in each direction and listen for approaching trains or other on-track
equipment before proceeding. If visibility is impaired at the required distance
for stopping under this section, the operator may allow the vehicle to slowly
roll forward for the purpose of gaining the visibility necessary to safely
cross the railroad tracks.
(KRS 189.550) (Prior Code, § 74.04) Penalty, see §
70.99(W)
§ 74.05 SLOW-MOVING VEHICLES.
   (A)   Except as provided in division (D) of this section, all slow-moving
vehicles sold, leased, or rented in, or for use within, the commonwealth shall
have affixed to them as standard equipment a slow-moving vehicle emblem.
   (B)   Except as provided in division (D) of this section, the slow-moving
vehicle emblem shall be displayed as herein provided on all slow-moving
vehicles operated day or night upon the public roads within the commonwealth.
   (C)   The slow-moving vehicle emblem shall be mounted as near the center of
the rear of the slow-moving vehicle as is practicable, and the lower edge of
the emblem shall be mounted at least three feet or more above the road surface,
and shall be maintained in a clean reflective condition.
   (D)   As an alternative to the slow-moving vehicle emblem, one-inch-wide
white or silver reflective tape may be used on motorless slow-moving vehicles
as follows:
      (a)   The rear of the vehicle shall be covered with a minimum of 100
square inches of the reflective tape;
      (b)   The reflective tape on the rear of the vehicle shall, at a minimum,
outline the entire rear of the vehicle;
      (c)   Each side of the vehicle shall be covered with a minimum of 36
square inches of reflective tape; and
      (d)   The highest point of the left front of the vehicle shall be covered
with a minimum of 24 square inches of reflective tape.
(KRS 189.820) (Prior Code, § 74.05) Penalty, see §
70.99(X)
§ 74.06 USE OF SLOW-MOVING VEHICLE EMBLEM.
   (A)   The slow-moving vehicle emblem shall be restricted to the uses
specified herein and the use on any other type of vehicle or on other objects
is prohibited.
   (B)   The slow-moving vehicle emblem shall not be required on trailers or
other drawn vehicles which do not obstruct the slow-moving vehicle emblem
required on the towing vehicle.
   (C)   Highway construction or maintenance vehicles and public utility
vehicles shall not require the slow-moving vehicle emblems when being guarded
by flagmen or flares.
   (D)   The use of the slow-moving vehicle emblems or alternate reflective
tape, as required under §
74.05, shall be in addition to any other reflective or lighting devices
required by law.
   (E)   The slow-moving vehicle emblem shall not be used on a bicycle.
(KRS 189.830) (Prior Code, § 74.06) Penalty, see §
70.99(X)
§ 74.07 OFF-ROAD VEHICLES.
   (A)   For the purpose of this section, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
      OFF-ROAD VEHICLE. A motor vehicle capable of cross-county travel, without
the benefit of a road or trail. It does not include a farm vehicle, a vehicle
used for military or law enforcement purposes, a vehicle used in construction,
mining, or other industrial-related purposes, aircraft, or any other vehicle
registered under state law.
   (B)   No person shall operate an off-road vehicle on any private or public
property without the consent of the landowner, tenant, or governmental agency
responsible for the property.
(KRS 189.860) (Prior Code, § 74.07) Penalty, see §
70.99(Y)
§ 74.08 DEFINITIONS PERTAINING TO EMERGENCY VEHICLES.
   For purposes of §§
74.01 through
74.12 the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings
ascribed to them respectively.
   (A)   As used in §§
74.09 through
74.12, EMERGENCY VEHICLE means any vehicle used for emergency purposes by a
fire department; any vehicle used for emergency purposes by the state police, a
public police department, corrections cabinet vehicles, or sheriff’s office;
any vehicle used for emergency purposes by a rescue squad; any publicly owned
vehicle used for emergency purposes by an emergency management agency;
ambulances; any vehicle commandeered by a police officer; or any motor vehicle
used by a paid or volunteer fireman or paid or volunteer ambulance personnel
while responding to an emergency or to a location where an emergency vehicle is
on emergency call.
   (B)   As used in §§
74.09 through
74.12, PUBLIC SAFETY VEHICLE means public utility repair vehicles; wreckers;
state, county, or municipal service vehicles and equipment; highway equipment
which performs work that requires stopping and standing or moving at slow
speeds within the traveled portions of highways; and vehicles which are
escorting wide-load or slow-moving trailers or trucks.
(KRS 189.910) (Prior Code, § 74.08)
§ 74.09 FLASHING LIGHTS.
   (A)   All Fire Department, rescue squad, or publicly-owned emergency
management agency emergency vehicles and all ambulances shall be equipped with
one or more flashing, rotating, or oscillating red lights, visible under normal
atmospheric conditions from a distance of 500 feet to the front of the vehicle,
and a siren, whistle, or bell, capable of emitting a sound audible under normal
conditions from a distance of not less than 500 feet. This equipment shall be
in addition to any other equipment required by the motor vehicle laws.
   (B)   All state, county, or municipal police vehicles and all sheriff’s
vehicles used as emergency vehicles shall be equipped with one or more
flashing, rotating, or oscillating blue lights, visible under normal
atmospheric conditions from a distance of 500 feet to the front of the vehicle,
and a siren, whistle, or bell, capable of emitting a sound audible under normal
conditions from a distance of not less than 500 feet. This equipment shall be
in addition to any other equipment required by the motor vehicle laws.
   (C)   All public safety vehicles shall be equipped with one or more
flashing, rotating, or oscillating yellow lights, visible under normal
atmospheric conditions from a distance of 500 feet to the front of the vehicle.
Yellow flashing, rotating, or oscillating lights may also be used by vehicles
operated by mail carriers while on duty, funeral escort vehicles, and church
buses.
   (D)   Red flashing lights may be used by school buses.
   (E)   No emergency vehicle, public safety vehicle, or any other vehicle
covered by §§
74.09 through
74.12 shall use any light of any other color than those specified by §§
74.09 through
74.12. Sirens, whistles, and bells may not be used by vehicles other than those
specified by §§
74.09 through
74.12, except that any vehicle may be equipped with a theft alarm signal device
which is so arranged that it cannot be used by the driver as an ordinary
warning signal.
   (F)   Vehicles used as command posts at incidents may be equipped with and
use when on scene, a green rotating, oscillating, or flashing light. This light
shall be in addition to the lights and sirens required in this section.
   (G)   A personal vehicle used by a paid or volunteer firefighter, ambulance
personnel, or emergency services director who is responding to an emergency
shall display the lights required in division (A) of this section.
(KRS 189.920) (Prior Code, § 74.09) Penalty, see §
70.99(Z)
§ 74.10 RIGHT-OF-WAY OF EMERGENCY VEHICLES; BLOCKING OR FOLLOWING; DRIVING OVER
UNPROTECTED FIRE HOSE.
   (A)   Upon the approach of an emergency vehicle equipped with, and
operating, one or more flashing, rotating, or oscillating red or blue lights,
visible under normal conditions from a distance of 500 feet to the front of the
vehicle; or the driver is given audible signal by siren, exhaust whistle, or
bell, the driver of every other vehicle shall yield the right-of-way,
immediately drive to a position parallel to, and as close as possible to, the
edge or curb of the highway clear of any intersection, and stop and remain in
that position until the emergency vehicle has passed, except when otherwise
directed by a police officer or firefighter.
   (B)   Upon the approach of any emergency vehicle, operated in conformity
with the provisions of division (A) of this section, the operator of every
vehicle shall immediately stop clear of any intersection and shall keep that
position until the emergency vehicle has passed, unless directed otherwise by a
police officer or firefighter.
   (C)   No operator of any vehicle, unless he or she is on official business,
shall follow any emergency vehicle being operated in conformity with the
provisions of division (A) of this section closer than 500 feet, nor shall he
or she drive into, or park the vehicle into, or park the vehicle within, the
block where the vehicle has stopped in answer to an emergency call or alarm
unless he or she is directed otherwise by a police officer or firefighter.
   (D)   No vehicle, train, or other equipment shall be driven over any
unprotected hose of a Fire Department when the hose is laid down on any street,
private driveway, or track for use at any fire or fire alarm unless the Fire
Department official in command consents that the hose be driven over.
(KRS 189.930)
   (E)   Upon approaching a stationary emergency or public safety vehicle, when
the emergency or public safety vehicle is giving a signal by displaying
alternately flashing yellow, red, red and white, red and blue or blue lights, a
person who drives an approaching vehicle shall, while proceeding with due
caution:
      (1)   Yield the-right-of way by moving to a lane not adjacent to that of
the authorized emergency vehicle if:
         (a)   The person is driving on a highway having at least four lanes
with not fewer than two lanes proceeding in the same direction as the
approaching vehicle; and
         (b)   If it is possible to make the lane change with due regard to
safety and traffic conditions; or
      (2)   Reduce the speed of the vehicle, maintaining a safe speed to road
conditions, if changing lanes would be impossible or unsafe.
   (F)   This section shall not operate to relieve the person who drives an
emergency vehicle from the duty to operate the vehicle with due regard for the
safety of all persons using the highways.
(KRS 189.930)
(Prior Code, § 74.10) Penalty, see §
70.99(J), (AA)
§ 74.11 EXEMPTIONS FROM TRAFFIC REGULATIONS.
   (A)   The speed limitations set forth in the Kentucky Revised Statutes do
not apply to emergency vehicles:
      (1)   When responding to emergency calls;
      (2)   To police vehicles when in pursuit of an actual or suspected
violator of the law; or
      (3)   To ambulances when transporting a patient to medical care
facilities; and
      (4)   The driver thereof is giving the warning required by divisions (E)
(1) and (E)(2) of this section. No portion of this division shall be construed
to relieve the driver of the duty to operate the vehicle with due regard for
the safety of all persons using the street or highway.
   (B)   The driver of an emergency vehicle, when responding to an emergency
call, or of a police vehicle in pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of
the law, or of an ambulance transporting a patient to a medical care facility
and giving the warning required by division (E) of this section, upon
approaching any red light or stop signal or any stop sign shall slow down as
necessary for safety to traffic, but may proceed past such red or stop light or
stop sign with due regard for the safety of persons using the street or
highway.
   (C)   The driver of an emergency vehicle, when responding to an emergency
call, or of a police vehicle in pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of
the law, or of an ambulance transporting a patient to a medical care facility
and giving warning required by division (E) of this section, may drive on the
left side of any highway or on the opposite direction of a one-way street
provided the normal lanes of traffic are blocked and he or she does so with due
regard for the safety of all persons using the street or highway.
   (D)   The driver of an emergency or public safety vehicle may stop or park
his or her vehicle upon any street or highway without regard to the provisions
of §§
71.010 and
71.014, provided that, during the time the vehicle is parked at the scene of an
emergency, that at least one warning light is in operation at all times.
   (E)   The driver of an emergency vehicle desiring the use of any option
granted by divisions (A) through (E) of this section shall give warning in the
following manner:
      (1)   By illuminating the vehicle’s warning lights continuously during
the period of the emergency; and
      (2)   By continuous sounding of the vehicle’s siren, bell, or exhaust
whistle; unless:
         (a)   The vehicle is an ambulance and the driver is of the opinion
that sounding of the siren, bell, or exhaust whistle would be detrimental to
the victim’s health; and
         (b)   In the event the driver of an ambulance elects not to use the
siren, bell, or exhaust whistle he or she shall not proceed past red lights or
drive in the opposite direction on a one-way street or in oncoming lanes of
traffic unless no other vehicles are within 500 feet of the front of the
ambulance. The driver shall not extinguish the warning lights during the period
of the emergency.
   (F)   No driver or operator of any emergency or public safety or other
vehicle shall use the warning lights or siren, bell, or exhaust whistle of his
or her vehicle for any purposes or under any circumstances other than those
permitted by §§
74.08 through
74.12.
   (G)   Sections 74.08 through 74.12 do not relieve the driver of any
emergency or public safety vehicle from the duty to drive with due regard for
the safety of all persons and property upon the highway.
(KRS 189.940) (Prior Code, § 74.11) Penalty, see §
70.99(BB), (CC)
§ 74.12 PROHIBITIONS; EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   No motor vehicle, except those designated under §§
74.08 through
74.12 as emergency vehicles, shall be equipped with, nor shall any person use
upon a vehicle, any siren, whistle, or bell. Any vehicle may be equipped with a
theft alarm signal device which shall be so arranged that it cannot be used as
an ordinary warning signal.
   (B)   No motor vehicle, except those designated under §§
74.08 through
74.12 as emergency vehicles, shall be equipped with, nor shall any person use
upon a vehicle any red or blue flashing, revolving, or oscillating light or
place a red light on the front thereof. This division (B) shall not apply to
the use of red flashing lights on school buses or to stop lights or turn
signals at the rear of any motor vehicle.
   (C)   No motor vehicle, except those designated under §§
74.08 through
74.12 as public safety vehicles, shall be equipped with, nor shall any person
use upon any vehicle any yellow flashing, revolving, or oscillating light. This
division (C) shall not apply to the use of yellow lights for turn signals; or
to emergency flasher lights for use when warning the operators of other
vehicles of the presence of vehicular traffic requiring the exercise of unusual
care in approaching, overtaking, or passing; or to vehicles operated by mail
carriers while on duty; funeral escort vehicles and church buses.
   (D)   Any person who is a regular or voluntary member of any Fire Department
furnishing fire protection for a political subdivision of the state or any
person who is a regular or voluntary member of a rescue squad may equip his or
her vehicle with red flashing, rotating, or oscillating lights and a siren,
bell, or exhaust whistle if he or she has first been given permission, in
writing, to do so by the Chief of the Fire Department or rescue squad. He or
she may use the lights and equipment only while proceeding to the scene of a
fire or other emergency or to a location where another emergency vehicle is on
emergency call in the performance of his or her official duties as a member of
a Fire Department or rescue squad.
   (E)   Any constable may, upon approval of the fiscal court in the county of
jurisdiction, equip vehicles used by said officer as emergency vehicles with
one or more flashing, rotating, or oscillating blue lights, visible under
normal atmospheric condition from a distance of 500 feet to the front of such
vehicle, and a siren, whistle, or bell, capable of emitting a sound audible
under normal conditions from a distance of not less than 500 feet. This
equipment shall be in addition to any other equipment required by the motor
vehicle laws. Any constable authorized by the fiscal court to utilize blue
lights and a siren pursuant to this section shall maintain at least the
insurance described by KRS 304.39 through 304.39-110.
   (F)   Any person who is a paid or voluntary member of any ambulance service
furnishing emergency medical services for a political subdivision of the state
may equip his or her vehicle with red flashing, rotating, or oscillating lights
and a siren, bell, or exhaust whistle if he or she has first been given
permission, in writing, to do so by the chief or director of the ambulance
service. He or she may use such lights and equipment only while proceeding to
the scene of an emergency, a medical facility, or to a location where another
emergency vehicle is on emergency call in the performance of his or her
official duties as a member of the ambulance service.
(KRS 189.950) (Prior Code, § 74.12) Penalty, see §
70.99(DD)
§ 74.13 TRAFFIC LAWS APPLICABLE TO PERSONS RIDING BICYCLES.
   Every person riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall be granted all the rights
and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle
by the laws of this state declaring rules of the road applicable to vehicles or
by this traffic code applicable to the driver of a vehicle, except as to those
provisions of laws and ordinances which by their nature can have no
application.
(Prior Code, § 74.13) Penalty, see §
70.99(J)
§ 74.14 OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES.
   Any person operating a bicycle shall obey the instructions of official
traffic-control signals, signs, and other control devices applicable to
vehicles, unless otherwise directed by a police officer.
(Prior Code, § 74.14) Penalty, see §
70.99(J)
§ 74.15 RIDING ON BICYCLES.
   A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride other than astride a permanent
and regular seat attached thereto. No bicycle shall be used to carry more
persons at one time than the number for which it is designed and equipped.
(Prior Code, § 74.15) Penalty, see §
70.99(J)
§ 74.16 RIDING ON ROADWAYS AND BICYCLE PATHS.
   (A)   Every person operating a bicycle upon a roadway shall ride as near to
the right-hand side of the roadway as practicable, exercising due care when
passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction.
   (B)   Persons riding or pushing bicycles upon a roadway shall not ride or
push two abreast in any business district or more than two abreast in any other
district.
(Prior Code, § 74.16) Penalty, see §
70.99(J)
§ 74.17 SPEED OF BICYCLE.
   No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater than is reasonable and
prudent under the conditions then existing.
(Prior Code, § 74.17) Penalty, see §
70.99(J)
§ 74.18 EMERGING FROM ALLEY OR DRIVEWAY.
   The operator of a bicycle emerging from an alley, driveway, or building,
shall, upon approaching a sidewalk or the sidewalk area extending across any
alleyway, yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians approaching on the sidewalk
or sidewalk area, and upon entering the roadway shall yield the right-of-way to
all vehicles approaching on the roadway.
(Prior Code, § 74.18) Penalty, see §
70.99(J)
§ 74.19 CARRYING ARTICLES ON BICYCLE.
   No person operating a bicycle shall carry any package, bundle, or article
which prevents the rider from keeping at least one hand on the handlebars.
(Prior Code, § 74.19) Penalty, see §
70.99(J)
§ 74.20 CLINGING TO VEHICLES.
   No person riding upon any bicycle shall attach the same or himself or
herself to any vehicle upon a roadway.
(Prior Code, § 74.20) Penalty, see §
70.99(J)
§ 74.21 PARKING OF BICYCLES.
   No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than upon the roadway
against the curb or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle or
against a building or at the curb, in such manner as to afford the least
obstruction to pedestrian traffic.
(Prior Code, § 74.21) Penalty, see §
70.99(J)
§ 74.22 RIDING ON SIDEWALKS.
   No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk.
(Prior Code, § 74.22) Penalty, see §
70.99(J)
§ 74.23 LAMPS AND OTHER EQUIPMENT ON BICYCLES.
   (A)   Every bicycle when in use at nighttime shall be equipped with a lamp
on the front which shall emit a white light visible from a distance of at least
500 feet to the front and with a red reflector on the rear of a type which
shall be visible from all distances from 50 to 300 feet to the rear when
directly in front of lawful upper beams of headlamps on a motor vehicle. A lamp
emitting a red light visible from 500 feet to the rear may be used in addition
to the red reflector.
   (B)   No person shall operate a bicycle unless it is equipped with a bell or
other device capable of giving a signal audible for a distance of at least 100
feet, except that a bicycle shall not be equipped with nor shall any persons
use upon a bicycle any siren or whistle.
   (C)   Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will enable the
operator to make the braked wheel skid on dry, level, clean pavement.
(Prior Code, § 74.23) Penalty, see §
70.99(J)
§ 74.24 PERSONS PROPELLING PUSH CARTS OR RIDING ANIMALS.
   Every person propelling any push cart or riding an animal upon a roadway,
and every person driving any animal-drawn vehicle, and any person riding a
bicycle, shall be subject to the provisions of this traffic code applicable to
the driver of any vehicle, except those provisions of this traffic code which
by their very nature can have no application.
(Prior Code, § 74.24)
§ 74.25 USE OF COASTERS, ROLLER SKATES, AND SIMILAR DEVICES RESTRICTED.
   No person upon roller skates, or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy
vehicle, or similar device, shall go upon any roadway except while crossing a
street at a crosswalk and when so crossing such person shall be granted all of
the rights and be subject to all of the duties applicable to pedestrians.
(Prior Code, § 74.25) Penalty, see §
70.99(J)
§ 74.26 TRUCKS HAULING STOCK TO DISPLAY OWNER’S NAME.
   The owners of all trucks used for the purpose of hauling livestock shall
have the names of the owners of the trucks painted on both sides and on the
rear, in letters not less than five inches high.
(Prior Code, § 74.26) Penalty, see §
70.99(EE)
§ 74.27 SCHOOL BUS OPERATION; EQUIPMENT.
   (A)   No school bus shall be licensed or operated for the transportation of
school children unless it has a folding sign on the driver’s side thereof, with
letters at least six inches in height and displaying the word “Stop” on both
sides.
   (B)   Upon stopping the school bus, the driver shall open out the sign so
that it will be plainly visible to traffic approaching from both directions.
   (C)   No driver shall stop a school bus for loading or unloading purposes in
a no passing area, such as a hill or curve, which does not afford reasonable
visibility to approaching motor vehicles from both directions.
(Prior Code, § 74.27) Penalty, see §
70.99(J)
§ 74.28 MOTOR VEHICLE LICENSE FEES AND TAXES.
   (A)   Automobiles, pickup trucks, or similar vehicles.
      (1)   For each automobile, pickup truck, or other similar-sized vehicle
owned or operated by persons, firms, or corporations residing in the city,
there is imposed a license fee per year of $10.
      (2)   All persons, individuals, corporations, or companies residing
outside of the city limits, and owning or operating or causing to be operated,
an automobile, pickup truck, or other similar-sized vehicle, upon and over the
streets thereof in connection with a business conducted, or regular occupation
followed within the city limits, or as a means of conveyance to and from a
position, job, or labor from which remuneration is received from that business
or occupation, shall pay a license tax per year of $10.
   (B)   Motorcycles; motor bikes.
      (1)   For each motorcycle, motor bike, or any other motor-driven vehicle,
containing two or three wheels, owned or operated by persons, firms, or
corporations residing in the city, there is imposed a license fee per year of
$5.
      (2)   All persons, individuals, corporations, or companies residing
outside of the city limits, and owning or operating or causing to be operated a
motorcycle, motor bike, or any other motor-driven vehicle, containing two or
three wheels, upon and over the streets thereof in connection with a business
conducted, or regular occupation followed within the city limits, or as a means
of conveyance to and from a position, job, or labor from which remuneration is
received from that business or occupation, shall pay license tax per year of
$5.
   (C)   Dual-wheeled vehicles.
      (1)   For each dual-wheeled vehicle owned or operated by persons, firms,
or corporations residing in the city, there is imposed a license fee per year
of $25.
      (2)   All persons, individuals, corporations, or companies residing
outside of the city limits, and owning or operating a dual-wheeled vehicle upon
and over the streets thereof in connection with a business conducted, or
regular occupation followed within the city limits, or as a means of conveyance
to and from a position, job, or labor from which remuneration is received from
that business or occupation, shall pay license tax per year of $25.
   (D)   Tandem axle and tractor trailer trucks.
      (1)   For each tandem axle and tractor trailer truck owned or operated by
persons, firms, or corporations residing in the city, there is imposed a
license fee per year of $50.
      (2)   All persons, individuals, corporations, or companies residing
outside of the city limits, and owning or operating a tandem axle and tractor
trailer truck upon and over the streets thereof in connection with a business
conducted, or regular occupation followed within the city limits, or as a means
of conveyance to and from a position, job, or labor from which remuneration is
received from such business or occupation, shall pay license tax per year of
$50.
   (E)   Penalty. Any person who fails to purchase such a license by midnight
of April l of each year, shall be penalized $25. This offense shall be excused
if the $25 penalty is deposited with the City Clerk within 48 hours of issuance
of a notice of violation. If the notice is rendered on a weekend or holiday, an
additional 24 hours will be allowed. Failure to deposit the $25 shall result in
issuance of a court citation or warrant for arrest.
(Prior Code, § 74.28) (Minute book DD, page 480, passed 7-15-1980; Minute book
DD, page 615, passed 12-2-1980; Minute book FF, page 290, passed 9-7-1982)

METHOD OF PARKING
§ 75.01 STANDING OR PARKING CLOSE TO CURB.
   No person shall stand or park a vehicle in a roadway other than parallel
with the edge of the roadway headed in the direction of lawful traffic movement
and with the right-hand wheels of the vehicle within 12 inches of the curb or
edge of the roadway, except as otherwise provided in this chapter for angle
parking on one-way streets.
(Prior Code, § 75.01)
§ 75.02 SIGNS OR MARKINGS INDICATING ANGLE PARKING.
   (A)   The Chief of Police shall determine upon what streets angle parking
shall be permitted and shall mark or sign such streets, but such angle parking
shall not be indicated upon any federal aid or state highway within this city
unless the State Highway Commission has determined that the roadway is of
sufficient width to permit angle parking without interfering with the free
movement of traffic.
   (B)   Angle parking shall not be indicated or permitted at any place where
passing traffic would thereby be caused or required to drive upon the left side
of the street.
(Prior Code, § 75.02)
§ 75.03 OBEDIENCE TO ANGLE PARKING SIGNS OR MARKINGS.
   Upon those streets which have been signed or marked by the Chief of Police
for angle parking, no person shall park or stand a vehicle other than at the
angle to the curb or edge of the roadway indicated by the signs or markings.
(Prior Code, § 75.03)
§ 75.04 LIGHTS ON PARKED VEHICLES.
   (A)   Whenever a vehicle is lawfully parked at nighttime upon any street
within a business or residence district no lights need be displayed upon the
parked vehicle.
   (B)   Any lighted headlamps upon a parked vehicle shall be depressed or
dimmed.
(Prior Code, § 75.04)
§ 75.05 DOUBLE PARKING.
   No person shall at any time double park any vehicle on any street of the
city for any purpose.
(Prior Code, § 75.05) Penalty, see §
75.99
§ 75.06 DIAGONAL PARKING.
   Motor vehicle parking on Lothbury Avenue between 18th and 19th Streets shall
be in a fashion parallel to the curb, and diagonal parking of motor vehicles
upon the avenue between those streets shall cease immediately.
(Prior Code, § 75.06) (Minute book FF, page 104, passed 2-16-1982)
STOPPING, STANDING, OR PARKING PROHIBITED
§ 75.20 STOPPING, STANDING, OR PARKING PROHIBITED IN CERTAIN PLACES.
   (A)   No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle except when necessary
to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a
police officer or traffic-control device, in the following places:
      (1)   In front of a public or private driveway;
      (2)   Within ten feet of a fire hydrant;
      (3)   On a sidewalk;
      (4)   Within an intersection;
      (5)   On a crosswalk;
      (6)   Within 20 feet of a crosswalk or intersection;
      (7)   Within 30 feet upon the approach to any flashing beacon, stop sign,
or traffic-control signal located at the side of the roadway;
      (8)   In any parkway in any street, or in any parkway dividing two
streets;
      (9)   Within 20 feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station and on
the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire state within 75 feet of
the entrance (when a sign is properly posted);
      (10)   Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when
such stopping, standing, or parking would obstruct traffic;
      (11)   On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge
or curb of a street;
      (12)   Upon any bridge or other elevated structure;
      (13)   In any underpass; and
      (14)   At any place where official signs or markings prohibits stopping,
standing, and parking.
   (B)   No person shall move a vehicle not owned by such person into any
prohibited area or away from a curb such distance as is lawful.
(Prior Code, § 75.10) Penalty, see §
75.99
§ 75.21 PARKING NOT TO OBSTRUCT TRAFFIC.
   No person shall park any vehicle upon a street, other than an alley, in such
a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of
the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic.
(Prior Code, § 75.11)
§ 75.22 PARKING IN ALLEYS.
   No vehicle or motor vehicle shall be parked in any alley so as to obstruct
the flow of traffic, except a reasonable time will be allowed for loading or
unloading, where same is necessary, on the alleys parallel to Cumberland Avenue
between 18th Street and 22nd Street.
(Prior Code, § 75.12)
§ 75.23 TWENTY-FOUR HOUR PARKING.
   No person shall park a vehicle on any street for a period longer than 24
hours.
(Prior Code, § 75.13)
§ 75.24 PARKING FOR CERTAIN PURPOSES PROHIBITED.
   No person shall park a vehicle upon any roadway for the principal purpose
of:
   (A)   Displaying such vehicle for sale; and
   (B)   Washing, greasing, or repairing such vehicle except repairs
necessitated by an emergency.
(Prior Code, § 75.14)
§ 75.25 PARKING ADJACENT TO SCHOOLS.
   The Chief of Police is authorized to erect signs indicating no parking upon
that side of any street adjacent to any school property when such parking
would, in his or her opinion, interfere with traffic or create a hazardous
situation.
(Prior Code, § 75.15)
§ 75.26 PARKING PROHIBITED AT ALL TIMES AT DESIGNATED PLACES.
   No person shall park a vehicle at any time upon any of the following places
or streets where the curb is painted yellow or other signs have been erected by
the Chief of Police designating no parking:
   (A)   Twentieth Street from Chester Street to Exeter Street;
   (B)   Edgewood Road from 20th Street to Rochester Avenue, except during
burial services at the Episcopal Church;
   (C)   The center of Cumberland Avenue;
   (D)   The south side of Lothbury Avenue from 20th Street east to Canal;
   (E)   Within 20 feet of the 20th Street bridge, or the bridge located on
Cumberland Avenue between 22nd and 23rd streets;
   (F)   Cumberland Avenue between 26th and 27th streets, on both sides of the
street;
   (G)   On either side of Arthur Heights; and
   (H)   Cumberland Avenue (KY 74) from Wilson Road to Petersborough Avenue
(30th Street).
(Prior Code, § 75.16) (Minute book U, page 9, passed 2-7-1967; Minute book HH,
page 38, passed 6-7-1983; Ord. 94-95, #30, passed 6-20-1995)
§ 75.27 PARKING TIME LIMITED IN CERTAIN DESIGNATED PLACES.
   (A)   When signs are erected, including signs on parking meters, giving
notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle for a longer period of time than
is designated on the signs at such places except Sundays and public holidays,
upon any of the streets where such signs have been erected as follows. No
vehicle shall be allowed to stand or park on Cumberland Avenue between 22nd
Street and 19th Street, and on 19th Street between Cumberland Avenue and
Lothbury Avenue, between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m.
   (B)   There shall be established and fixed certain zones and signs to be
erected as no parking/tow-away zones (at owner’s expense) on the following
street: Petersborough Avenue (30th Street) between Cumberland Avenue north to
YMCA parking lot between hours of 8:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m.
      (1)   Generally. A citation shall be issued hereunder with respect to
each separate offense.
      (2)   Penalty. Any person who violates this no parking regulation by
parking on said street between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m., the owner
of the vehicle as determined by the license of the vehicle shall be immediately
served with a citation to be issued and served by the City Police Department to
appear and answer said citation in the County District Court where he or she
shall be subject to a minimum penalty or fine of $25 and court costs.
      (3)   Special permit. The Chief of Police of the City Police Department
or his or her designated representative may authorize a special permit to allow
parking as an exception to divisions (B)(1) and (B)(2) of this section, either
by phone or in person. An applicant for a special permit must state the
requested date, time, and occurrence. A special permit may not be granted
unless the applicant guarantees that the special permit will be met and
maintained.
(Prior Code, § 75.17) (Ord. FY 88-89, #8, passed 10-18-1988)
§ 75.28 CHIEF OF POLICE TO DETERMINE CERTAIN PARKING REGULATIONS.
   The Chief of Police is authorized to erect signs or place signs on parking
meters indicating no stopping, parking, or time limit parking upon any street
in the city or upon one side of the street as indicated by such signs where he
or she determines particular hazards exist or where unusual delay in traffic
exists.
(Prior Code, § 75.18)
§ 75.29 NO PARKING; STREET CLEANING.
   To facilitate street cleaning, it shall be illegal for any parked on the
following avenues and streets at the following designated times and places:
   (A)   No motor vehicle of any kind or type shall be parked upon Cumberland
Avenue between 12th Street and 25th Street between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and
5:00 a.m.;
   (B)   No motor vehicle of any kind or type shall be parked upon 19th Street
or Main Street between Reams Lumber Company and Chester Avenue between the
hours of 4:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m.;
   (C)   No motor vehicle of any kind or type shall be parked upon 20th Street
between Edgewood Road and Chester Avenue between the hours of 4:00 a.m. and 6:
00 a.m.;
   (D)   No motor vehicle of any kind or type shall be parked upon 21st Street
between the canal and Chester Avenue between the hours of 4:00 a.m. and 6:00
a.m.;
   (E)   No motor vehicle of any kind or type shall be parked upon 22nd Street
between the canal and Chester Avenue between the hours of 4:00 a.m. and 6:00
a.m.; and
   (F)   No motor vehicle of any kind or type shall be parked upon Chester
Avenue between 18th Street and 22nd Street between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and
5:00 a.m.
(Prior Code, § 75.19) Penalty, see §
75.99
§ 75.30 PARKING TRUCKS AT NIGHT AND ON SUNDAY.
   No person, corporation, owner, operator, employee, or agent of any such
person or corporation shall park and leave standing for more than 30 minutes,
any motor bus, motor truck over one-half ton capacity, semitrailer truck,
trailer truck or trailer attached or detached or any heavy machinery or
equipment vehicle, on any of the hereinafter named streets between the hours of
7:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. and at any time on Sundays. The streets are as follows:
   (A)   Cumberland Avenue from 10th Street to 30th Street;
   (B)   Lothbury Avenue from 20th Street to 18th Street;
   (C)   Chester Avenue from 22nd Street to 18th Street;
   (D)   Eighteenth Street from Chester Avenue to Lothbury Avenue;
   (E)   Nineteenth Street from Lothbury Avenue to Amesbury Avenue;
   (F)   Twentieth Street from Chester Avenue to Amesbury Avenue;
   (G)   Twenty-first Street from Chester Avenue to Cumberland Avenue; and
   (H)   Twenty-second Street from Chester Avenue to Cumberland Avenue.
(Prior Code, § 75.20)
§ 75.31 PARKING LIMIT FOR VEHICLES CONVEYING FARM PRODUCTS.
   No person driving or propelling, or in charge of, any vehicle or conveyance
from which garden or farm products, or other merchandise or wares are sold,
shall park the same on any street of the city for a longer time than ten
minutes, except on Lothbury Avenue between 18th and 19th Streets.
(Prior Code, § 75.21)
§ 75.32 IMPOUNDING OF VEHICLES PARKED IN VIOLATION OF THE LAW.
   (A)   Any vehicle parked upon the streets of the city at a place, in a
manner or for a length of time prohibited by this chapter, is, if unoccupied,
declared to be an obstruction in such streets and a public nuisance; and any
police officer of the city is authorized to cause the same to be removed to and
impounded in the depository provided by the city for such purpose.
   (B)   All charges shall be paid to the city for any fine, storage charges,
or hauling charges before the release of the impounded vehicle is authorized.
   (C)   Impounded vehicles shall be held for a period of 90 days, and if
unclaimed by that time, shall be advertised and sold.
(Prior Code, § 75.22)
§ 75.33 PARKING RESTRICTED ON CHASTEEN DRIVE AND NUTWOOD ROAD; SPEED LIMIT.
   (A)   No operator of a motor vehicle shall drive at a greater speed than 15
mph on Chasteen or that part of Nutwood Road that lies within the area of the
Municipal Housing Project, both in the city.
   (B)   Parking on Chasteen Drive shall be restricted to the right-hand side
of the walk side of the street going west from the office of the project.
   (C)   Parking on Nutwood Road shall be restricted to the right-hand side of
the street going north from Polar Bear Avenue.
(Prior Code, § 75.23)
§ 75.34 IMPOUNDING OF VEHICLES UPON RECEIPT OF COMPLAINT.
   (A)   The Police Department, upon the receipt of a complaint that any public
street or alleyway in the city, or any private driveway or parking lot or other
type of private property, is being obstructed by the parking of any type of
vehicle in the street or alleyway or on or adjacent to the private driveway or
property, so that free access thereto is impaired or prevented, and on
verification of the complaint by officers of the agency, the investigating
office of the agency is authorized and directed to cause the obstructing
vehicle to be impounded and immediately hauled away from the place where the
obstruction has occurred to a secure storage area where it shall remain until
the cost of the hauling away of the vehicle has been paid by the owner or
operator of the vehicle or someone in his or her behalf.
   (B)   A list of persons or firms who are willing to perform the work of
hauling off such vehicles shall be maintained by the Police Department, and the
work shall be assigned to these persons or firms in sequential fashion, giving
no preference to any of them.
(Prior Code, § 75.24) (Minute book CC, page 165, passed 12-5-1978)
LOADING ZONES
  § 75.45 LOADING PERMITS IN NO PARKING AREAS.
   (A)   No vehicle shall be parked or allowed to remain against the curb of
any street in the city, where the curb has been painted yellow or sign posted
denoting a “no parking” restricted area.
   (B)   Loading and unloading privileges in such areas may be granted by the
Chief of Police by issuing to the applicant, where circumstances necessitate
such action, a written permit to do so, only, however, after a thorough
investigation by the Chief of Police, or an officer acting for him or her, and
a bona fide need of such a permit on the part of the applicant for loading or
unloading purposes and not otherwise. The permit may be cancelled by the Chief
of Police at any time for violations of the provisions of the permit.
(Prior Code, § 75.25)
§ 75.46 BUS LOADING ZONES.
   (A)   No bus or buses shall be allowed to stop or park for the purpose of
receiving or discharging passengers on Cumberland Avenue between 19th Street
and 22nd Street, except at the intersections of Cumberland Avenue and 21st
Street and Cumberland Avenue and 20th Street.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any motor transportation company, or the
owner, operator, or person in charge of any bus to drive the same, or permit
the same to be driven, upon the L. & N. Railroad Company right-of-way or
station grounds at its passenger station at the end of Lothbury Avenue, or to
park or permit any bus to stand or remain on the right-of-way or station
grounds for any period of time.
   (C)   A BUS, as mentioned in this section, is a motor vehicle operating over
public highways between fixed terminals or over a regular route for hire, or
for which a certificate or convenience from the Commission or motor
transportation is required for its operation under the laws of Kentucky.
   (D)   It shall also be unlawful for any operator, employee, or owner of such
bus to go on the railroad company’s property to solicit business.
(Prior Code, § 75.27)
   TWO-HOUR PARKING LIMIT ZONES
  § 75.60 TWO HOUR FREE PARKING ZONES.
   (A)   There are established and fixed certain zones to be known as two-hour
parking limit zones on the following streets and avenues of the city:
      (1)   Cumberland Avenue from 18th to 22nd Streets;
      (2)   Twentieth Street from Chester Avenue to Edgewood Road;
      (3)   Twenty-first Street from Chester Avenue to Cumberland Avenue;
      (4)   Nineteenth Street from Chester Avenue to Amesbury Avenue, including
bridge over canal;
      (5)   Lothbury Avenue from 18th Street to 20th Street; and
      (6)   From time to time as traffic conditions require in such other
streets and avenues as are designated by ordinance of Council for the location
of such zones.
   (B)   The time limit for parking in the designated zones in this section
shall be two hours.
   (C)   A parking ticket or citation shall be issued hereunder with respect to
each separate offense.
(Prior Code, § 75.35) (Minute book GG, page 23, passed 10-5-1982) Penalty, see
§
75.99
§ 75.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   The owner or operator of any vehicle so parked in violation of §
75.29 shall be subject to a fine of not less than $5 nor more than $15, and any
vehicle so parked may be removed by wrecker to the city hall parking area,
where such vehicle can be reclaimed by its owner by payment of the charges of
towing the vehicle.
   (B)   Whoever violates any other section of this chapter, shall be deemed
guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a
fine of not less than $5 and not more than $100 for each violation, or by
imprisonment in jail for not less than ten days nor more than 30 days, or both
so fined and imprisoned in the discretion of the court or jury trying the case,
and in the case of conviction, shall pay the costs incurred by the city.
   (C)   Any person who violates §§
75.05 or
75.20 shall be excused if such person, within 48 hours from the time of the
issuance of the parking citation, deposits with the City Clerk’s office a fine
of $25. The violations referred to herein and the fine shall be noted on any
parking citation issued.
   (D)   Any person who violates the two-hour limit established in §
75.60 by parking longer than two hours in the same space shall be subject to a
fine of $10 if paid within 48 hours. If this penalty of $10 is not paid to the
City Clerk within 48 hours, the owner of the vehicle as determined by the
license of the vehicle shall be immediately served with a citation to be issued
and served by the Police Department to appear and answer the citation in the
Bell District Court where he or she shall be subject to a minimum penalty or
fine of $25 and court costs.
(Prior Code, § 75.99) (Minute book CC, page 90, passed 7-18-1978; Minute book
GG, page 23, passed 10-5-1982)

CHAPTER 90: STREETS AND SIDEWALKS
Section
   
90.01   Permission to cut into public way required

§ 90.01 PERMISSION TO CUT INTO PUBLIC WAY REQUIRED.
   No person, nor any corporation or other legal entity, acting through its
employees or agents, shall hereafter cut into or in any way disturb or destroy
the surface or foundation of any public way in the city, without first
obtaining permission from the Council of the city to so cut the public way and
without also posting such bond as may be required by the Council of the city
for the repair and reestablishment of the public way in the same condition or
better condition than it was in prior to the time same was cut.
(Prior Code, § 90.01)
§ 90.02 APPLICATION TO BE FILED WITH CLERK.
   Any person, corporation, or other legal entity desiring to cut a public way
within the corporate limits of the city shall first make application in the
office of the Clerk, wherein the city shall be advised which public way is
proposed to be cut, the extent to which such public way is to be cut, the
method by which such public way is to be restored to its condition prior to
cutting, and the bond proposed to be executed to assure the city that the
public way will be restored as required.
(Prior Code, § 90.02)
§ 90.03 CITY ENGINEER TO INVESTIGATE APPLICATIONS; REJECTIONS.
   The Clerk shall immediately advise the City Engineer that such application
has been filed, whereupon the City Engineer shall investigate the application
and shall as soon as possible submit same with his or her recommendations to
the Public Works Committee of the Council. The Public Works Committee shall at
the next meeting of the Council present the application to the Council,
together with its recommendations as to whether the application should be
accepted or rejected and, if rejected, setting out the reasons why the
application is rejected. In the event it is recommended that an application be
rejected, it shall be the duty of the Public Works Committee, prior to the
meeting of the Council, to notify the City Clerk that the application has been
rejected and the City Clerk shall thereupon notify the applicant.
(Prior Code, § 90.03)
§ 90.04 EMERGENCY CUTTING OF PUBLIC WAY.
   In the event an emergency arises such as a leak in a water main or a similar
emergency requiring immediate action to prevent excessive damage to the public
ways of the city, or danger to the public, the City Engineer shall be notified
and shall supervise the cutting and repair of the public way.
(Prior Code, § 90.04)
§ 90.05 PUBLIC UTILITIES; BOND.
   Every public utility operating in the city shall be required to post a
standing bond of at least $2,500, which bond shall assure the repair of any
public way which is cut as a result of any emergency referred to in §
90.04. This bond shall remain in force during all times that the public utility
operates within the city limits. At its option, each public utility operating
within the city limits subject to the provisions of this chapter may post a
standing bond of not less than $5,000, which bond shall assure the proper
repair of any public way which is cut by the utility, including emergency
repairs referred to above, and all other repairs for which an individual bond
is required. If such bond is executed, the utility will be relieved of the
obligation of executing individual bonds for each separate cutting of any
public way in the city. However, the same requirements as to permits and
inspections by the City Engineer and all other requirements under this chapter
shall apply to the utilities.
(Prior Code, § 90.05)
§ 90.06 RELEASE OF BONDS.
   No bond required to be posted under this chapter shall be released until the
street has been restored and has been inspected by the City Engineer and
approved as repaired. Whereupon, the applicant may then request the Council to
release the applicant upon the bond posted under the terms of this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 90.06)
§ 90.07 USING PUBLIC WAYS FOR VENDING OR ADVERTISEMENT.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation or any employee or
agent of same, to use any street, sidewalk, or alley or any public way, either
in whole or in part, for the purpose of vending any article whatever or
conducting any business, occupation, or trade or displaying or advertising any
business, occupation, or trade or to place any materials, goods, wares, and
merchandise on any such public ways, or any portion thereof, for the purpose of
advertising, displaying, or selling or for any other purpose.
(Prior Code, § 90.07) Penalty, see §
90.99
§ 90.08 DUTY TO KEEP SIDEWALKS CLEAN AND IN GOOD ORDER.
   The owners or lessees of lots in the city shall keep the sidewalks, next to
their premises, clean and in good order. Any person, who shall fail or refuse
to do so after three days’ notice from the Chief of Police, shall be held in
violation of this section.
(Prior Code, § 90.08) Penalty, see §
90.99
§ 90.09 OBSTRUCTING STREET OR SIDEWALK.
   It shall be unlawful to obstruct any of the regularly laid out streets or
sidewalks of the city without first obtaining permission from the Mayor to do
so.
(Prior Code, § 90.09) Penalty, see §
90.99
§ 90.10 SWEEPING GARBAGE OR REFUSE INTO STREET.
   No person shall throw, sweep, or otherwise cause to be placed into or on any
street, sidewalk, avenue, alley, lot, or yard in the city, any garbage, slop,
ashes, or other refuse matter, unless the same be placed in covered boxes,
barrels, or other receptacle for removal by the owner or occupant of such lot
or yard or by the city, at least once per week.
(Prior Code, § 90.10) Penalty, see §
90.99
Cross-reference:
   Burning of trash, §
91.20
§ 90.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Whoever cuts into a public way of the city without complying with the
requirements of §§
90.01 through
90.06 shall be fined not less than $50, nor more than $100 for each separate
offense hereunder and, in addition, shall be liable in damages for the proper
repair of the public way.
   (B)   Whoever violates §§
90.07 or
90.08 shall be fined not more than $10.
   (C)   Whoever violates §§
90.09 or
90.10 shall be fined not less than $10 nor more than $50.
(Prior Code, § 90.99)

PUBLIC NUISANCE
§ 91.01 CERTAIN CONDITIONS DECLARED A NUISANCE.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for the owner, occupant, or person having control
or management of any land within the city to permit a public nuisance to
develop thereon.
   (B)   The following conditions are declared to be public nuisances:
      (1)   Dangerous trees or stacks adjoining street. Any tree, stack, or
other object standing in such a condition that it will, if the condition is
allowed to continue, endanger the life, limb, or property of, or cause hurt,
damage, or injury to persons or property upon the public streets or public ways
adjacent thereto, by the falling thereof or of parts thereof;
      (2)   Accumulation of rubbish. An accumulation on any premises of filth,
refuse, trash, garbage, or other waste material which endangers the public
health, welfare, or safety, or materially interferes with the peaceful
enjoyment by owners or occupants of adjacent property because of the danger
that it will catch or communicate fire, attract and propagate vermin, rodents,
or insects, or blow rubbish into any street, sidewalk, or property of another;
      (3)   Storage of explosives. The storage of explosive material which
creates a safety hazard to other property or persons in the vicinity;
      (4)   Weeds and grass. The excessive growth of weeds, grass, or other
vegetation. Unless otherwise provided, EXCESSIVE shall mean growth to a height
of ten inches or more;
      (5)   Open wells. The maintenance of any open, uncovered, or insecurely
covered cistern, cellar, well, pit, excavation, or vault situation upon private
premises in any open or unfenced lot or place;
      (6)   Trees and shrubbery obstructing streets, sidewalks, and drainage.
The growing and maintenance of trees or shrubbery which in any way interferes
with the use, construction, or maintenance of streets or sidewalks, causes
injury to streets or sidewalks, or constitutes an obstruction to drainage;
      (7)   Keeping of animals. The failure to keep an animal’s pen, yard, lot,
or other enclosure in a sanitary condition and free from preventable offensive
odors; and
      (8)   Junk; scrap metal; motor vehicles. The storage of motor vehicles in
any inoperative condition, motor vehicles unfit for further use, automobile
parts, or scrap metal within the city limits except on premises authorized by
the city for such purposes.
(Prior Code, § 91.01) (Ord. FY 96-97, #12, passed 1-7-1997) Penalty, see §
91.99
§ 91.02 ABATEMENT.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for the owner, occupant, or person having control
or management of any land within the city to permit a public nuisance, health
hazard or source of filth to develop thereon through the accumulation of
rubbish or the excessive growth of weeds or grass.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for the owner, occupant, or person having control
or management of any land in an unincorporated area to knowingly permit a
public nuisance or health hazard to develop thereon through the accumulation of
rubbish.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful in the city for the owner of property to permit
any structure upon the property to become unfit and unsafe for human
habitation, occupancy, or use or to permit conditions to exist in the structure
which are dangerous or injurious to the health or safety of the occupants of
the structure, the occupants of neighboring structures, or other residents of
the city.
   (D)   The procedures shall comply with all applicable statutes,
administrative regulations, or codes. Proper notice shall be given to property
owners before any action is taken pursuant to this section; and, prior to the
demolition of any unfit or unsafe structure, the right to a hearing shall be
afforded the property owner.
   (E)   The city shall have a lien against the property for the reasonable
value of labor and materials used in remedying the situation. The affidavit of
the responsible officer shall constitute prima facie evidence of the amount of
the lien and the regularity of the proceedings pursuant to this statute, and
shall be recorded in the office of the County Clerk. The lien shall be notice
to all persons from the time of its recording and shall bear interest
thereafter until paid. The lien created shall take precedence over all other
subsequent liens, except state, county, school board, and city taxes, and may
be enforced by judicial proceedings.
   (F)   In addition to the remedy prescribed in division (E) of this section
or any other remedy authorized by law, the owner of a property upon which a
lien has been attached pursuant to this section shall be personally liable for
the amount of the lien, including all interest, civil penalties, and other
charges and the city may bring a civil action against the owner and shall have
the same remedies as provided for the recovery of a debt owed.
   (G)   The provisions of divisions (D), (E), and (F) of this section shall
not apply to an owner, occupant, or person having control or management of any
land located in an unincorporated area if the owner, occupant, or person is not
the generator of the rubbish or is not dumping or knowingly allowing the
dumping of the rubbish and has made reasonable efforts to prevent the dumping
of rubbish by other persons onto the property.
(KRS 65.8840) (Prior Code, § 91.02) (Ord. FY 96-97, #12, passed 1-7-1997)
§ 91.03 NUISANCE BY OTHERS.
   For the purposes of this chapter, it shall not be essential that the
nuisance be created or contributed to by the owner, occupant, or person having
control or management of the premises, but merely that the nuisance be created
or contributed to by licensees, invitees, guests, or other persons for whose
conduct the owner or operator is responsible, or by persons for whose conduct
the owner or operator is not responsible, but by the exercise of reasonable
care ought to have become aware of.
(Prior Code, § 91.03) (Ord. FY 96-97, #12, passed 1-7-1997)
§ 91.04 UNUSUAL AND LOUD NOISE PROHIBITED.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to create or
assist in creating any unreasonable loud and disturbing noise in the city.
Noise of such character, intensity, and duration as to be detrimental to the
public health, welfare, and peace is prohibited.
   (B)   The following acts, among others, are declared to be loud and
disturbing noises in violation of this section, but this enumeration shall not
be deemed to be exclusive:
      (1)   The sounding of any horn or signal device on any automobile,
motorcycle, bus, or other vehicle, except as a danger signal, so as to create
any unreasonable loud or harsh sound, or the sounding of such device for an
unreasonable period of time, or the use of any gong or siren upon any vehicle,
other than police, fire, or other emergency vehicle;
      (2)   The playing of any radio, phonograph, or other musical instrument
in a manner or with such volume, particularly during hours between 11:00 p.m.
and 7:00 a.m. as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort, or repose of any
person in any dwelling, hotel, or other type of residence;
      (3)   No bird or animal shall be kept within 125 feet of the property
line of another, which, by causing frequent or long continued noise, shall
disturb the comfort and repose of any person;
      (4)   (a)   The use of any automobile, motorcycle, trucks of any size, or
any vehicle so out of repair, so loaded, or in a manner as to create loud
grating, grinding, rattling, or other noise, particularly through residential
areas during daylight hours, and most particularly throughout the nighttime
hours; and
         (b)   No vehicle used for commercial hauling shall operate between the
hours of dusk to daylight if noise so generated by such vehicles shall be
operated in a section zoned residential if such operation creates noise or
pollution that disturbs the quiet, peace, and repose of the neighborhoods.
      (5)   The conducting, operating, or maintaining of any garage or service
station in any residential area so as to cause loud or offensive noises to be
emitted therefrom between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. on weekdays or
on Sundays;
      (6)   The creation of any excessive noise on any street adjacent to any
school, institution of learning, or court while the same are in session, or
within 150 feet of any hospital, which unreasonably interferes with the working
of those institutions, provided conspicuous signs are displayed in those
streets indicating that the area is a school, court, or hospital area;
      (7)   The creation of any excessive noise on Sundays on any street
adjacent to any church, provided conspicuous signs are displayed in such
streets adjacent to churches indicating that the same is a church street;
      (8)   The erection (including excavation), demolition, alteration, or
repair of any building in a residential or business district other than between
the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., on weekdays, except in the case of urgent
necessity in the interest of public safety and then only with a permit from the
code enforcement office, which permit may be renewed for a period of three days
or less while the emergency continues;
      (9)   The use of any drum, loud speaker, or other instrument or device
for the purpose of attracting attention by creation of noise to any
performance, show, or sale or display of merchandise; and
      (10)   The use of any mechanical loud speakers or amplifiers on trucks or
other moving vehicles for advertising purposes or other purposes except where
permission is received from the City Council.
(Prior Code, § 91.04) (Ord. FY 96-97, #12, passed 1-7-1997) Penalty, see §
91.99
§ 91.05 SUSPENSION.
   (A)   Whenever it is brought to the attention of the City Council that a
nuisance exists and the City Council deems that there is an immediate threat to
the public health, safety, welfare, the City Council may by majority suspend
the license of any person conducting business upon the premises where the
nuisance exists.
   (B)   The City Clerk shall cause notice of the suspension to be served
personally upon the licensee or at the premises where the nuisance exists.
   (C)   Upon application of the licensee, the City Council may remove the
suspension upon such terms as it may direct.
(Prior Code, § 91.05) (Ord. FY 96-97, #12, passed 1-7-1997)
GARBAGE AND REFUSE
§ 91.20 BURNING OF TRASH IN RECEPTACLES.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to kindle or maintain a
bonfire, or burn trash lumber, leaves, straw, or any other combustible material
in any street or alley, or on any premises or vacant lot, unless such burning
is done in covered receptacles of not more than one and one- fourth-inch wire
mesh, or of metal.
   (B)   The Chief of the Fire Department may issue a general permit, by
publication, during seasons of the year, for the burning of leaves or other
like materials outside of receptacles, but, in no event, shall such permission
cover or apply to the burning of leaves or other like materials on any city
street paved with asphalt, concrete, or like material.
   (C)   All burning of materials permitted by division (B) of this section
shall be conducted on still days, during daylight between the hours of 4:00
p.m. and 8:00 p.m. with an adult in constant attendance, and shall be done in a
location at least 25 feet from any building or structure, and where standing
grass or weeds will not communicate fire to nearby property.
(Prior Code, § 91.40) (Minute book T, page 316, passed 11-2-1966) Penalty, see
§
91.99
Cross-reference:
   Sweeping garbage or refuse into street, §
90.10
DISCHARGE OF FIREARMS
§ 91.35 DISCHARGE OF FIREARM PROHIBITED; EXCEPTIONS.
   It is deemed to be in the best interest of the citizens to prohibit and make
unlawful the discharge of a firearm within city limits, except as follows:
   (A)   Any duly sworn and authorized law enforcement official or other duly
authorized official shall be exempt from this subchapter if the discharging of
his or her firearm occurs during and in furtherance of their official capacity;
   (B)   Any duly licensed, permitted and authorized shooting facility;
   (C)   Any person(s) discharging a firearm in defense of one’s life or
property; and
   (D)   Military funerals and/or military ceremonies.
(Prior Code, § 91.50) (Ord. FY 94-95, #13, passed 11-15-1994) Penalty, see §
91.99
§ 91.36 HUNTING, TRAPPING PROHIBITED.
   Due to the close proximity of dwelling houses, schools, industrial ventures,
automobiles traveling the thoroughfares, and the like, of and within the city
limits and the dangers which are inherent with firearms and other hunting and
trapping devices and weapons, it is deemed to be in the best interest of the
general public as a whole to prohibit and make unlawful any and all hunting and
trapping within the city limits.
(Prior Code, § 91.51) (Ord. FY 94-95, #14, passed 11-15-1994) Penalty, see §
91.99
§ 91.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Whoever violates any provision of §§
91.01 through
91.05, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not less than $100
nor more than $500. Each day’s continued violation shall constitute a separate
offense.
   (B)   Any person who violates any of the provisions of §
91.20 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction of same shall be
fined not less than $10 nor more than $50 for each such offense.
   (C)   Upon conviction of a violation of §§
91.35 and
91.36, a $100 fine shall be assessed in addition to any and all statutory
penalties, if any.
   (D)   Whoever violates any other provision of this chapter shall be fined
not more than $20, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each
day during on or which the offense occurs or continues.
(Prior Code, § 91.99) (Ord. FY 94-95, #13, passed 11-15-1994, Ord. FY 94-95,
#14, passed 11-15-1994; Ord. FY 96-97, #12, passed 1-7-1997)
CHAPTER 92: CURFEW
Section
   
92.01   Definitions
   
92.02   Time limits
