92.99   Penalty
§ 92.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ALLOW. Either permit or neglect to refrain or prevent. It requires actual or
constructive knowledge on the part of the parent or guardian, that is, the
parent or guardian must actually know about the child violating this section,
or the circumstances must be such that a reasonable prudent parent or guardian
should have known the child was violating this section.
   CITY PARK. Any recreational facility owned, operated, or maintained by the
city; to include picnic areas, shelters, pools, playgrounds, facilities and
equipment for engaging in any sport or activity (such as basketball, horseshoe
pitch, skating, and the like), restrooms, buildings, and grounds encompassing
any such area.
   MINOR. Any person under the age of 18, or, as may be otherwise phrased, any
person of the age of 17 or younger.
   PARENT. Any person having legal custody of a minor:
      (1)   As a natural or adoptive parent;
      (2)   As a legal guardian;
      (3)   As a person who stands “in loco parentis”; or
      (4)   As a person to whom legal custody has been given by order of court.
   REMAIN. To stay behind, to tarry, or to stay unnecessarily upon or in any
public assembly, building, place, street, or highway.
(Prior Code, § 92.01) (Ord. 95-96, #2, passed 9-5-1995; Ord. FY 11-12, #8,
passed 5-15-2012)
§ 92.02 TIME LIMITS.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any minor to be or remain in or upon any
public assembly, building, place, street, or highway within the city at night
during the following periods:
Time Day of the Week
Time                              Day of the Week
1:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m.            Saturday
1:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m.            Sunday
11:00 p.m. Sunday to 6:00 a.m.    Monday
11:00 p.m. Monday to 6:00 a.m.    Tuesday
11:00 p.m. Tuesday to 6:00 a.m.   Wednesday
11:00 p.m. Wednesday to 6:00 a.m. Thursday
11:00 p.m. Thursday to 6:00 a.m.  Friday
 
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any parent or guardian to allow a minor to be
or remain in or upon a public assembly, building, place, street, or highway in
the city under circumstances not constituting an exception as enumerated in §
92.03 during the time periods contained in division (A) of this section.
(Prior Code, § 92.02) (Ord. 95-96, #2, passed 9-5-1995) Penalty, see §
92.99
§ 92.03 EXCEPTIONS.
   In the following cases a minor in or upon any public assembly, building,
place, street or highway in the city during the hours provided for in §
92.02 shall not be considered in violation of this section:
   (A)   When the minor is accompanied by a parent or guardian;
   (B)   When accompanied by an adult authorized by a parent or guardian of
such minor;
   (C)   When exercising First Amendment rights protected by the United States
Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech, and the
right of assembly, provided that written notice signed by the minor and
countersigned by a parent is in the possession of such minor specifying when,
where, and in what manner said minor will be exercising such First Amendment
rights;
   (D)   In the case of reasonable necessity but only after such minor’s parent
has communicated to the Police Department the facts establishing such
reasonable necessity;
   (E)   When the minor is on the sidewalk of the place where such minor
resides, or on the sidewalk of either next-door neighbor who has not
communicated an objection to a police officer of the Police Department;
   (F)   When returning home, by direct route from, and within one hour of the
termination of, a school activity, or any activity of a religious or other
voluntary association, provided that justification indicating the place and
time of termination of said event can be given to any investigating officer of
the Police Department;
   (G)   When authorized by regulation issued by the Chief of Police in cases
of reasonable necessity involving more minors than may be reasonably dealt with
on an individual basis. Such regulation should be issued sufficiently in
advance to permit publicity through news media and through other agencies such
as the schools. The regulation shall define the activity, the scope of the use
of the public assembly, building, place, street, or highway permitted and the
period of time involved not to extend more than one hour beyond the termination
of the activity, and the reason for finding that such regulation is reasonably
necessary. The Chief of Police shall notify the Police Department personnel of
said information;
   (H)   When engaged in a business or occupation which the laws of the state
authorizes a minor to perform;
   (I)   When the minor is, with written parental consent, in a motor vehicle
with a lawfully authorized driver; and
   (J)   When the minor, who is a duly authorized and licensed driver, is
operating a motor vehicle within the city for the purpose of passing through,
by direct route, from one location to another either within or out of the city,
including all minors that may also be within the vehicle.
(Prior Code, § 92.03) (Ord. 95-96, #2, passed 9-5-1995)
§ 92.04 DUTIES OF LAW ENFORCEMENT.
   (A)   A police officer upon finding or being notified of any minor in or
upon any public assembly, building, place, street, or highway reasonable
believed to be in violation of §
92.02 shall stop and question such minor and request such information as his or
her name and age and the name and address of his or her parent or guardian.
   (B)   If a police officer determines or has reasonable cause to believe that
a curfew violation has occurred, the police officer may obtain the necessary
information to issue a citation to the minor’s parent or guardian and then
either take the minor home, take the minor to the police station and notify the
parent pursuant to KRS 610.220, or direct the minor to proceed immediately to
his or her home.
(Prior Code, § 92.04) (Ord. 95-96, #2, passed 9-5-1995)
§ 92.05 PARK HOURS.
   (A)   City park hours are 6:00 a.m. until 12:00 a.m. (midnight) daily, year
round. Except as provided for in division (B) of this section, no person is
permitted to be on any park premises between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 6:00
a.m. This section shall not be construed as an indication that any particular
services or functions of a park will be available during all open hours;
seasonal and staffing limitations may apply to recreational functions.
   (B)   Park hours may be extended for city sponsored special events, sporting
events conducted by city sanctioned leagues or organizations, or by specific
approval of the executive authority or his or her designee. Events held at the
Community Center under a rental agreement are subject to the terms agreed upon
and any applicable administrative policy. In the event of extended hours, a
city official shall notify the Police Department when all functions are
complete and the affected park is to be closed.
   (C)   The Police Department is directed to regularly patrol all city parks
closed hours. If any person is discovered unlawfully on park premises, they are
to be immediately removed from the premises. The officer may issue a warning
for a first offense if no other violations of statute or ordinance are
discovered. In the event of enforcement action, an officer may elect to charge
an offender pursuant to state trespassing statutes (KRS Chapter 511) of he or
she has determined that the offender has been previously charged with a
violation of this section.
(Prior Code, § 92.05) (Ord. FY 11-12, #8, passed 5-15-2012) Penalty, see §
92.99
§ 92.99 PENALTY.
   Any parent, guardian or person having legal custody allowing a minor to
violate §
92.02(B) shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to a fine of no
more than $500 or imprisonment for a period not to exceed six months or both.
Any person found in violation of §
92.05(A) shall be subject to a fine of not more than $100.
(Prior Code, § 92.99) (Ord. 95-96, #2, passed 9-5-1996; Ord. FY 11-12, #8,
passed 5-15-2012)

§ 93.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   DOG. Includes both male and female, and the plural of dog. None of the
provisions of this chapter apply to dogs under the age of four months.
   OWNER. When applied to the proprietorship of a dog, includes every person
having a right of property in the dog, every person who keeps or harbors the
dog or has it in his or her care, every person who permits a dog to remain on
or about any premises occupied by him or her.
   PEACE OFFICER or OFFICER OF THE CITY. Any person upon whom police duties
have been conferred by the city.
   REGULARLY PRACTICING AND LICENSED VETERINARIAN. A veterinarian who has a
state license to practice in Kentucky or who has a license to practice in any
state on a comity basis with Kentucky.
(Prior Code, § 93.01) (Ord. 06-07, #3, passed 8-15-2006)
§ 93.02 LICENSE REQUIRED FOR ALL DOGS.
   No person shall own or keep any dog in the city unless such dog is licensed
by the Clerk of the city or one of his or her deputies, and unless the dog
shall at all times wear the city license tag provided for by this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 93.02) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.03 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   The owner of any dog in the city shall apply to a regular practicing and
licensed veterinarian, who will be a Deputy Clerk, appointed for this purpose,
for a license for each such dog owned or kept by him or her, and such
application shall be accompanied by a statement of the breed, sex, age, color,
and markings of such dog and such application shall also be accompanied by a
receipt from a regular practicing veterinarian, showing that the dog for which
the license is applied for has been subjected to an injection of serum for the
prevention of rabies. Upon the filing of the application, accompanied by the
receipt from the veterinarian, a city tag will be issued the owner of the dog,
free of charge, and the tag shall be of metal and impressed thereon the year
for which the license tag is issued and the license tag shall be displayed on
the dog at all times.
(Prior Code, § 93.03) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.04 LICENSE TAGS NOT TRANSFERABLE.
   No license tag issued for one dog shall be transferable to another dog, and
if the tag is lost the same shall be replaced without cost by the city upon
application by the person to whom the original license was issued. Any person
becoming the owner of a dog shall forthwith apply for and secure a license for
such dog in the same manner as the annual license is obtained under the
provisions of §
93.03.
(Prior Code, § 93.04) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.05 UNLICENSED DOGS TO BE IMPOUNDED.
   It shall be the duty of the peace officers of the city, or anyone given
police powers by the city to seize and impound any dog found running at large
or accompanied by its owner or keeper, which does not bear a city license tag.
(Prior Code, § 93.05)
§ 93.06 DUTY TO SEARCH FOR UNLICENSED DOGS.
   It shall be the duty of the peace officers of the city, or anyone given
police powers by the city, to go upon the premises of any person for the
purpose of ascertaining if the person is the owner or keeper harboring any
unlicensed dog. However, a warrant theretofore shall be obtained to search the
premises, and if any unlicensed dog is found, the officer shall seize and
impound the dog in a place provided by the city and notice shall be given to
the owner and keeper of the dog of its being impounded. If the dog is not
claimed within five days after the notice is given, the officer of the city,
whose duty it is to enforce this act, shall dispose of the dog by sale or by
destruction in a humane manner.
(Prior Code, § 93.06)
§ 93.07 UNKNOWN OWNER OF IMPOUNDED DOG.
   If the owner or keeper of the dog so impounded is not known to the officer
impounding the dog, it shall be his or her duty to advertise in the newspaper
at least one time, the date of the seizure of the dog, its breed, sex, color,
and other line of markings for identification; and if five days have elapsed
after the publication and no claim is made for the dog, then the dog shall be
disposed of by sale or destruction in a humane manner.
(Prior Code, § 93.07)
§ 93.08 UNLAWFUL REMOVING OF DOG TAGS.
   No person shall remove the city license tag from the dog or remove any
collar or appliance with the license tag attached thereto from any dog, except
the owner or his or her authorized agent.
(Prior Code, § 93.08) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.09 ALLOWING DOG TO BECOME STRAY PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person who owns a dog, or has a dog under his
or her control or in his or her custody, to abandon or permit the dog to become
a stray or lost dog within the city.
(Prior Code, § 93.09) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.10 TRADING DOGS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to congregate in groups for
the purpose of trading in dogs, or for any person to permit congregation in
groups on property owned or controlled by them.
(Prior Code, § 93.10) (Minute book V, page 203, passed 6-24-1969) Penalty, see
§
93.99
§ 93.11 CRUELTY TO ANIMALS.
   No person shall beat or otherwise injure or misuse a horse or other animal
in an immoderate, cruel, or unnecessary degree; nor shall this person leave, or
cause to be left, any wounded, maimed, diseased, or worn-out horse or mule on
any street, alley, lot, or on the commons, to die a lingering death.
(Prior Code, § 93.11) Penalty, see §
93.99
Cross-reference:
   For provisions concerning dogs, see §
93.25
§ 93.12 RUNNING AT LARGE PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, being the owner or harborer or having
charge or control of any animal, to permit such animal to run at large in any
street or any other public place in the city or to permit any such animal to go
upon or enter any private yard, lot, or enclosure without the consent of the
owner of such yard, lot, or enclosure.
(Prior Code, § 93.12) (Ord. FY 87-88, #3, passed 8-4-1987) Penalty, see §
93.99
Statutory reference:
   Cattle not to run at large, see KRS 259.210
   Confinement and control of dogs at night, see KRS 258.265
§ 93.13 KEEPING STOCK NEAR RESIDENCES PROHIBITED.
   (A)   No person shall keep, or permit to be kept, any cows, horses, or other
stock or animals in any enclosure or building within 100 feet of the property
line of any other property owner whose premises may be used for residence
purposes.
   (B)   Any landlord or agent of a landlord, whose tenant shall be guilty of a
violation of this section, shall also be guilty of such violation, if he or she
shall not upon notice thereof cause his or her tenant to abate such conditions
or evict him or her from the premises if legally possible, and any lease or
rental shall be subject to this police regulation.
   (C)   Upon notice and failure to comply with this section, the City Council
may by order direct the Police Chief to remove such stock from the premises and
put the same in a sanitary condition at the expense of the owner or lessee.
(Prior Code, § 93.13) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.14 LOUD ANIMALS PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or harbor any animal which
howls, barks, or emits audible sounds which are unreasonably loud or disturbing
and which are of such a character, intensity, and duration as to disturb the
peace and quiet of the neighborhood or to be detrimental to the life and health
of any individual.
(Prior Code, § 93.14) (Ord. FY 87-88, #3, passed 8-4-1987) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.15 KEEPING HOGS OR PIGS WITHIN CITY LIMITS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any hogs or pigs anywhere within
the city limits, either in pens or running at large. Provided that nothing in
this section shall apply to the temporary keeping of hogs or pigs awaiting
delivery or shipment when brought into the city for that purpose.
(Prior Code, § 93.15) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.16 BEEKEEPING.
   It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to keep bees within two
blocks of the central business district.
(Prior Code, § 93.16) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.17 CITY AS A BIRD SANCTUARY.
   The city is proclaimed to be a municipal bird sanctuary. The people are
called upon to protect birds from stray dogs, cats, or unlawful shooting, and
to replant berry-producing trees and shrubs for food and shelter.
(Prior Code, § 93.17) (Minute book Y, page 146, passed 10-3-1972)
§ 93.18 WILD, VICIOUS, AND FEROCIOUS ANIMALS PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to harbor or keep any vicious or
ferocious animal or suffer or permit such animal to go unconfined or run at
large.
(Prior Code, § 93.18) (Ord. FY 87-88, #3, passed 8-4-1987) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.19 DANGEROUS DOGS.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or harbor within the city
limits a dog that shall bite or fiercely attack any person while outside the
owner’s yard or enclosure. This section shall not apply where a person shall
break into or enter, without permission, the premises or enclosure of such dog
and be pursued therefrom and attacked or bitten by such dog.
   (B)   The owner(s) must provide a secure fencing to keep the dog confined on
his or her own property. When off the owner’s property, the dog must be kept on
a secure leash of no more than eight feet in length and under control.
(Prior Code, § 93.19) (Ord. FY 87-88, #3, passed 8-4-1988; Ord. 06-07, #3,
passed 8-15-2006) Penalty, see §
93.99
Statutory reference:
   Physicians to report persons bitten by dogs and other animals, see KRS
258.065
§ 93.20 TRAPPING OR KILLING SQUIRRELS PROHIBITED.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to trap, kill, maim, or mutilate any squirrel
within the city limits.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful to knowingly place a poisoned substance which
will harm or kill any squirrel within the city limits where a squirrel can come
into contact with said substance.
   (C)   The only exception to divisions (A) or (B) of this section shall be in
such cases where it is necessary to protect property in the city, or if said
squirrels propose a health hazard to the citizens of the city as determined by
a license medical doctor, a doctor of veterinary medicine, or the local Health
Department.
(Prior Code, § 93.20) (Ord. FY 88-89, #12, passed - -) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.21 DOGS ARE PERSONAL PROPERTY.
   (A)   The city recognizes that dogs are personal property, belonging to
owners, not guardians.
   (B)   No city authority shall restrict or prohibit the ownership of dogs by
breed, by size, by physical description, by gender, or by reproductive status.
   (C)   No breed specific ordinances shall stand, to include home rule, where
applicable.
   (D)   The city recognizes the right of the people to own any breed of dog in
a responsible manner.
(Prior Code, § 93.21) (Ord. 06-07, #3, passed 8-15-2006) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.22 DOGS IN PUBLIC.
   (A)   No dog shall be allowed in any city park, public or community event.
   (B)   All dogs shall be securely leashed on a lead no longer than eight feet
in length and controlled in the presence of an adult when off the owner’s
property. This shall not apply to service dogs such as but not limited to guide
dogs for the blind.
   (C)   No child under the age of 14 shall be allowed to lead a dog in public
areas without the direct supervision of an adult. This does not include junior
showmanship or other sanctioned dog show competition. Any parent whose
unattended child under the age of 14 is found in public with a dog on, or off a
leash, may be charged with reckless endangerment.
   (D)   No child under the age of ten should be left unattended with any dog.
(Prior Code, § 93.22) (Ord. 06-07, #3, passed 8-15-2006) Penalty, see §
93.99
Cross-reference:
   For similar provisions, see §
93.23
§ 93.23 STRICT LIABILITY.
   (A)   A dog owner will be held strictly liable for any harm, injury,
fatality, or trespass committed by his or her dog while off the owner’s
property at large, or out of the owner’s immediate control. This liability
shall include remuneration, fines, and/or jail time to commensurate with the
damage caused by the owner’s dog.
   (B)   A dog owner can be charged with negligent homicide whose dog kills a
person while off the owner’s property, unless the dog is protecting the owner
from a criminal act.
   (C)   A dog owner can be charged with reckless endangerment whose dog
injures a person, requiring medical attention, while off the owner’s property
at large or out of the owner’s immediate control.
(Prior Code, § 93.23) (Ord. 06-07, #3, passed 8-15-2006) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.24 DOG ABANDONMENT.
   (A)   Any person who abandons a dog by dumping it alongside any thoroughfare
or in a public place, or by moving away and leaving the dog shall be subject to
a $250 per dog fine, and jail time or community service not to exceed 30 days.
   (B)   All dogs’ owners must have proof of rabies shot and name of owner on
the dog.
(Prior Code, § 93.24) (Ord. 06-07, #3, passed 8-15-2006) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.25 CRUELTY TO DOGS.
   (A)   The owner shall provide his or her dog with shelter appropriate to the
climate, and a clean environment in which to live.
   (B)   The owner shall provide shade from sun and cover from the rain/snow.
   (C)   The owner shall provide the dog with food and clean drinking water
daily.
(Prior Code, § 93.25) (Ord. 06-07, #3, passed 8-15-2006) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.26 CONTAINMENT AND CARE.
   (A)   All dogs shall be contained to their owner’s property in either a
securely fenced yard, enclosure, or securely fastened tether.
   (B)   Every precaution must be made to protect the public from dogs that are
not behind a fenced enclosure.
   (C)   A sign warning of a dog breed being in the property must be visibly
posted and the presence of a dog(s) that is only tethered. The assumption of
liability is on the dog owner.
(Prior Code, § 93.26) (Ord. 06-07, #3, passed 8-15-2006) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Whoever violates §§
93.02 through
93.08 shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction
thereof, be fined not less than $10 nor more than $25.
   (B)   Whoever violates §§
93.09 and
93.10 shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than $5 nor more than $20.
   (C)   Whoever violates §
93.11 shall be fined in any sum not exceeding $50.
   (D)   Whoever violates §§
93.12,
93.14,
93.18, or
93.19 shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, be fined
not less than $10 nor more than $25.
   (E)   Whoever violates §
93.13 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not less than $10 nor
more than $100 or imprisoned not less than ten days nor more than 30 days, or
both such fine and imprisonment. A separate offense shall be deemed committed
upon each day during or on which the violation occurs or continues.
   (F)   Whoever violates §
93.15 shall be fined not more than $10.
   (G)   Whoever violates §
93.16 shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than $50 nor more than $100 for
each offense. Each day shall constitute a separate offense.
   (H)   Whoever violates §
93.20 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not less than $100
nor more than $500 for the first offense and from $500 to $1,000 for the second
and any subsequent offense.
   (I)   Whoever violates §
93.24 by failing to provide proof of rabies can result in a fine of not less
than $50 nor more than $100.
(Prior Code, § 93.24)
   (J)   Violations of §
93.25 shall be considered animal negligence and the owner shall be charged
fines and/or jail time to commensurate with the harm done to the animal. The
court may hold a nearing to remove the animal from possession of the owner (see
§
93.23). The owner has the right to appeal the ruling.
   (K)   Whoever violated §§
93.19(B),
93.21 through
93.23 and
93.26 shall upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than $25 not more than
$50.
(Prior Code, § 93.99) (Ord. FY 88-89, #12, passed - -; Ord. FY 87-88, #3,
passed 8-4-1987; Ord. 06-07, #3, passed 8-15-2006)
CHAPTER 94: PUBLIC ACCOMMODATIONS; FAIR EMPLOYMENT
Section
   
94.01   Definitions
   
94.02   Discrimination in public accommodations prohibited
   
94.03   Discrimination in employment prohibited
   
94.04   Human rights commission; function
   
94.05   Duty of city officers

94.99   Penalty
Cross-reference:
   Procedure for grievances relating to discrimination based on disability, see

§ 94.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   EMPLOYER. The City of Middlesboro and any person or business employing three
or more employees.
   PLACE OF PUBLIC ACCOMMODATIONS. Any establishment offering goods or services
to the general public.
(Prior Code, § 94.01)
§ 94.02 DISCRIMINATION IN PUBLIC ACCOMMODATIONS PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any place of public accommodation to discriminate
against any person on the grounds of race, color, religion, ancestry,
disability, or national origin.
(Prior Code, § 94.02) Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.03 DISCRIMINATION IN EMPLOYMENT PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any employer, employment agency, labor union, or
apprenticeship program to discriminate against, segregate, classify, or treat
differently any person because of his or her race, color, religion, ancestry,
disability, or national origin.
(Prior Code, § 94.03) Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.04 HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION; FUNCTION.
   The city’s Commission on Human Rights shall receive all complaints alleging
violation of this chapter. The Commission shall investigate all complaints and
shall endeavor to eliminate any unlawful practice by conference, conciliation,
and persuasion.
(Prior Code, § 94.04)
§ 94.05 DUTY OF CITY OFFICERS.
   All officers of the city shall, upon request, assist the Commission in
carrying out its duties under this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 94.05)
§ 94.06 PROSECUTION FOR VIOLATIONS.
   If the Commission cannot achieve voluntary compliance with this chapter, the
Commission shall certify the complaint to the city prosecutor for prosecution.
(Prior Code, § 94.06)
§ 94.99 PENALTY.
   Violation of this chapter shall be deemed a misdemeanor, punishable by a
fine of not less than $20 and not more than $100.
(Prior Code, § 94.99)
CHAPTER 95: NUMBERING OF BUILDINGS
Section
   
95.01   Numbering of houses on avenues
   
95.02   Numbering of houses on streets north of Cumberland Avenue
   
95.03   Numbering of houses on streets south of Cumberland Avenue
§ 95.01 NUMBERING OF HOUSES ON AVENUES.
   The houses on the avenues of the city shall be numbered beginning with the
number 101 for the northeast corners of all the avenues of the city, and their
intersection with first street running westward to the end of each of the
avenues, allowing one odd number for each 25 feet fronting on the north side,
and one even number for each 25 feet fronting on the south side of the avenues.
One hundred numbers shall be allowed to the length of each block fronting on
the avenues or streets.
(Prior Code, § 95.01)
§ 95.02 NUMBERING OF HOUSES ON STREETS NORTH OF CUMBERLAND AVENUE.
   The houses on the streets north of Cumberland Avenue of the city shall be
numbered, beginning with the number 101 for the northeast corners of all the
streets and their intersections of Cumberland Avenue, running north to the end
of each of the streets, allowing one odd number for each 25 feet fronting on
the west side, and one even number for each 25 feet fronting on the east side
of the avenues or streets.
(Prior Code, § 95.02)
§ 95.03 NUMBERING OF HOUSES ON STREETS SOUTH OF CUMBERLAND AVENUE.
   The houses on the streets south of Cumberland Avenue of the city shall be
numbered, beginning with the number 101 for the southwest corners of all the
streets and their intersections of Cumberland Avenue, running south to the end
of each of the streets, allowing one odd number for each 25 feet fronting on
the west side, and one even number for each 25 feet fronting on the east side
of each street; the 100 numbers being allotted to the length of each block.
(Prior Code, § 95.03)
CHAPTER 96: ABANDONED VEHICLES
Section
   
96.01   Definitions
   
96.02   Abandonment of vehicles

§ 96.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   PERSON. Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, or
organization of any kind.
   PROPERTY. Any real property within the corporate limits of the city which is
not a street, avenue, or highway.
   STREET or AVENUE. The entire width between the boundary lines of every way
publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for
purposes of vehicular travel.
   VEHICLE. A machine propelled by power other than human power designed to
travel along the ground by use of wheels, treads, runners, or slides, and
transport persons or property or pull machinery, and shall include without
limitation, automobile, truck, trailer, motorcycle, tractor, buggy, and wagon.
(Prior Code, § 96.01) (Minute book Y, page 226, passed 4-3-1973)
§ 96.02 ABANDONMENT OF VEHICLES.
   No person shall abandon any vehicle within the city and no person shall
leave any vehicle at any place within the city for such time and under such
circumstances as to cause the vehicle reasonably to appear to have been
abandoned.
(Prior Code, § 96.02) (Minute book Y, page 226, passed 4-3-1973)
§ 96.03 LEAVING OF WRECKED OR JUNKED VEHICLE ON STREET.
   No person shall leave any partially dismantled, nonoperating, wrecked, or
junked vehicle on any street, avenue, or highway within the city.
(Prior Code, § 96.03) (Minute book Y, page 226, passed 4-3-1973)
§ 96.04 DISPOSITION OF WRECKED OR DISCARDED VEHICLES.
   (A)   No person in charge or control of any property within the city,
whether as owner, tenant, occupant, lessee, or otherwise, shall allow any
partially dismantled, nonoperating, wrecked, junked, or discarded vehicle to
remain on the property longer than seven days. This chapter shall not apply to
a vehicle in an enclosed building, a vehicle on the premises of a business
enterprise operated in a lawful place and manner, when necessary to the
operation of such business enterprise, or a vehicle in an appropriate storage
place or depository maintained in a lawful place and manner by the city.
   (B)   Further, this chapter shall not apply to inoperable, dismantled,
junked vehicles in outdoor storage areas that are maintained in such a manner
that they do not constitute a health hazard and are screened from ordinary
public view by means of a screen, fence, suitable trees or shrubbery, or other
appropriate means, and the storage of which does not otherwise violate
applicable zoning or business regulations.
(Prior Code, § 96.04) (Minute book Y, page 226, passed 4-3-1973; Ord. FY 19-20,
#7, passed 11-26-2019)
§ 96.05 IMPOUNDING.
   The Mayor, a City Code Enforcement Officer, Chief of Police, or any member
or members of the Police Department designated by them are authorized to enter
private property and remove or have removed by an authorized designee any
vehicle left at any place within the city which reasonably appears to be in
violation of this chapter or lost, stolen, or unclaimed. This vehicle shall be
impounded until lawfully claimed or disposed of in accordance with KRS 376.275.
The city may, at its election, allow vehicles in violation of this chapter to
be impounded by authorized, private impoundment facilities, in which case, said
impoundment facility shall agree in writing with the city to comply with all
provisions of KRS 376.275 and thereby assume all legal responsibility and
liability for doing so.
(Prior Code, § 96.05) (Minute book Y, page 226, passed 4-3-1973; Ord. FY 19-20,
#7, passed 11-26-2019)
§ 96.06 NOTICE.
   Pursuant to KRS 376.275, within ten days of removal of the vehicle, the last
owner of record shall be attempted to be ascertained by inquiry to the Kentucky
Transportation Cabinet and the Bell County Court Clerk, and notice shall issue
to said owner of record in the name and address listed, notifying last owner of
record of the following: the location of where the vehicle was removed from;
where the vehicle has been impounded, including the make, model, license
number; and vehicle identification number (VIN) of the vehicle, and the
requirements for securing release and return of said vehicle. If said vehicle
is not claimed and fees, costs, and fines are not paid on the same, said
vehicle may be disposed of in accordance with KRS 376.275.
(Prior Code, § 96.06) (Ord. FY 19-20, #7, passed 11-26-2019)
§ 96.07 LIEN.
   (A)   Pursuant to KRS 376.275, and §§
32.217 and
91.02(E) the city shall have a lien against any vehicle for all accrued/
accruing fines and the cost of such work done in abating such nuisance, and may
charge the same against the owner of the property. It is hereby provided that
the general overhead of administrative expense of inspection, removal, locating
the owner, issuing a notice, re-inspection, legal fees, ordering work done,
storage fees, together with all necessary incidents of the same, shall be
compiled by a member of code enforcement office or a City Clerk, and a
certified statement of expenses shall be filed as a lien of record with the
County Clerk’s office.
   (B)   The lien shall be notice to all persons from the time of its recording
and shall bear interest at the rate of 12% per annum thereafter, until paid.
   (C)   The lien created shall take precedence over all other subsequent liens
except state, county, school board, and city taxes, and may be enforced by
judicial proceedings.
   (D)   In addition to this remedy or any other remedy authorized by law, the
owner of a vehicle or property upon which a lien has been attached pursuant to
this section shall also be personally liable for the amount of the lien,
including all interest, civil penalties, and other charges, and the city may
bring civil action against the owner and shall have the same remedies as
provided for the recovery of a debt owed. In any action to enforce this lien,
the responsible person or property owner shall also be liable for recording
fees, court costs, and reasonable attorney fees.
(Prior Code, § 96.07) (Ord. FY 19-20, #7, passed 11-26-2019)
§ 96.99 PENALTY.
   Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to the
fine assessment as provided for in §
32.216 of this code of ordinances, which fine shall continue in effect and
perpetually be assessed for each consecutive (month) said violation remains
unabated. Further, any violator is subject to the lien assessment as provided
for hereinabove under §
96.07.
(Prior Code, § 96.99) (Ord. FY 19-20, #7, passed 11-26-2019)
CHAPTER 97: AMUSEMENTS
Section
Parades
   
97.01   Regulating permits
Carnivals, Fairs, Circuses and Traveling Shows
   
97.15   Carnivals, fairs, circuses, and traveling shows
PARADES
§ 97.01 REGULATING PERMITS.
   (A)   No parade shall be conducted within the city unless the person, group,
organization, or other entity responsible for the same has first acquired a
permit for the activity from the city. Issuance of all permits shall have prior
approval of the Chief of Police and the Mayor. Any refusal to issue a requested
permit may be appealed to the Common Council within 30 days of the refusal.
   (B)   No permit shall issue for any unlawful activity or for any other
activity detrimental or contrary to the public welfare, public safety, or
public interest of the citizenry.
(Prior Code, § 97.01) (Minute book BB, page 157, passed 7-27-1976)
CARNIVALS, FAIRS, CIRCUSES, AND TRAVELING SHOWS
§ 97.15 CARNIVALS, FAIRS, CIRCUSES, AND TRAVELING SHOWS.
   (A)   Before any carnival, fair, circus or traveling show appears within the
city limits, the sponsors and/or organizations shall no less than 30 days prior
to said appearance inform the City Clerk of the dates and location of said
activity, who shall then bring the request before the Common Council for
consideration.
   (B)   The above requirement does not relieve any sponsor and/or organization
from obtaining any other permits or license or paying any other fees which have
been imposed by this code.
(Prior Code, § 98.01) (Ord. FY 01-02, #3, passed 9-18-2001)
Cross-reference:
   License fee, see §
110.09
CHAPTER 98: YARD SALES
Section
   
98.01   Definitions
   
98.02   Yard sales on commercial property prohibited
   
98.03   Yard sales on public property; permit
   
98.04   Yard sales on residential property
   
98.05   Signs
   
98.06   Highways, streets, and rights-of-way
 
   
98.99   Penalty
§ 98.01 DEFINITIONS.
   The following words and phrases are defined for their application to this
chapter only. For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   COMMERCIAL PROPERTY. A privately owned location, including buildings,
parking lots, and adjacent landscaped areas, where business, commercial, or
professional service activities occur. Includes vacant business locations and
empty lots along the city’s business corridor or downtown area.
   NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATION. Any organization having non-profit or charitable
status as defined by the Federal Internal Revenue Service. Examples include,
but are not limited to, churches, schools (or groups within a school), civic
organizations, health research foundations or associations, and organizations
supporting public or community improvement endeavors.
   PUBLIC PROPERTY. Property owned by a government entity, school, or other
publicly funded organization. Includes buildings, parking lots, and adjacent
landscaped areas. An example of this type of property would be the city
downtown parking lot.
   YARD SALE. The outdoor display and sale of tangible personal property,
either new or used, at a temporarily established point of sale such as a
garage, yard, carport, parking lot, or tent. These sales are also commonly
referred to as garage sales, rummage sales, flea markets, attic sales, and
other similar descriptive terms.
(Prior Code, § 99.01) (Ord. FY 14-15, #3, passed 3-2-2015)
§ 98.02 YARD SALES ON COMMERCIAL PROPERTY PROHIBITED.
   (A)   No yard sale shall be conducted on any commercial property within the
city by a private party or group. This prohibition applies to both occupied and
vacant properties. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent a
licensed business from offering outdoor displays of the goods or services for
which the business is licensed at the business location specified on the
license.
   (B)   A non-profit organization may conduct a yard sale on commercial
property with the consent of the property or business owner. The provisions of
§
98.03 apply to these sales, including the permit requirement.
(Prior Code, § 99.02) (Ord. FY 14-15, #3, passed 3-2-2015) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.03 YARD SALES ON PUBLIC PROPERTY; PERMIT.
   (A)   Yard sales are permitted on public property, as defined in §
98.01, within the city under the following conditions.
      (1)   The sale must be conducted by a non-profit organization as defined
in this chapter.
      (2)   All proceeds from the sale shall go to the organization to further
its goals, programs, or operational costs. None of the sale proceeds shall
inure to an individual except to cover expenses of conducting the sale.
   (B)   A non-profit organization intending to conduct such a sale must first
obtain a permit from the City Clerk.
      (1)   The City Clerk shall design and implement a permit form; there
shall be no fee for the permit.
      (2)   The permit shall be obtained prior to the event and specify the
organization conducting the sale, the location and duration of the sale, and a
contact person for the property to be used.
      (3)   If the public property to be used is city property, the Clerk shall
verify that the location is available before issuance of a permit and notify
the applicant within two business days.
      (4)   Once issued, a copy of the permit shall be transmitted to the
Police Department prior to the event.
   (C)   Nothing in this section is intended to regulate yard sales held by a
non-profit organization on its own property except that the provisions of §
98.05 (Signs) shall apply to all sales within the city.
(Prior Code, § 99.03) (Ord. FY 14-15, #3, passed 3-2-2015) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.04 YARD SALES ON RESIDENTIAL PROPERTY.
   The city does not regulate yard sales on residential property. However, the
provisions of §
98.05 (Signs) shall apply to all sales within the city, including those on
residential property. Nothing in this section shall prevent law enforcement
from addressing safety issues (e.g., parking, traffic) at a residential yard
sale.
(Prior Code, § 99.04) (Ord. FY 14-15, #3, passed 3-2-2015)
§ 98.05 SIGNS.
   (A)   No sign advertising a yard sale shall be displayed more than two days
prior to a sale. The person or organization exercising ownership or leasehold
rights over the property on which a yard sale is advertised to be held shall be
presumed to have placed the sign advertising the sale that identifies that
address or location. The organization identified as holding a sale on public
property shall likewise be presumed responsible for the placement of signs
advertising a sale. This presumption may be rebutted by evidence to the
contrary.
   (B)   Yard sale signs may be posted on private property with the express
permission of the property owner. Signs may be posted on city property, except
that they shall not be mounted or attached to any utility pole, street sign,
traffic sign, or other public device or structure unless the structure’s
specific purpose is to display advertising or announcements. At any location,
the sign must be securely staked or mounted.
   (C)   All signs relating to a yard sale must be removed, including all
stakes, staples, or other mounting devices, within 24 hours of the conclusion
of the sale. The same presumptions regarding responsibility listed in division
(A) of this section apply to removal.
(Prior Code, § 99.05) (Ord. FY 14-15, #3, passed 3-2-2015) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.06 HIGHWAYS, STREETS, AND RIGHTS-OF-WAY.
   No goods, produce, or other items, either second-hand or new, shall be
offered for sale on the right-of-way, shoulder, or sidewalk of any public
highway, street, or thoroughfare. This section shall not apply to a licensed
business offering its own products for sale in front of the licensed business
location.
(Prior Code, § 99.06) (Ord. FY 14-15, #3, passed 3-2-2015) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.99 PENALTY.
   Acts contrary to the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed a violation
and any person, organization, or corporation so convicted shall be fined not
less than $50 nor more than $100, in addition to any court costs. Each day the
violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate
offense and shall be punishable as such.
(Prior Code, § 99.99) (Ord. FY 14-15, #3, passed 3-2-2015)
CHAPTER 99: SMOKING IN PUBLIC PLACES
Section
   
99.01   Definitions
   
99.02   Smoking prohibited
   
99.03   Where smoking is not prohibited
   
99.04   Posting of signs
   
99.05   Duties of persons in control of public places
   
99.06   Prohibition of smoking in outdoor areas
   
99.07   Nonretaliation; nonwaiver of rights
   
99.08   Enforcement
 
   
99.99   Penalty
§ 99.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   DWELLING. Any place used as a primary residence; including, but not limited
to, private rooms in nursing homes (except private residences when used as a
childcare, adult daycare, or health care facility, which shall not be
considered a DWELLING for purpose of this chapter).
   PRIVATE ORGANIZATION. An establishment which maintains selective members, is
operated by the membership, does not provide food or lodging for pay to anyone
who is not a member or a members’ guest and has been granted an exemption from
the payment of federal income tax as a non-profit organization under 26 U.S.C.
§ 501.
   PUBLIC PLACE. An enclosed area to which the public is invited or any
building in which a portion is open to the public, including, but not limited
to, banks, educational facilities, gaming facilities, health care facilities,
hotels and motels, laundromats, public transportation vehicles and facilities,
reception areas, restaurants, retail food production and marketing
establishments, retail service establishments, retail stores, shopping malls,
sports arenas, theaters, convenience stores, gas stations, recreational areas
including parks and public pools and waiting rooms. A private residence is not
a PUBLIC PLACE unless it is used as a child care, adult daycare, or health care
facility.
   SMOKE or SMOKING. Inhaling, exhaling, burning, or carrying any lighted or
heated cigar, cigarette, or pipe or any other lighted or heated tobacco or
plant product intended for inhalation in any manner or in any form.
(Prior Code, § 100.01) (Ord. FY 14-15, #5, passed 5-19-2015)
§ 99.02 SMOKING PROHIBITED.
   Smoking shall be prohibited in all public places as those terms are defined
in §
99.01 above, including all city and county owned facilities and all places of
employment within the city.
(Prior Code, § 100.02) (Ord. FY 14-15, #5, passed 5-19-2015) Penalty, see §
99.99
§ 99.03 WHERE SMOKING IS NOT PROHIBITED.
   (A)   The prohibition set forth in §
99.02 above shall not apply to any of the following:
      (1)   In any dwelling; or
      (2)   A private organization except when the establishment is open to the
public.
   (B)   Nothing in this chapter shall authorize smoking in any place where it
is otherwise prohibited by statute, ordinance, regulation, or by order of the
Fire Marshal.
(Prior Code, § 100.03) (Ord. FY 14-15, #5, passed 5-19-2015)
§ 99.04 POSTING OF SIGNS.
   (A)   An owner, lessee, principal manager, or person in control of a public
place shall post signs, with letters of not less than one inch high or symbols
no less than three inches high, using the words “No Smoking” or the
international “No Smoking” symbol consisting of a pictorial representation of a
burning cigarette enclosed in a red circle with a red bar across it
conspicuously either on all public entrances or in a position clearly visible
on entry into the public place.
   (B)   The owner, operator, manager, or designee or employee of every public
place shall inform persons violating this chapter of the applicable provisions
thereof and require compliance.
   (C)   All ashtrays except for ashtrays displayed for sale and not for use on
the premises and including receptacles located outside the enclosed public
place used only for disposal shall be removed from any areas where smoking is
prohibited and shall not be permitted by the owner, operator, manager, or other
person having control of the public place. Any permanent structure that
functioned or was used as an ashtray shall be disabled or altered to prevent
its use as an ashtray.
   (D)   The requirements of this section do not apply to any areas where
smoking is not prohibited.
(Prior Code, § 100.04) (Ord. FY 14-15, #5, passed 5-19-2015)
§ 99.05 DUTIES OF PERSONS IN CONTROL OF PUBLIC PLACES.
   (A)   An owner, lessee, principal manager, or person in control of a public
place shall:
      (1)   Ask smokers to refrain from smoking in any non-smoking area; and
      (2)   Use any other legal means which may be appropriate to further the
intent of this chapter.
   (B)   An owner, principal manager, proprietor, or any other person in
control of the public place shall ensure compliance by subordinates, employees,
and agents with this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 100.05) (Ord. FY 14-15, #5, passed 5-19-2015) Penalty, see §
99.99
§ 99.06 PROHIBITION OF SMOKING IN OUTDOOR AREAS.
   Smoking is prohibited within 20 feet from the main outside entrance for the
public to any public place as to ensure that tobacco smoke does not enter the
public place or through entrances, windows, ventilation systems, or other
means.
(Prior Code, § 100.06) (Ord. FY 14-15, #5, passed 5-19-2015) Penalty, see §
99.99
§ 99.07 NONRETALIATION; NONWAIVER OF RIGHTS.
   (A)   No person or employer shall discharge, refuse to hire, or in any
manner retaliate against an employee, applicant for employment, or customer
because that employee, applicant, or customer exercises any rights afforded by
this chapter.
   (B)   An employee who works in a setting where an employer allows smoking
does not waive or otherwise surrender any legal rights the employee may have
against the employer or any other party.
(Prior Code, § 100.07) (Ord. FY 14-15, #5, passed 5-19-2015) Penalty, see §
99.99
§ 99.08 ENFORCEMENT.
   Enforcement of this chapter shall be by citation issued by any police
officer of the city. Notice of the provisions of this chapter shall be provided
by publication.
(Prior Code, § 100.08) (Ord. FY 14-15, #5, passed 5-19-2015)
§ 99.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   An owner, manager, proprietor, lessee, or other person in control of
the premises who violates any provision herein, including a person who smokes
in an area where smoking is prohibited, shall be subject to the following
penalties:
      (1)   A fine of $25 for the first offense;
      (2)   A fine of $100 for the second offense; and
      (3)   A fine of $250 for the third and each subsequent offense.
   (B)   Persons who smoke in an area where smoking is prohibited and who
refuse to extinguish their smoking material when asked, may be required to
leave the premises, and shall be subject to prosecution for trespass if they do
not leave when asked.
   (C)   If the person who violates any provisions of this chapter is the
owner, manager, proprietor, lessee, or other person in control of the premises,
the fines described in divisions (A)(1), (A)(2), and (A)(3) of this section
shall be doubled.
   (D)   Each citation shall constitute a separate and distinct offense.
(Prior Code, § 100.99) (Ord. FY 14-15, #5, passed 5-19-2015)
