§ 110.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ASSOCIATION. A partnership, limited partnership, joint venture, or any other
form of unincorporated enterprise, owned, or engaged in by two or more persons.
   BUSINESS. An enterprise, activity, or undertaking of any nature conducted
for gain or profit, or conducted by an individual, copartnership, association,
or any other entity. This shall not include the usual activities of boards of
trade, chambers of commerce, trade associations, or unions (or other
associations performing the services usually performed by trade associations or
unions); community chest funds or foundations, corporations, or associations,
organized and operated exclusively for religious, charitable, scientific,
literary, educational, or civic purposes, or for the prevention of cruelty to
children or animals; clubs or fraternal organizations operated exclusively for
social, literary, educational, or fraternal purposes where no part of the
earnings or income or receipts for such units, groups, or associations inures
to the benefit of any private shareholder or individual.
   BUSINESS RECEIPTS. The sum total of gross receipts from sales plus gross
credit or charges for work done and performed or services rendered.
   CITY. City of Middlesboro, Kentucky.
   CORPORATION. A corporation or joint stock association organized under the
laws of the United States, the State of Kentucky, or any other state,
territory, or foreign country or dependency.
   DIRECTOR OF FINANCE. A licensed certified public accountant appointed to the
position in the city by the Mayor and with the advice and consent of the Common
Council.
   EMPLOYEES. Any person engaging in or following any trade, occupation,
profession, or activity within the meaning of the definition for “occupations,
trades, professions, or other activities” in this section.
   EMPLOYER. Any individual, person, partnership, association, corporation,
governmental body, or unit or administration or agency, or any other entity,
who or that employs one or more persons on a salary, wage, commission, or other
compensation basis.
   FIDUCIARY. A person who holds in trust property, moneys, or properties, to
which another has a beneficial title or interest, or who receives and controls
income for another person or persons.
   LICENSEE. Any person required to file a return or to pay a license fee under
this chapter.
   NET PROFITS. The net income from the operation of a business or enterprise
after providing for all costs and expenses incurred in the conduct thereof.
This amount shall be the same for that business or enterprise as reported for
Kentucky income tax purposes for a given tax period after deducting all federal
taxes paid in that period.
   OCCUPATIONS, TRADES, PROFESSIONS, OR OTHER ACTIVITIES. The performing of any
kind of work, the rendering of any kind of personal service, or the holding of
any kind of position or job within the city, by any clerk, laborer, tradesman,
manager, official, or other employee. This includes any nonresident of the
city, who is employed by an employer as defined in this chapter, where the
relationship between the individual performing the services and the person for
whom such services are rendered is one of a legal relationship of employer and
employee, including also, a partner of a firm or an officer of a firm or
corporation if this partner of a corporation or officer thereof receives a
salary for his or her personal services rendered in the business of the firm or
corporation, and shall also include and mean the holding of any kind of office
or position, either by election or appointment by a federal, state, county, or
city officer or employee where the services of such official or employee are
rendered with the city.
   PAYROLLS. The total wages, salaries, and other personal service
compensation.
   PERSON. Any natural person, copartnership, fiduciary, association, or
corporation. Whenever the word PERSON is used in any clause prescribed in and
imposing a penalty in the nature of a fine or imprisonment, the word as applied
to a partnership or other forms of unincorporated enterprise shall mean the
partners or members thereof, and as applied to corporations, shall mean the
officers and directors thereof.
   SALARIES, WAGES, COMMISSIONS, AND OTHER COMPENSATION. The total gross amount
of all salaries, wages, commissions, bonuses, share of net partnership
receipts, or withdrawals, corporate dividends paid in lieu of salaries or
wages, and any and all other payments or other consideration which a person
receives or is entitled to, for any work done, or personal services rendered in
any trade, occupation, or profession, or any other activity, including all
deductions whether for tax, insurance, or other. The amount paid to traveling
salesmen or other workers as allowance or reimbursement for travel or other
expenses incurred in the business of the employer to the extent of excess of
such amounts over such expenses actually incurred and accounted for by the
employee to his or her employer are excluded from the foregoing definition.
   TREASURER. Treasurer of the City of Middlesboro, Kentucky.
(Prior Code, § 110.01) (Minute book AA, page 47, passed 12-13-1974; Minute book
AA, page 128, passed - -)
§ 110.02 LICENSE FEES; ON WHOM IMPOSED.
   (A)   There is levied and imposed an annual license fee upon all persons,
associations, corporations, or other activity in the city, for the privilege of
engaging in occupations, trades, professions, or other activities. This license
fee shall be measured by and be equal to 2.45% of the gross salaries, wages,
commissions, and other compensations earned by such persons for work done or
services performed or rendered in the city and the net profits of all
businesses, professions, or occupations from activities conducted in the city
on and after April 1, 2024.
   (B)   Where salaries, wages, commissions, and other compensations and net
profits are earned for work done or services performed or rendered, both within
and without the city, license fees shall be measured by that part of the
salaries, wages, commissions, and other compensations and net profits as is
earned as a result of work done or services rendered or performed in the city.
Such license fees shall be computed by obtaining the percentage which the
compensation or net profits for work performed or services rendered within the
city bears to the total compensation earned.
(Prior Code, § 110.02) (Minute book AA, page 47, passed 12-13-1974; Minute book
AA, page 128, passed - -; Ord. passed 12-19-2023)
§ 110.03 BUSINESS ENTITIES.
   (A)   In the case of a license fee payer being an individual, partnership,
association, corporation, fiduciary, or other entity engaged in the conduct,
operation, or prosecution of any business, profession, activity, or other
enterprise, and where the same consumes at least 20% of the activity time of
such license fee payer, there is imposed an annual license fee on the license
fee payer of 2% of the net profits of such business, profession, activity, or
other enterprise.
   (B)   A business entity within the meaning of §§
110.01 and
110.02 which has a branch or branches, office or offices, and/or store or
stores, warehouses, or other place or places in which the entity’s business is
transacted, located in the city shall be considered to be conducting,
operating, prosecuting, or carrying on a trade, business, profession,
enterprise, undertaking, or other activity to the full extent of the sum total
of all transactions originating or consummated in, by, or through the
Middlesboro branch, office, store, warehouse, or other place of business
including:
      (1)   Billings made on such transactions;
      (2)   Services rendered;
      (3)   Shipments made; or
      (4)   Goods, chattels, merchandise, and the like sold.
   (C)   The absence of a branch office, store, warehouse, or other permanent
place of business within the city shall not exempt or render non-licensable the
net profits of any trade, business, profession, or enterprise or other activity
on which a license fee is imposed by this chapter.
   (D)   In the case of partnership, association, or other unincorporated
business owned by one or more persons, the license fee, generally, shall be
upon the partnership, association, or business enterprise as an entity and not
ordinarily upon the partners or members thereof.
(Prior Code, § 110.03) (Minute book AA, page 47, passed 12-13-1974; Minute book
AA, page 128, passed - -; Minute book BB, page 35, passed 2-3-1976)
§ 110.04 RETURN AND PAYMENT OF TAX.
   (A)   Every person whose earnings or net profits are subject to the license
fee by this chapter, shall prepare and file a license fee return with the
Director of Finance within the time periods specified herein, outlining the
compensation received or net profits earned subject to the license fee with
computation of the amount of the fee owed to the city.
   (B)   For all license fee payers to whom the net profits basis for
determining the license fee applies, the following divisions shall be
applicable:
      (1)   For a license fee payer who derives all net profits from activities
outside the city, the license fee shall be computed on the basis of the license
fee payer’s average annual number of employees as follows:
 
Employees   Fee
0—25      $250
26—50     $350
51—100    $500
100 or more $750
 
      (2)   (a)   For a license fee payer who derives his or her net profits
from activities both within and without the city, the percentage of gross
receipts from activities within the city must be first computed and multiplied
times the total net profits of the license fee payer to arrive at the net
profits subject to the license fee hereunder. The license fee payer shall be
liable for the fee as computed under this division (B)(2)(a) or the fee listed
under the average annual employer table of division (B)(1) of this section,
whichever is greater.
         (b)   Any license fee payer under division (B)(2)(a) of this section,
shall file, together with his or her license fee return, a statement, certified
under penalties of perjury by both the license fee payer and the preparer of
his or her return, that the percentage applied hereunder is a true and accurate
reflection of the business records of the license fee payer.
      (3)   For a license fee payer who derives all net profits from activities
within the city, the license fee payer shall compute his or her net profit as
defined in § 1100.01, subject to a minimum license fee of $50.
      (4)   Where an employer has withheld the license fee from the entire
earnings of an employee, it shall not be necessary for such employee to file a
license fee return unless directed to do so by the Director of Finance.
   (C)   If the return is made for a fiscal year or for any period other than a
calendar year, the return shall be made within 135 days from the end of the
fiscal year or other period.
   (D)   The person making the return shall, at the time of filing, pay to the
Treasurer the amount of fee shown to be due by the return.
   (E)   Where any portion of the license fee otherwise due shall have been
deducted at the source and shall have been paid to the Treasurer by the person
making the deduction, a credit equal to the amount so paid shall be deducted
from the amount shown to be due and only the balance, if any, shall be due and
payable at the time of filing of the return.
   (F)   If a licensee shall terminate his or her business or employment for
which the license fee has not been withheld during the calendar year or fiscal
year, the proper return shall be filed and the tax paid within 135 days after
termination of the business or employment.
   (G)   Persons temporarily engaged in business, as defined herein, within the
city of temporarily performing services within the city, shall file a return
and pay the license fee upon the completion of the business or employment.
(Prior Code, § 110.04) (Minute book AA, page 47, passed 12-13-1974; Minute book
AA, page 128, passed - -)
§ 110.05 COLLECTION OF LICENSE FEE AT SOURCE.
   (A)   It is the duty of each employer (as defined in §
110.01) who employs one or more persons on a salary, wage, commission, or other
compensation basis, to deduct monthly or more often, at the time of the payment
of such compensation, the license fee on such salary, wage, bonus, incentive
payment, commission, or other compensation due by the employer to the employee.
The license fee shall be deducted by the employer from all compensation paid to
employees for activities in the city. However, the mere fact that the license
fee is not withheld will not relieve the employee of the responsibility of
filing a return and paying the fee on the compensation received. A nonresident
employer either maintaining an office, business address, or doing business or
who is otherwise subject to service of legal process is subject to the
withholding provisions of this section.
   (B)   Where an employee receives compensation for personal services rendered
or performed partly within and partly without the city, the withholding agent
shall deduct and withhold that portion of the compensation which is earned
within the city in accordance with the following rules of apportionment.
      (1)   If the licensee is a traveling salesman, agent, or other employee
whose compensation on the basis of commission depends directly on the volume of
business transacted by him or her, the deducting and withholding shall attach
to that portion of the entire compensation, which the volume of business
transacted by him or her within the city bears to the volume of business
transacted by him or her both within and without the city.
      (2)   The deducting and withholding of personal service compensation of
all other employees (including officers of corporations), shall attach to that
portion of the personal service compensation of such employee, which the total
number of working days employed within the city bears to the total number of
working days employed within and without the city.
      (3)   If it is impossible to apportion the earnings as provided above
because of the peculiar nature of the services of the employee, or group of
employees similarly or identically circumstanced, or of the unusual basis of
compensation, apportionment shall be made in accordance with the facts and the
fee deducted. The employer shall furnish the Director of Finance a detailed
statement of facts.
      (4)   The occasional entry into the city of an employee who performs the
duties for which he or she is employed entirely outside the city, but enters
the city for the purpose of reporting, receiving, instructing, or accounting
incidental to his or her duties outside the city, shall not be deemed to take
this employee out of the class of those rendering their service entirely
outside the city.
   (C)   An employer is required to withhold the license fee on the full amount
of any advances made to an employee on account of commissions where in excess
of commission earned.
   (D)   An employer required to withhold the license fee on compensation paid
to an employee may in determining the amount on which the fee is to be
withheld:
      (1)   Ignore any amount allowed and paid by the employer to the employee
for expenses necessarily and actually incurred by the employee in the actual
performance of his or her services; or
      (2)   Deduct any amount necessarily incurred and expended by the employee
in the actual performance of his or her services, for which expense he or she
is not to be or has not been reimbursed by the employer; provided, that in
either case, such expense must be recognized by the federal and state
authorities for payroll tax purposes and the federal authorities for income tax
purposes, and the employee shall furnish the employer before the deduction is
made, an itemized statement of the expenses claimed.
   (E)   Such employer shall, however, on or before January 31 of each year,
furnish the Director of Finance a list of employees in such form as the
employer may choose, setting forth the following information in respect to the
preceding calendar year:
      (1)   Name;
      (2)   Address; and
      (3)   Gross wages paid.
(Prior Code, § 110.05) (Minute book AA, page 47, passed 12-13-1974)
§ 110.06 RETURNS OF LICENSE FEE WITHHELD AND PAYMENT.
   (A)   The return and payment required to be made on account of deductions by
employers from salaries, wages, and other compensation of employees shall be
made quarterly for the quarterly periods ending March 31, June 30, September
30, and December 31 of each year.
   (B)   The employer (in addition to any return required to be filed with
respect to his or her own earnings or net profits) shall, on or before the last
day of the month following each quarterly period, make a return and pay to the
Treasurer the full amount of the license fee so deducted or withheld with
respect to compensation paid all of his or her employees subject to the license
fee under this chapter. No part of such tax so withheld and so reported may be
paid to the Treasurer in installments.
   (C)   The return required to be filed under this section shall be made on a
form furnished by or obtainable from the Treasurer.
   (D)   On or before January 31, unless a written request for extension is
made to, and granted by the Director of Finance in the form prescribed by him
or her, an information return shall be made showing all employees from whom
city license fee have been withheld, giving the name and address of each
employee, the total amount of compensation paid during the year, and the amount
of city license fees withheld from such employees.
   (E)   In deducting and withholding the license fee at source and in the
payment of any fee under this chapter, a fractional part of a cent shall be
disregarded unless it amounts to one-half or more, in which case it shall be
increased to $0.01.
(Prior Code, § 110.06) (Minute book AA, page 47, passed 12-13-1974)
§ 110.07 IMPOSITION OF LICENSE FEE; EMPLOYEES.
   (A)   Employees in general. The license fee is imposed on both residents and
nonresidents of the city at the rate of 2% of all salaries, wages, commissions,
and other compensations earned for work done or services performed or rendered
in the city.
   (B)   Subject to license fees. The following are subject to the license fee:
      (1)   Salaries, bonuses, or incentive payments received by an individual,
whether directly or through an agent and whether in cash or in property, for
services rendered:
         (a)   As an officer, agent, or employee, or both of a corporation
(including a corporation of the first or non-profit class), joint stock
association or joint stock company;
         (b)   As an officer, agent, or employee (as distinguished from a
partner or member) of a partnership, limited partnership, or any other form of
unincorporated enterprise owned by one or more persons;
         (c)   As an officer, agent, or employee (as distinguished from the
proprietor) of a business, trade, or profession, conducted by an individual
owner;
         (d)   As an officer, agent, or employee (whether elected or appointed,
enlisted or commissioned) of a governmental administration, agency, arm,
authority, board, body, branch, bureau, department, division, section, or unit
of the commonwealth, or any of the political subdivisions thereof, or those of
any other state or commonwealth;
         (e)   As an officer, agent, or employee (whether elected or appointed)
of a governmental administration, agency, arm, authority, board, body, branch,
bureau, department, division, section, or unit of the United States government
or of a corporation created and owned or controlled by the United States
government or any of its agencies, or those of any foreign country or
dependency except those enlisted or commissioned in the military service; or
         (f)   As an officer, agent, or employee of any other entity.
      (2)   Wages, bonuses, or incentive payments received by an individual,
whether directly or through an agent and whether in cash or in property for
services rendered:
         (a)   Whether based upon hourly, daily, weekly, semimonthly, monthly,
or annual unit of production of piece-work rates; and
         (b)   Whether paid by an individual, copartnership, association,
corporation (including a corporation of the first or non-profit class), a
governmental, administration, agency, arm, authority, board, body, branch,
bureau, department, division, section, or unit, or other entity.
      (3)   Commissions received by a taxpayer, whether directly or through an
agent and whether in case or in property, for services rendered regardless of
how computed or by whom paid. (If amounts received as a drawing account exceed
the commissions earned the tax is payable on the amounts received.) If such
commissions are included in the net earnings of a trade, business, or
profession regularly carried on by such individual, they shall not again be
separately taxed;
      (4)   (a)   Fees, unless such fees are properly included as part of the
net profits of trade, business, profession, or enterprise regularly carried on
by the individual; and
         (b)   Fees paid to a director or officer of a corporation are subject
to withholding under §
110.08 as in the case of any other employee.
      (5)   Other compensation which will be treated as subject to the license
fee:
         (a)   Tips received by waiters and others. Tips received are subject
to the license fee and will be reported in the same manner as earnings of an
independent contractor;
         (b)   Vacation and/or holiday benefits. Payments made to employees by
an employer as vacation wages are subject to the license fee; and
         (c)   Separation payments. Payments made to employees by an employer
at the time of a voluntary or involuntary separation (dismissal) of the
employee from the service of the employer, are to be regarded as subject to the
license fee.
      (6)   The following money receipts are not deemed to be “salaries, wages,
commissions and other compensations and net profits” within the meaning of this
chapter:
         (a)   Old age or retirement payments. Periodical payments, commonly
recognized as old age or retirement pensions, made to persons retired from
service after reaching a specified age or after a stated period of employment,
are not subject to the license fee;
         (b)   Disability, sickness, accident benefits, and unemployment
compensation. Payments made to employees by an employer under a disability,
sickness, and accident plan, are not subject to the license fee. Unemployment
compensation payments, by the commonwealth, or any other agency are not subject
to the license fee;
         (c)   Death benefits. Death benefits payable by an employer to the
beneficiary of an employee or to his or her estate, whether payable in a single
sum or otherwise, are not subject to the license fee;
         (d)   Benefits arising under the Workmen’s Compensation Act. Amounts
received by employees under the Workmen’s Compensation Act, being KRS 342.0011
et seq. as compensation for a disability sustained during the course of
employment, together with any amount of damages received by suit or agreement
on account of such disability, are not subject to the license fee.
      (7)   Applicability of the foregoing regulations to employees whose
compensation is not wholly subject. In the case of individuals whose
compensation is earned for services performed both within and without the city
and who receive subject payments as set forth in the foregoing rules and
regulations, they are subject to the license fee in the same proportion that
services performed within the city bear to their total employment time.
(Prior Code, § 110.07) (Minute book AA, page 47, passed 12-13-1974)
§ 110.08 SPECIFIC GROUPS OF EMPLOYEES.
   (A)   Musicians and entertainers. In the field of professional musicians
there has arisen a practice peculiar to the engagement of musicians exclusively
through so-called “contractors”. The practice which arose by prescription by
the American Federation of Musicians and local union regulations, enables the
purchaser of music to deal with only one of the number of musicians required
for a particular occasion.
      (1)   For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
         (a)   CONTRACTOR. This term means that individual musician through
whom the purchaser and the musician negotiates the contract of service and the
performance thereof. The CONTRACTOR may or may not perform actual musical
service under a contract which he or she has negotiated.
         (b)   NAME BANDS OR ORCHESTRAS. This term means one which is
identified or known by a name and which holds itself out to the public as a
permanent organization, and in addition thereto has either: a fixed personnel;
or the individual member musician has contracted for his or her services with
the leader or the owner of the band at a fixed salary by term or by individual
engagement and over whom the purchaser has no direct control.
         (3)   PURCHASER OF MUSIC. The person, partnership, organization, or
association for whom or which the musical services are to be performed or
furnished and who exercises an employer’s control over the conduct of the
musicians. For example: hotels, cafés, taprooms, restaurants, theaters, clubs,
radio stations, and radio sponsors.
      (2)   When a contract for the purchase of music has been executed between
a purchaser and a contractor, the musician shall be deemed to be the employee
of the purchaser, except in the case of name bands, in which event the
musicians shall be deemed to be employees of the leader or owner of the name
band.
      (3)   The purchaser, and in the case of a name band, the leader or owner
thereof, shall be the person responsible for withholding the license fee from
the wages paid to the musicians, and the remittal thereof to the Treasurer.
      (4)   Entertainers other than musicians. An entertainer other than a
musician is usually engaged by a purchaser through a booking agent. The booking
agent, once the contract of employment has been executed, does not exercise an
employer’s control over the entertainer.
      (5)   The owner of a club, café, taproom, theater, or any place which
furnishes entertainment to the public or to its patrons, shall be deemed the
person liable as an employer of entertainers. Such employer must deduct the
license fee from the compensation paid to the entertainer and remit the same to
the Treasurer.
   (B)   Insurance companies.
      (1)   There is hereby imposed on each insurance company a license fee for
the privilege of engaging in the business of insurance within the corporate
limits of the city for the calendar year 1985, and thereafter on a calendar
year basis.
      (2)   The license fee imposed upon each insurance company which issues
life insurance policies on the lives of persons residing within the corporate
limits of the city shall be 2% of the first year’s premiums actually collected
within each calendar quarter by reason of the issuance of such policies.
      (3)   The license fee imposed upon each insurance company which issues
any insurance policy which is not a life insurance policy shall be 3% of the
premiums actually collected within each calendar quarter by reason of the
issuance of such policies on risks located within the corporate limits of the
city on those classes of business which such company is authorized to transact,
less all premiums returned to policy holders; however, any license fee or tax
imposed upon premium receipts shall not include premiums received for insuring
employers against liability for personal injuries to their employees, or death
caused thereby, under the provisions of the Worker’s Compensation Act and shall
not include premiums received on policies of group health insurance provided
for state employees under KRS 18A.225(2).
      (4)   All license fees imposed by this division (B) shall be due no later
than 30 days after the end of each calendar quarter. License fees which are not
paid on or before the due date shall bear interest at the tax interest rate as
defined in KRS 131.010(6).
      (5)   Every insurance company subject to the license fees imposed by this
division (B) shall annually, by March 31, furnish the city with a written
breakdown of all collections in the preceding calendar year for the following
categories of insurance:
         (a)   Casualty;
         (b)   Automobile;
         (c)   Inland marine;
         (d)   Fire and allied perils;
         (e)   Health; and
         (f)   Life.
   (C)   Railroad and train service employees.
      (1)   For railroad employees who perform all of their work within the
limits of the city, the license fee shall be measured by the proportionate
share of their gross earnings representing service within the city.
      (2)   Where such employees serve both within and without the city, the
license fee shall be measured by the proportionate share of their gross
earnings representing service within the city.
      (3)   Where the work of such employees is preponderantly outside the
city, the employee shall not be deemed to be engaged in a service within the
city.
      (4)   Officers and supervisory personnel whose headquarters are in the
city and whose occupations regularly require part of the work to be done
outside the city, shall be allowed to prorate the compensation on which a
license is due, for that part of the work done within the city. There shall be
no proration of compensation for employees’ headquarters within the city where
travel is only incidentally connected with the occupation. Individual cases of
claimed exemption under this division (C)(4) shall be subject to review by the
Director of Finance.
      (5)   No license shall be due on compensation of railroad employees for
sick leave.
      (6)   The fact that any particular railroad employee affected by the
foregoing regulations may be engaged in interstate commerce, is not relevant in
determining the subjectability of compensation received by him or her.
   (D)   Motor freight and commercial transportation other than railroads.
Since the circumstances involved in the employment of such employees are
substantially analogous to those of railroad train and engine service
employees, the set of regulations applicable thereto shall apply to employees
in the aforesaid category.
   (E)   Federal, state, or municipal employees.
      (1)   Compensation received from the federal government for services
performed within any federal reservation situated within the geographical
limits of the city, title to which is in the federal government, is subject
income, even though exclusive jurisdiction thereof was granted to the federal
government by the commonwealth and the city.
      (2)   Compensation received from state, county, and municipal
governmental agencies is subject to the provisions of this chapter.
      (3)   Refund of tax withheld and paid covering activities outside the
city will be made to employees upon application on a form provided by the
Finance Director.
   (F)   Real estate salesmen; brokers.
      (1)   Real estate salesmen or brokers who are engaged in the business as
employees rather than as independent contractors are not required to file a
return for the commissions earned by them. The employer is required to deduct
the fee from the commissions earned and remit the same to the Treasurer.
      (2)   Real estate salesmen or brokers acting as independent contractors
are subject to a license fee on their net profits in accordance with the rules
and regulations as provided for herein.
   (G)   Tailors. Tailors who receive work to perform in their own shops for a
specified amount to be paid for each garment are independent contractors.
   (H)   Nurses.
      (1)   A registered nurse (except as provided below) is in the same status
as any other professional person and is required to file a return upon her net
profits. He or she may deduct the actual expenses incurred from the earning of
his or her fees. Deductible items are expenses recognized as deductions by the
Internal Revenue Service and Department of Revenue.
      (2)   A registered nurse regularly employed by a hospital, institution,
business entity, or individual is subject to the withholding provisions of this
chapter.
   (I)   Executives and directors. An officer or director of a corporation
performing service out of the city except for occasional visits to the city
office to examine correspondence is not subject to the license fee. Where an
organization meets in the city, and part of the work required as officer or
director of such organization is done by him or her in the city, his or her
compensation is subject in the ratio that those duties bear to his or her total
duties.
   (J)   Domestic servants. Domestic servants employed in private homes are not
subject to the provisions of this chapter.
   (K)   Miscellaneous.
      (1)   Where compensation is received (paid) in property, its fair market
value, at the time of receipt, shall be subject to a license fee and to
withholding (deduction of fee at source). Board and lodging and similar items
shall be included in earnings at their fair market value, where such board and
lodging is considered part of the compensation paid. However, the value
accepted for the purpose of the state and federal payroll taxes may be accepted
by the Director of Finance.
      (2)   In the case of employees who incur and pay expenses directly
connected with performance of their duties or services and for which no
reimbursement is made by the employer, the reasonable actual expenses incurred
and paid in earning the compensation may be deducted in computing the amount
subject to the license fee. To be allowed, however, such expenses must be
recognized as deductions by the federal and state authorities for payroll tax
purposes.
      (3)   Such items as personal, family, or living expenses, expenses
commuting to and from work, old age benefits taxes, deductions for group
insurance, or hospitalization pension plans are not deductible as expenses
directly connected with the performance of service.
(Prior Code, § 110.08) (Minute book AA, page 47, passed 12-13-1974; Ord. FY 84-
85, #6, passed 10-16-1984)
§ 110.09 REGULATORY LICENSE FEES.
   (A)   The legislative body of the city finds that the following occupations
are of such a nature as to require special regulation and supervision and
therefore the following minimum license fees are imposed on every person,
corporation, and association, engaged in the business, occupation, calling, or
profession, or using, holding, or exhibiting articles named below who shall pay
in advance to the city for each calendar year (or fraction thereof in the case
of a new business) the licensee fee or fees herein set forth, which payment
shall be a credit on the license fee as otherwise provided in this chapter.
However, where minimum fees are set forth in the following table for a period
less than one year, the same shall be considered as the minimum fee due for the
period set forth in the table and shall be paid in advance of engaging in the
activity.
   (B)   In the event that a licensee is engaged in more than one type of
activity in one business entity, the highest minimum license fee shall apply.
Under column head “Date Due”, in division (E) of this section the words,
“Before Showing” shall mean that the license fee per showing is due prior to
the date of each showing. Where the word “Yearly” appears under the column
head, the same shall mean that the minimum fee shall be due on or before May 1,
and shall be for the ensuing year ending April 30 and for a like period of time
for each succeeding year thereafter.
   (C)   In no event shall any minimum fee set forth under this section or
under division (D) of this section be reduced for the reason that the business
or activity covering same shall have been commenced subsequent to May 1, of the
tax year.
   (D)   Automobiles, trucks, or delivery wagons:
      (1)   For each truck or delivery wagon operated by a license fee payer
based in the city, there is imposed an annual license fee on each such vehicle
of $15 but subject to a maximum annual license fee of $50 per license fee
payer.
      (2)   For each business entity based outside the city and operating a
truck or delivery wagon to a delivery point within the city there is imposed an
annual license fee of $100 or $2 per day.
   (E)   Activities and due dates:
Activity Date Due
Activity                                           Date Due
Carnivals, regardless of local sponsorship         $200 per day before showing
Circuses, regardless of local ownership            $100 per day before showing
City directory, 12 free copies of city directory   $50
Dance halls, tax exempt to non-profit or fraternal $20 a dance
organizations
Fortune telling, clairvoyant, palmist yearly       $150 per day or $1,000
Door to door salesmen, whether itinerant or not,   $5 per day or $50 yearly
each salesman
Nurseryman, itinerant                              $25 yearly
Peddlers produce grown or produced in Bell County  Exempt
   General peddlers                             $5 per day or $25 yearly
   Ice cream or confection peddlers, each wagon $15 per year
   Poultry, itinerant dealers                   $25 per year
   Pawnbrokers                                  $350 per year
 
         (a)   Every person, firm, or corporation conducting or engaging in the
business of operating, renting, leasing, selling, distributing, or installing
any machine board, table, or device where same is operated by the insertion of
a coin, or any counter device where same is operated or otherwise used for
amusement or skill, except those used solely for the purpose of vending chewing
gum, peanuts, candy, cigarettes, or other merchandise and about which there is
no element of amusement or skill, shall pay a license fee. Licenses shall be
publicly displayed on each machine. The license fee per machine per year shall
be $10 per year.
         (b)   Pinhooker: the business of buying livestock on the streets from
farmers delivering same to stock market for purpose of resale. The fee shall be
$25 per year.
   (F)   For corporations, associations, clubs, or fraternal organizations
operated exclusively for social, literary, educational, or fraternal purposes
where no part of the earnings, income, or receipts for such units, groups, or
associations inures to the benefit of any private shareholder or individual,
the fee shall be $25 per year.
   (G)   Any companies and individuals working within the city for the purpose
of cutting, trimming, pruning or otherwise altering the physical appearance of
trees or who performs any type of construction work within city limits are
required to obtain a business license prior to initiating any job. The fee
levied and imposed for this business license is $5 per job initiated.
(Prior Code, § 110.09) (Minute book AA, page 47, passed 12-13-1974; Minute book
AA, page 128, passed - -; Ord. FY 93-94, #12, passed 5-17-1994; Ord. FY 08-09,
#6, passed 5-5-2009) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 110.10 PAYMENT OF LICENSE FEE; WITHHOLDING AND RETURN.
   (A)   Each employer who employs one or more persons within the city shall
deduct monthly, or more often, at the time of payment thereof, the license fee
due from each employee measured by the amount of salaries, wages, commissions,
or compensation due by the employer to the employee, and shall pay to the
Treasurer the amount of license fee so deducted. The payment required to be
made on account of deduction by employers shall be made quarterly, for the
quarterly periods ending March 31, June 30, September 30 and December 31, of
each year, on or before the last day of the month next following the quarter of
the deduction, to the Treasurer.
   (B)   The employer shall, annually during the month of January of each year,
make a return to the Director of Finance in which is set forth the name and
residence of each employee of the employer during the preceding calendar year,
giving the amount of salaries, wages, commissions, or other compensations
earned during such preceding year, by each employee. However, the failure or
omission of any employer to deduct such license fee in compliance with these
regulations with respect to making returns and payment thereof, as may be fixed
in this chapter or established by the Director of Finance.
   (C)   Each person subject to a license fee imposed by this chapter shall, on
or before May 15, following the close of each year, make and file with the
Director of Finance a return, in duplicate, on a form furnished by or obtained
from the Treasurer, setting forth the aggregate amount of salaries, wages,
commissions, and other compensations or net profits during the preceding year.
However, where the entire license due under this chapter has been withheld
under the provisions hereof, the Director of Finance may waive the filing of
the return by the licensee; provided, that where the fiscal year of the
business, profession, or other activity differs from the calendar year and the
licensee files federal income tax returns for such fiscal years, the license
tax shall be measured by the net profit of the fiscal year. In the case where
taxpayers have fiscal years ending June 30, and prior to December 31, such
taxpayers shall file their license tax reports on May 15, of the following year
and pay a license fee based upon the net profit for such fiscal year so ending.
Where the fiscal year ends after December 31, and prior to June 30, such
taxpayers shall file a tentative tax license return on May 15 of each year. For
those persons filing a tentative return a final return will be filed on May 15
after the ending of the fiscal year. Full credit can be taken for any amount
paid on the tentative return. It is the intent of this chapter that any license
fee paid hereunder during any calendar year is for the right to do business for
that calendar year.
   (D)   The Director of Finance shall have the authority to extend the filing
of the returns at his or her discretion. Such extension shall be upon the
written request of the licensee. However, any balance unpaid when payment is
due under the terms of this chapter shall bear interest at the rate of 7% per
annum until paid.
(Prior Code, § 110.10) (Minute book AA, page 47, passed 12-13-1974)
§ 110.11 DUTIES OF THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCE.
   (A)   Duties. The Director of Finance is required:
      (1)   To collect and receive the license fee imposed under this chapter;
      (2)   To keep an accurate record showing the amount received from each
license payer and withholding employer;
      (3)   To pay over on a monthly basis to the City Treasurer, the gross
fees collected hereunder; and
      (4)   To enforce all provisions of this chapter and any rules and
regulations pertaining thereto.
   (B)   Regulations; rulings.
      (1)   Under the powers given the Director of Finance, these regulations
are issued. Additional regulations and rulings will be issued from time to time
as circumstances may demand.
      (2)   These regulations, together with all amendments and supplements
thereto and all changes therein, will be on file with the Director of Finance
of the city, and will be open to public inspection. Copies thereof will, so far
as possible, be available to all license payers, employers, and their
representatives upon request.
   (C)   Request from state. For the purpose of verifying the accuracy of any
return based on net profits for a specified period, the Director of Finance is
authorized and empowered to request from the Kentucky Department of Revenue the
amount of net profit listed by a license fee payer on his or her Kentucky state
income tax return for the corresponding period.
   (D)   Corresponding net profit figures. Corresponding net profit figures on
both the Kentucky state income tax return and the city net profit return shall
be prima facie evidence that the license fee payer has filed an accurate
return.
   (E)   Net profit figures vary. In the event that the net profit figures on
the respective returns vary, or in the event of mathematical errors in the city
returns, the Director of Finance may assess the license fee payer for any
deficiencies deemed due and owing, notifying the license fee payer by certified
letter of the tax due. The license fee payer shall have the right, within 30
days of the receipt of the notice, to file a written protest with the Director
of Finance. Within 30 days of the filing of the protest, the license fee payer
shall file with the Director of Finance a written statement, certified under
penalties of perjury, outlining the findings to which the license fee payer
takes exception and the grounds upon which the license fee payer relies. The
Director of Finance, upon receipt of the license fee payer’s written statement,
shall grant a conference to the license fee payer. Proceedings at the
conference shall be informal. The license fee payer may present evidence by
affidavit, witnesses, or oral or written testimony or argument. Within 30 days
of the conference, the Director of Finance shall notify the license fee payer
by certified mail of his or her decision and the amount, if any, of his or her
final deficiency assessment. Within 30 days of the receipt of the original
deficiency assessment, or upon completion of the protest and conference
procedures, and receipt of the final deficiency assessment, the license fee
payer shall pay any deficiency. The license fee payer may at this point file a
suit for refund or credit in a court of competent jurisdiction.
   (F)   Limitations on assessment in collection. The Director of Finance is
governed by the same period of limitations on assessment in collection as the
Kentucky Department of Revenue.
   (G)   Application for refund. An employee application for refund of
occupational taxes hereunder shall not be maintained unless filed with the
Director of Finance within one year of the closing of the taxable year upon
which the refund is based.
(Prior Code, § 110.11) (Minute book AA, page 47, passed 12-13-1974; Minute book
AA, page 128, passed - -)
§ 110.12 EMPLOYERS MUST KEEP ACCURATE RECORDS OF WITHHOLDINGS.
   (A)   Employers are required to keep such records as will enable the
Director of Finance to ascertain that proper amounts have been withheld from
employee earnings and an employee has filed a true and accurate license fee
return, and to make the same available to the Director of Finance upon his or
her written request.
   (B)   If the Director of Finance ascertains that either a return or the
amount of withholdings is incorrect, he or she may assess the license fee payer
and collect any deficiency in accordance with the procedures outlined for net
profit license fee payers under §
110.11(C).
(Prior Code, § 110.12) (Minute book AA, page 47, passed 12-13-1974; Minute book
AA, page 128, passed - -)
§ 110.13 OVERPAYMENT OF LICENSE FEE; EMPLOYER REQUIRED TO PAY.
   (A)   Should it be disclosed, either as a result of an investigation by the
Director of Finance or through the medium of the filing of a claim or petition
for refund or credit, that an overpayment has been made, the city will refund
this overpayment.
   (B)   The employer will in every instance be required to pay the full
license fee which should have been withheld, even though he or she may fail to
withhold from the employee. If too much has been withheld, the excess shall be
refunded by the employer to the employee. While the withholding agent
(employer) will be expected to maintain complete records of such adjustments
with the employees, any such adjustment made during any month will not need to
be reflected in the withholding return or disclosed by schedules or statements
thereto attached. However, where adjustments are made between employer and
employee, disclosure shall be made in a statement supporting the annual
schedule or schedules filed pursuant to these regulations.
(Prior Code, § 110.13) (Minute book AA, page 47, passed 12-13-1974)
§ 110.14 CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION.
   Any information gained by the Treasurer, Director of Finance, or any other
official, agent, or employee of the city a result of any returns,
investigations, hearings, or verifications required or authorized by this
chapter shall be confidential, except in accordance with proper judicial order,
and any person or agent divulging such information shall, upon conviction, be
subject to a fine of not less than $500 or imprisonment not to exceed 12
months, or both, at the discretion of the court, and shall be dismissed from
employment by the city upon conviction. However, such person may disclose to
the Commissioner of Revenue of the State of Kentucky or its duly authorized
agent all such information and the right to inspect any of the books and
records of the city if the Commissioner of Revenue grants to the city the
reciprocal right to obtain information from the files and records of the
Department of Revenue of the state and maintains the privileged character of
the information so furnished to him or her.
(Prior Code, § 110.14) (Minute book AA, page 47, passed 12-13-1974; Minute book
AA, page 128, passed - -)
§ 110.15 INTEREST AND PENALTIES.
   All license fees imposed by this chapter remaining unpaid after they become
due shall bear interest, in addition to the amount of the unpaid fee, at the
rate of 7% per annum, and the license payers upon whom the taxes are imposed
shall be liable, in addition to the fee and interest, to a penalty of 10% of
the amount of such unpaid license fee.
(Prior Code, § 110.15) (Minute book AA, page 47, passed 12-13-1974; Minute book
AA, page 128, passed - -)
§ 110.16 UNLAWFUL IMPOSITION OF LICENSE.
   All moneys derived from license fees under the provisions of this chapter
shall be paid to the City Treasurer and placed to the credit of the General
Revenue Fund of the city and shall be used and expended in defraying current,
general, and incidental expenses of the city. It is the purpose of this chapter
to provide revenue for the General Fund and it is not the intention of the city
or of this chapter to impose and require an occupational license fee prohibited
by law.
(Prior Code, § 110.16) (Minute book AA, page 47, passed 12-13-1974)
§ 110.17 ADMINISTRATION.
   This chapter shall be administered by the Director of Finance under the
direction of the Common Council. The Director of Finance with the approval of
the Common Council shall have authority to issue and promulgate such
regulations as he or she may consider necessary for the administration of this
chapter, provided, that such regulations are not inconsistent with the
provisions of this chapter. No license shall be issued for any unlawful
activity, or for any business that the Director of Finance with approval of the
Mayor shall consider to be detrimental to the public welfare or contrary to the
public interest; but any such decision to refuse to issue a license may be
appealed to the Common Council.
(Prior Code, § 110.17) (Minute book AA, page 47, passed 12-13-1974)
§ 110.18 LICENSE MAY BE REVOKED.
   (A)   Any license issued under this chapter may, with notice to the holder
thereof, and a hearing as hereinafter provided, be revoked or suspended by the
Common Council:
      (1)   If, within 12 months prior to the date on which charges are filed,
there has been a conviction of any person for any action or activity occurring
in, on, or at the premises covered by the license in violation of any provision
of this chapter or any other ordinance of the city or of any statute of the
commonwealth against gambling, disorderly conduct, or any other offense, and a
judgment of conviction in the Police Court of the city, or in any other court
of competent jurisdiction, shall be conclusive evidence of such violation;
      (2)   If there shall occur in, on, or at the premises covered by the
license any condition which is a nuisance or obnoxious to the morals and
general welfare of the public;
      (3)   If any person is disorderly in, on, or at the premises covered by
the license and disturbs the good order of the community, or the license holder
suffers or permits any disorderly conduct in, on, or at the licensed premises;
or
      (4)   If the holder of the license shall misrepresent any material facts
as to the kind of business in his or her return, or any other fact necessary or
proper to determine the amount of license tax to be paid.
   (B)   When the Mayor has probable cause to believe that a license should be
revoked for any of the causes enumerated herein, it shall be his or her duty to
prefer charges against the holder of such license by filing a statement of the
charges against the holder of the license with the City Clerk; the charges
shall be in writing and each charge shall be clearly set out. Within three days
after the filing of the charges and of the time of the hearing thereof, the
statement of charges shall be mailed to the licensee at the address shown on
the license and a hearing before the Common Council shall be held within ten
days after the filing of the charges with the Council. The evidence shall be
transcribed and the action and decision of the Common Council on the charges
shall be reduced to writing and recorded in the minute book.
(Prior Code, § 110.18)
§ 110.19 ENFORCEMENT.
   It shall be the duty of the members of the Police Department of the city to
enforce the provisions of this chapter and a failure or neglect on the part of
any police officer to enforce these provisions shall be grounds for his or her
dismissal through proceedings before the Common Council of the city in
accordance with state statutes.
(Prior Code, § 110.19) (Minute book AA, page 47, passed 12-13-1974; Minute book
AA, page 128, passed - -)
§ 110.20 VIOLATION PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation, or association to
engage in, pursue, or carry on any business, trade, occupation, or profession
mentioned in the preceding sections of this chapter, without first obtaining a
license and paying the tax herein provided for.
(Prior Code, § 110.20) (Minute book AA, page 47, passed 12-13-1974; Minute book
AA, page 128, passed - -) Penalty, see
110.99
§ 110.21 EMPLOYER ANNUAL ESTIMATED LICENSE FEE.
   (A)   In lieu of the requirements of §§
110.02,
110.05 to
110.10, and
110.13, an employer may pay to the city an employer annual estimated license
fee. The fee, which is deemed an obligation of the employer, shall be paid to
the city on or prior to January l5 of each year and shall be calculated by
determining 2% of the estimated annual compensation, as defined in §
110.01, to be paid to its employees working within the city for that year. The
estimated compensation shall be determined by multiplying by four, the
compensation paid to all employees working within the city during the fourth
quarter of the prior calender year.
   (B)   On or prior to April l5 of the year following the year in which an
estimated license fee payment is made, the employer shall file a return
calculating 2% of the compensation actually paid to its employees working
within the city during the prior year. The return shall also show the
difference between the amount paid for the annual estimated fee and 2% of the
applicable employees compensation for that year. In the event 2% of the
applicable annual employee compensation shall be less than the amount paid for
the estimated fee, the employer shall not be entitled to a refund. Should 2% of
the applicable annual employee compensation exceed the estimated fee by 10% or
less, no additional payment shall be required by the employer. Should 2% of the
applicable annual employee compensation exceed the estimated fee by more than
10%, the employer shall include payment for any amount in excess of 10% with
its return.
   (C)   Any employer who has paid the employer annual estimated license fee in
a prior year and fails to pay it on or before January 15 of the next subsequent
year shall be sent a delinquent notice by the City Clerk notifying the employer
that unless it makes payment of the estimated fee in full within 30 days, it
shall be deemed to have waived its right to elect to pay the fee. Any employer
who receives the delinquent notice and fails to make payment within the 30 days
or any employer who has not paid the employer annual estimated license fee in
the prior year and fails to do so on or before January 15 of the current year
shall be deemed to have waived its right to elect to pay the fee and shall be
subject to all other applicable provisions of this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 110.21) (Minute book GG, page 178, passed 3-l-1983)
§ 110.99 PENALTY.
   Any person, firm, corporation, or association violating any of the
provisions of this chapter, where a different fine is not provided, shall be
fined not less than $1, nor more than $50 for each offense, and each day the
violation is continued shall constitute a separate offense.
(Prior Code, § 110.99)
CHAPTER 111: ADVERTISING
Section
   
111.01   Use of obscene material in advertising
 
   
111.99   Penalty
§ 111.01 USE OF OBSCENE MATERIAL IN ADVERTISING.
   (A)   For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
      ADVERTISING PURPOSES. Purposes of propagandizing in connection with the
commercial sale of a product or type of product, the commercial offering of a
service, or the commercial exhibition of an entertainment.
      DISPLAYS PUBLICLY. Exposing, placing, posting, exhibiting, or in any
fashion displaying in any location, whether public or private, an item in such
a manner that it may be readily seen by normal unaided vision viewing it from a
public thoroughfare, aisleway, depot, or vehicle.
      NUDITY. Uncovered, or less than opaquely covered, postpubertal human
genitals, pubic areas, or the covered human male genitals in a discernibly
turgid state.
      PUBLIC THOROUGHFARE, AISLEWAY, DEPOT, OR VEHICLE. Any street, highway,
park, depot, or transportation platform, or passageway in any business
establishment, or other similar place, whether indoors or out.
      SEXUAL CONDUCT. Human masturbation, sexual intercourse, or any touching
of the genitals, pubic areas, or buttocks of the human male or female, or the
breasts of the female, whether alone or between members of the same or opposite
sex or between humans and animals.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly:
      (1)   Display publicly or cause to be displayed publicly for advertising
purposes a picture, photograph, drawing, sculpture, or other visual
representation or image or a person or portion of the human body that depicts
nudity or sexual conduct; or
      (2)   Permit any display described in division (B)(1) of this section on
the premises owned, rented or operated by him or her.
(Prior Code, § 111.01) (Minute book BB, page 465, passed 2-21-1978) Penalty,
see §
111.99
§ 111.99 PENALTY.
   Any person who violates §
111.01 (B) shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than
$500 or imprisoned for not more than six months, or both.
(Prior Code, § 111.99) (Minute book BB, page 465, passed 2-21-1978)
CHAPTER 112: CONVENTION AND TOURIST ACTIVITY
Section
Transient Room Tax

TRANSIENT ROOM TAX
§ 112.01 ENACTMENT.
   (A)   A 3% room tax is hereby enacted on the rent for every occupancy of a
suite, room, or rooms, charged by all persons, companies, corporations, or
other like or similar persons, groups, or organizations doing business as motor
courts, motels, hotels, inns, or like or similar accommodations or businesses.
   (B)   Transient room taxes shall not apply to rooms, lodgings, or
accommodations supplied for a continuous period of 30 days or more to the same
individual.
(Prior Code, § 112.01) (Minute book HH, page 212, passed 12-6-1983; Minute book
OO, page 6, passed 7-15-1986)
§ 112.02 COLLECTION AND ENFORCEMENT.
   The collection and enforcement of this tax shall be carried out by the City
Clerk, or other designated agent of the city. The tax shall be due on the first
day of each month and shall be remitted by the City Clerk or designated agent
to the Treasurer of the Middlesboro/Bell County Tourist and Convention
Commission by the tenth day of each month. The City Clerk or designated agent
shall notify the Treasurer of the Middlesboro/Bell County Tourist and
Convention Commission and the appropriate legal office of the city each month
of any delinquent taxpayers, together with the amount of any arrearage
attributable thereto. The City Attorney is hereby authorized to institute any
legal action that may be necessary to enforce the provisions of this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 112.02) (Minute book HH, page 212, passed 12-6-1983; Minute book
OO, page 6, passed 7-15-1986; Ord. FY 90-91, #19, passed 4-16-1991)
§ 112.03 USE OF FUNDS, REMITTANCE.
   Pursuant to KRS 91A.390, all moneys collected under the provision of this
chapter must be remitted to the Middlesboro/Bell County Tourist and Convention
Commission for use in the attraction and promotion of tourist and convention
business.
(Prior Code, § 112.03) (Ord. FY 90-91, #19, passed 4-16-1991)
TOURIST AND CONVENTION COMMISSION
§ 112.15 CREATION; MEMBERSHIP.
   (A)   There is created the Middlesboro/Bell County Tourist and Convention
Commission as provided by KRS 91A.350.
   (B)   The Middlesboro/Bell County Tourist and Convention Commission shall be
composed of seven members to be appointed, jointly, by the Mayor of the City of
Middlesboro and the Bell County judge/executive in the following manner:
      (1)   Two Commissioners from a list submitted by the local city hotel and
motel association. In the absence of such an association, the Mayor and the
Bell County judge/executive shall contact all of the hotel and motel owners, or
their representatives, in the city and request that they submit a list of names
from which two Commission members shall be selected to represent the local city
hotels and motels;
      (2)   One Commissioner from a list submitted by the local county hotel
and motel association, provided that if only one local hotel and motel
association exists which covers both the city and county, then three
Commissioners shall be appointed from a list submitted by it. In the absence of
such an association, the Mayor and the Bell County Judge/Executive shall
contact the owners, or their representatives, of all of the hotels and motels
located in Bell County and request that they submit a list of names from which
one Commissioner shall be selected. As an alternative, the Mayor and the Bell
County Judge/Executive may make a request to all of the city and county hotels
and motels for a single list from which three Commissioners shall be appointed;
      (3)   One Commissioner from a list submitted by the local restaurant
association or associations. In the absence of such an association, the Mayor
and the Bell County judge/executive shall contact the owners, or their
representatives, of all of the restaurants located in Bell County and request
that they submit a list of names from which one Commissioner shall be selected;
      (4)   One Commissioner from a list submitted by the Bell County Chamber
of Commerce;
      (5)   One Commissioner by the Mayor of the city; and
      (6)   One Commissioner by the Bell County Judge/Executive.
   (C)   Vacancies shall be filled in the same manner in which the original
appointments are made.
   (D)   The Commissioners shall be appointed for terms of three years
provided, that in making the initial appointments, the Mayor and the Bell
County Judge/Executive shall appoint two Commissioners for a term of three
years, two Commissioners for a term of two years, and three Commissioners for a
term of one year.
   (E)   Commissioners shall serve without compensation, but shall be
reimbursed for reasonable expenses incurred in the performance of their
official duties. Commissioners shall be citizens of Bell County, Kentucky.
   (F)   A Commissioner may be removed from office, jointly, by the Mayor of
the city and by the Bell County Judge/Executive as provided by KRS 65.007.
Removals shall not require fiscal court approval.
   (G)   The Commission shall elect from its membership a Chairperson and a
Treasurer, and may employ such personnel as are necessary to effectively carry
out the purpose of KRS 91A.350 to 91A.390.
   (H)   The Commission may enter into such contracts as are necessary to
effectively carry out the purpose of KRS 91A.350 to 91A.390. Such contracts may
include, but shall not be limited to, the procurement of promotional services,
advertising services and other services and materials relating to the promotion
of tourist and convention business; provided, contracts of the type enumerated
shall be made only with persons, organizations, and firms with experience and
qualifications for providing promotional services and materials such as
advertising firms, chambers of commerce, publishers, and printers. Such
contracts shall be submitted to the legislative bodies of the city and Bell
County for their review and comment prior to the execution of such contracts.
   (I)   The books of the Commission shall be audited annually by an
independent auditor who shall make a report to the Commission, to the
organizations submitting names from which Commission members are selected, to
the Mayor of the city, and to the Bell County Judge/Executive.
   (J)   Any powers granted to tourist and convention Commissions by KRS
91A.350 to 91A.390 or subsequent statutes, which are not specifically
enumerated in this chapter, are hereby conveyed to the Middlesboro/Bell County
Tourist and Convention Commission, and such statutes are hereby incorporated
herein by reference and made a part hereof.
   (K)   Any obligations or agreements with federal, state or local
governmental agencies entered into by the Middlesboro Tourist and Convention
Commission shall be assumed by the Middlesboro/Bell County Tourist and
Convention Commission, subject to approval by the appropriate governmental
agencies.
   (L)   The Chairperson and Treasurer of the Middlesboro Tourist and
Convention Commission are hereby directed to satisfy any outstanding financial
obligations of that organization within 30 days of the enactment of this
chapter by the city and enactment of a companion chapter by the Bell County
Fiscal Court. At that time, the Chairperson and Treasurer of the Middlesboro
Tourist and Convention Commission shall relinquish all Commission records and
arrange for a transfer of any assets to the Middlesboro/Bell County Tourist and
Convention Commission.
(Prior Code, § 112.10) (Minute book HH, page 212, passed 12-6-1983; Minute book
OO, page 6, passed 7-15-1986; Ord. FY 90-91, #19, passed 4-16-1991)
§ 112.16 JOB DESCRIPTION.
   Job descriptions for any proposed employees of the Middlesboro/ Bell County
Tourist and Convention Commission shall be submitted to the legislative bodies
of the city and Bell County for their review and comment prior to the hiring of
the employee(s). No job description is to be required of Commission members.
(Prior Code, § 112.11) (Minute Book HH, page 212, passed 12-6-1983; Minute Book
OO, page 6, passed 7-15-1986; Ord. FY 90-91, #19, passed 4-16-1991)
CHAPTER 113: FINANCIAL INSTITUTION FRANCHISE AND LOCAL DEPOSIT TAX
Section
   
113.01   Imposition of tax
   
113.02   Tax rate
   
113.03   Lien imposed
   
113.04   Use of tax
 
   
113.99   Penalty
§ 113.01 IMPOSITION OF TAX.
   There is hereby imposed on all “financial institutions”, as defined in KRS
Chapter 136, located within the corporate limits of the city, for the 1996 tax
year and all subsequent years, a franchise tax at the rate of 0.025% on all
deposits, as defined in KRS Chapter 136, maintained by such financial
institutions.
(Prior Code, § 113.01) (Ord. FY 96-97, #2, passed 7-16-1996)
§ 113.02 TAX RATE.
   (A)   For transition purposes, the 1996 tax year will be treated differently
in terms of collection of taxes than for all subsequent years. For the 1996 tax
year, the following timetable is hereby established. The city will issue tax
bills to financial institutions no later than May 1, 1997. Payment of the tax
shall be due with a 2% discount by May 31, 1997, or without the discount by
June 30, 1997.
   (B)   For all tax years subsequent to the 1996 tax year, the following
timetable is hereby established. The city will issue tax bills to financial
institutions no later than December 1 of each year. Payment of the tax shall be
due with a 2% discount by December 31 of each year, or without the discount by
January 31 of each year.
(Prior Code, § 113.02) (Ord. FY 96-97, #2, passed 7-16-1996)
§ 113.03 LIEN IMPOSED.
   The city shall have a lien for taxes upon any and all property subject to
the tax imposed by these sections, which lien shall be superior to all
encumbrances prior or subsequent.
(Prior Code, § 113.03) (Ord. FY 96-97, #2, passed 7-16-1996)
§ 113.04 USE OF TAX.
   All moneys collected pursuant to these sections shall be paid into the
General Fund of the city to be used for the payment of proper expenditures as
determined by the City Council.
(Prior Code, § 113.04) (Ord. FY 96-97, #2, passed 7-16-1996)
§ 113.99 PENALTY.
   All taxes due in accordance with these sections which are not paid before
June 30, 1997, for tax year 1996, or which are not paid before January 31, for
all subsequent years tax years shall be deemed delinquent and shall be subject
to a penalty of 10% and shall bear interest at the rate of 1% per annum.
(Prior Code, § 113.99) (Ord. FY 96-97, #2, passed 7-16-1996)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 114.001 TITLE.
   This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the “Alcoholic Beverage
Chapter of the City of Middlesboro” (“city”).
(Prior Code, § 114.001) (Ord. FY 15-16, #4, passed 1-19-2016; Ord. FY 20-21,
#2, passed 8-18-2020)
§ 114.002 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to establish uniform regulations and
requirements for the licensing and regulation of alcoholic beverage manufacture
and sales pursuant to authorization of KRS Chapters 241 through 244.
(Prior Code, § 114.002) (Ord. FY 20-21, #2, passed 8-18-2020)
§ 114.003 DEFINITIONS.
   The definitions of the words used throughout this chapter, unless the
context requires otherwise, shall have the same meaning as those set out in the
Kentucky Alcoholic Beverage Control Law (KRS Chapters 241 through 244) of the
commonwealth and all amendments and supplements thereto.
(Prior Code, § 114.003) (Ord. FY 15-16, #4, passed 1-19-2016; Ord. FY 20-21,
#2, passed 8-18-2020)
§ 114.004 SCOPE.
   This chapter shall be construed to apply to the manufacture and traffic in
both malt beverages and distilled spirits and wine where the context permits
such application. Nothing in the ordinance from which this chapter is derived
shall excuse or relieve the licensee, or the owner, proprietor, employee,
agent, or person in charge of any licensed premises where alcoholic beverages
are sold from the restrictions, requirements, and penalties of any other
ordinance or ordinances of the city or of any statutes of the state relating to
violations pertaining to alcoholic beverages.
(Prior Code, § 114.004) (Ord. FY 20-21, #2, passed 8-18-2021)
§ 114.005 PROVISIONS ADOPTED.
   The provisions of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law of the commonwealth
(KRS Chapters 241 through 244) and all amendments and supplements thereto, are
adopted so far as applicable to this chapter except as otherwise lawfully
provided herein.
(Prior Code, § 114.005) (Ord. FY 20-21, #2, passed 8-18-2021)
LICENSES; REGULATORY LICENSE FEE; EXPIRATION OF LICENSE
§ 114.020 GENERAL.
   For the privilege of causing, permitting, and engaging in the actions,
business, and transactions authorized thereby in regard to traffic in alcoholic
beverages in the city and pursuant to the authority of KRS 243.070, there is
hereby established a corresponding city regulatory license fee for each of the
state licenses described in KRS 243.070. The fee for each city license shall be
as set out in the following schedule. In the event KRS 243.070 shall hereafter
be amended to authorize additional city licenses, the regulatory fee for each
city license shall be the maximum fee provided in the statute as amended.
   (A)   Distilled spirits and wine license fees. The following distilled
spirits and wine regulatory license fees may be issued by the city, the fees
for which shall be:
      (1)   Distiller’s license, per annum: $250;
      (2)   Rectifier’s license, per annum: $1,500;
      (3)   Wholesaler’s distilled spirits and wine license, per annum: $3,000;
      (4)   Quota retail package license, per annum: $600;
      (5)   Special temporary license, per event: $10;
      (6)   Nonquota type 1 retail drink license (includes distilled spirits,
wine, and malt beverages): $2,000;
      (7)   Nonquota type 2 retail drink license (includes distilled spirits,
wine, and malt beverages), per annum (restaurant drink license): $800;
      (8)   Distilled spirits and wine temporary auction, per event: $200;
      (9)   Nonquota type 3 retail drink license (includes distilled spirits,
wine, and malt beverages): $300;
      (10)   Special Sunday sale retail drink license, per annum: $300; and
      (11)   Bottling house or bottling house storage license, per annum: $500.
   (B)   Malt beverage license fees. The following kinds of malt beverage
regulatory license fees may be issued by the city, the fees for which shall be:
      (1)   Brewer’s license, per annum: $500;
      (2)   Microbrewery license, per annum: $500;
      (3)   Malt beverage distributor’s license, per annum: $400;
      (4)   Nonquota retailer malt beverage package license, per annum: $200;
      (5)   Nonquota type 4 retail malt beverage drink license, per annum:
$200;
      (6)   Malt beverage brew-on premises license, per annum: $100; and
      (7)   The holder of a nonquota retail malt beverage license may obtain a
nonquota type 4 malt beverage drink license for a fee of $50. The holder of a
nonquota type 4 malt beverage drink license may obtain a nonquota retail malt
beverage package license for a fee of $50.
   (C)   Restaurant drink license.
      (1)   The City Council hereby determines, acknowledges and declares that
an economic hardship exists within the city; that the sale of alcoholic
beverages by the drink could aid economic growth; and, that there is a need for
restaurant drink licenses to be issued pursuant to KRS 242.1244;
      (2)   A retail drink licensee must be a bona fide restaurant open to the
general public having dining facilities for not less than 50 persons; or, a
hotel, motel, or inn containing not less than 50 sleeping units and having
dining facilities for not less than 50 persons; and
      (3)   The gross receipts of the restaurant or the dining facility from
the sale of food for consumption on the premises is reasonably estimated to be
not less than 50% of the total food and beverage receipts of such restaurant or
dining facility for the license period.
   (D)   Other license fees. The following kinds of other regulatory license
fees may be issued by the city, the fees for which shall be:
      (1)   Caterer’s license, per annum: $800; and
      (2)   Limited restaurant license or limited golf course license, per
annum (includes distilled spirits, wine, and malt beverages): $700.
(Prior Code, § 114.015) (Ord. FY 20-21, #2, passed 8-18-2020; Ord. FY 23-24,
#091923ABC, passed 10-17-2023)
§ 114.021 QUOTA RETAIL DRINK LICENSE PROHIBITED.
   Pursuant to KRS 243.230, the legislative body of the city hereby prohibits
the issuance of any quota retail drink licenses.
(Prior Code, § 114.016) (Ord. FY 20-21, #2, passed 8-18-2020)
§ 114.022 CERTAIN SPECIAL LICENSES DEFINED.
   (A)   Special temporary licenses. A special temporary license for a
qualifying event may be issued only as set out in KRS 243.260. This license
shall authorize the licensee to exercise the privileges of a quota retail drink
licensee and an NQ4 retail malt beverage drink licensee at designated premises
for a specified and limited time, not to exceed 30 days, and shall expire when
the qualifying event ends. All restrictions and prohibitions applying to a
distilled spirits and wine quota retail drink license or an NQ4 retail malt
beverage drink license shall apply also to a special temporary license. In the
case of a non-profit organization holding an NQ4 retail malt beverage license,
such organization may be issued a special temporary license to sell distilled
spirits and wine by the drink on the licensed premises, in conjunction with any
public or private event, for a specified and limited time, not to exceed ten
days.
   (B)   Special license required for Sunday sales. No retail drink license
shall offer alcoholic beverages for sale on Sunday unless the licensee shall
have obtained a special license for Sunday sales.
(Prior Code, § 114.017) (Ord. FY 20-21, #2, passed 8-18-2020)
§ 114.023 EXPIRATION OF LICENSE; PRORATION OF FEES.
   All city licenses, except temporary licenses, shall begin on April 30 of any
year and shall expire on April 29 of the following year. Any licenses issued
after October 31 of any year shall be assessed a fee which is based on the pro
rata portion of the remainder of the license period; however, the cost of any
license shall not be less than one-half the amount of the full fee for an
annual license of that type.
(Prior Code, § 114.018) (Ord. FY 20-21, #2, passed 8-18-2021)
§ 114.024 PAYMENT OF LICENSE FEES; DELINQUENCY.
   No licensee shall enter into or begin operating any business for which a
license is required by this chapter until the license fee has been paid in
full. The fee for renewal of any license shall be paid with the renewal
application. Failure to pay any license fee within ten days after it becomes
due shall result in a penalty equal to 10% of the license fee. Any licensee
failing to pay the fees, including penalties, within ten days after such fees
are due may be subject to revocation of the license and to other penalties as
provided in this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 114.019) (Ord. FY 20-21, #2, passed 8-18-2020)
§ 114.025 REFUND OF FEES.
   (A)   Should any licensee under this chapter be prohibited from conducting
the licensed business for the full period covered by the license because of any
changes that may hereafter be made in the laws of the commonwealth with
reference to alcoholic beverages or other causes outside licensee’s control,
then the city shall refund to the licensee the proportionate part of the
license fee for the period during which the licensee is prevented from carrying
on business if the licensee provided sufficient proof to the Administrator that
such period of inactivity was not the fault of the licensee or the result of a
revocation, suspension, or other wrongdoing by licensee, or an agent or
employee of the licensee.
   (B)   In the event a violation of this chapter occurs that results in the
suspension or revocation of the license, the city shall not be required to
refund any portion of the license fee.
(Prior Code, § 114.020) (Ord. FY 20-21, #2, passed 8-18-2020)
§ 114.026 REGULATORY LICENSE FEE.
   (A)   Pursuant to KRS 242.1244 and 243.075, there is hereby imposed a
regulatory license fee on the gross receipts of sale of alcoholic beverages of
