§ 151.01 ADOPTION OF HOUSING CODE.
   The 1966 State Suggested Housing and Unsafe Building Code, and all
amendments thereto, with the exception of paragraph 107, page 6, now on file in
the City Clerk’s office, is adopted and incorporated by reference, and made a
part of this code as though fully set out herein.
(Prior Code, § 151.01)
§ 151.02 SCOPE AND APPLICATION.
   (A)   Every building situated within the city and used in whole or in part
as a dwelling unit, or as two or more units, as a residence of any nature
whatsoever, or as a place of business in which any persons work or enter for
any purpose whatsoever, shall conform to the requirements of this code or of
the State Building Code as promulgated in Title 815 KAR Chapter 7 by the
state’s Board of Housing, Buildings, and Construction, as appropriate,
irrespective of the class to which the buildings may otherwise belong and
irrespective of when the buildings may have been constructed, altered, or
repaired.
   (B)   No person shall occupy as owner-occupant or let or sublet to another
for occupancy any dwelling or dwelling unit designed or intended to be used for
the purpose of living, sleeping, cooking, or eating therein, or any other
residential building, or use any building for commercial purposes in which
persons work or members of general public enter, nor shall any vacant dwelling
building be permitted to exist which does not comply with the requirements of
this chapter of the city’s code of ordinances or of the State Building Code as
promulgated in Title 815 KAR Chapter 7 by the state’s Board of Housing,
Buildings, and Construction, as appropriate.
   (C)   All buildings or structures within the city which are found to be
dangerous or injurious to the health or safety of the occupants of such
structures, the occupants of neighboring structures, or other residents of the
city shall be deemed unfit and unsafe for human habitation, occupancy, or use.
   (D)   Fitness for human habitation, occupancy, or use shall be determined in
accordance with the criteria established in this chapter of the city’s code of
ordinances, or in the State Building Code as promulgated in 815 KAR 7:120 by
the state’s Board of Housing, Buildings, and Construction, as appropriate, and
any building or structure which fails to meet such criteria or has any defects
set forth therein shall be deemed unfit for human habitation, occupancy, or
use.
(Prior Code, § 151.02) (Ord. FY 88-89, #18, passed 4-18-1989; Ord. FY 90-91,
#1, passed 7-31-1990)
§ 151.03 DEFINITIONS.
   (A)   Generally. For the purpose of this chapter the following words and
phrases shall have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively.
      APPROVED. Constructed, installed, and maintained in accordance with the
provisions of this code and other pertinent ordinances of the city and with
rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereof.
      BASEMENT. A portion of a building located partly underground, but having
less than half its clear floor-to-ceiling height below the average grade of the
adjoining ground.
      BOARD OF HOUSING APPEALS. The Board established by §
151.20 of this code.
      CELLAR. A portion of a building located partly or wholly underground, and
having half or more than half of its clear floor-to-ceiling height below the
average grade of the adjoining ground.
      DWELLING. Any building or structure, or part thereof, used and occupied
for human habitation or intended to be so used, and includes any outhouses and
appurtenances belonging thereto and enjoyed therewith.
      DWELLING UNIT. Any room or group of rooms located within a dwelling and
forming a single habitable unit with facilities which are used for living,
sleeping, cooking, and eating.
      EXTERMINATION. The control and elimination of insects, rodents, or other
pests by eliminating their harborage places; by removing or making inaccessible
materials that may serve as food; by poisoning, spraying, fumigating, trapping,
or by any other recognized and legal pest elimination methods approved by the
Inspector. (See INSPECTOR.)
      GARBAGE. The animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling,
preparation, cooking, and consumption of food.
      HABITABLE ROOM. A room or enclosed floor space used or intended to be
used for living, sleeping, cooking, or eating purposes, excluding bathrooms,
water closet compartments, laundries, pantries, foyers, communicating
corridors, closets, or storage spaces.
      HOUSEHOLD. All persons who occupy a dwelling unit. (A person living alone
or any group of persons sharing a dwelling unit is a HOUSEHOLD.)
      INFESTATION. The presence, within or around a dwelling, of any insects,
rodents, or other pests.
      INSPECTOR. The City Building Inspector.
      MULTIPLE DWELLING. Any dwelling containing more than two dwelling units.
      OCCUPANT. Any person, over one year of age, living, sleeping, cooking, or
eating in or having actual possession of, a dwelling unit or rooming unit.
      ORDINARY MINIMUM WINTER CONDITIONS. A temperature of 0°F.
      OWNER. A holder of any legal or equitable estate in the premises, whether
alone or jointly with others, and whether in possession or not.
      PARTIES IN INTEREST. All individuals, associations, partnerships,
corporations, and others who have interest in a dwelling and any who are in
possession or control thereof; as agent of the owner, as executor, executrix,
administrator, administratrix, trustee, or guardian of the estate of the owner.
Any person thus representing the owner or owners shall be bound to comply with
the provisions of this chapter and of the rules and regulations adopted
pursuant thereto, to the same extent as if he or she were the owner, and upon
failure to comply therewith shall be subject to the same penalties hereinafter
set out in §
151.99.
      PLUMBING. All of the following supplied facilities and equipment: gas
pipes; gas burning equipment; water closets; sinks; installed dishwashers;
lavatories; bathtubs; shower baths; installed clothes-washing machines; catch
basins; drains, vents; and any other similar supplied fixtures, together with
all connections to water, sewer, or gas lines.
      PREMISES. A platted lot or part thereof or unplatted lot or parcel of
land or plot of land, either occupied or unoccupied by any dwelling or non-
dwelling structure.
      PUBLIC HALL. Any hall, corridor, or passageway not within the exclusive
control of one family.
      ROOMING HOUSE. Any dwelling or that part of any dwelling containing one
or more rooming units, in which space is let by the occupant to three or more
persons who are not husband or wife, son or daughter, mother or father, sister
or brother of the occupant.
      ROOMING UNIT. Any room or group of rooms forming a single habitable unit
used or intended to be used for living and sleeping but not cooking or eating
purposes.
      RUBBISH. All waste materials, except garbage. The term shall include the
residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke, and other combustible material,
paper, rags, cartons, boxes, wood, excelsior, rubber, leather, tree branches,
yard trimmings, tin cans, metals, mineral matter, glass, crockery, and dust.
      SINGLE UNIT DWELLING. A dwelling occupied by one family alone.
      SUPPLIED. Paid for, furnished, or provided by, or under the control of,
the owner or operator, their agents, or representative.
      WATER CLOSET. A toilet, with a bowl and trap made in one piece, which is
connected to the city water and sewer system or other approved water supply and
sewer system.
      WORKMANLIKE STATE OF MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR. In such a state as to comply
with all codes and ordinances pertaining to construction of buildings and
installation of utilities.
   (B)   Meaning of certain words. Whenever the words DWELLING, ROOMING HOUSE,
ROOMING UNIT, and PREMISES are used in this chapter, they shall be construed as
though they were followed by the words “or any part thereof”.
(Prior Code, § 151.03) (Ord. FY 88-89, #18, passed 4-18-1989)
§ 151.04 MINIMUM STANDARDS FOR LIGHTING.
   (A)   Where there is electric service available from power lines which are
not more than 300 feet away from a dwelling, every habitable room in the
dwelling shall contain at least two separate wall type electric outlets, or one
outlet and one supplied ceiling type electric light fixture. Every bathroom,
laundry room, furnace room, and public hall shall contain at least one ceiling
or wall type electric light fixture. Every outlet and fixture shall be in
working condition and installed in accordance with the requirements of the
National Electric Code.
   (B)   Every habitable room shall have at least one window or skylight facing
directly to the outside or other means of lighting which is approved as
adequate by the Inspector. The minimum total
   (C)   Every public hall and stairway in every multiple dwelling containing
five or more dwelling units shall be adequately lighted at all times. Every
public hall and stairway in a structure containing not more than four dwelling
units may be supplied with conveniently located light switches controlling an
adequate lighting system which may be turned on when needed instead of full-
time lighting.
   (D)   Bathrooms shall conform to the lighting requirements for habitable
rooms.
(Prior Code, § 151.04)
§ 151.05 MINIMUM STANDARDS FOR VENTILATION.
   (A)   Every habitable room shall have at least one window or skylight
opening directly to the outdoors which can easily be opened, or such other
device as will adequately ventilate a room. The minimum total openable window
area in every habitable room shall be equal to one-half of the minimum total
window area required in §
151.04(B) except where there is supplied some other device affording adequate
ventilation and approved by the Inspector.
   (B)   Every bathroom shall have ventilation equal to four square feet or
such other device as will adequately ventilate the room and which is approved
by the Inspector.
(Prior Code, § 151.05)
§ 151.06 MINIMUM STANDARDS FOR HEATING.
   (A)   Every dwelling shall have heating facilities which are properly
installed, are maintained in safe and good working condition, and are capable
of safely and adequately heating all habitable rooms and bathrooms in every
dwelling unit located therein to a temperature of at least 70°F at a distance
of three feet above floor level, when the outside temperature is 0°F.
   (B)   All gas burning room heaters shall be vented to the outside air by a
smoke-pipe or flue. Rubber tube or armored rubber tube connections on all gas
heating fixtures are prohibited.
(Prior Code, § 151.06)
§ 151.07 MINIMUM STANDARDS FOR BASIC EQUIPMENT AND FACILITIES.
   (A)   Water supply. There shall be a portable supply of running water piped
into each dwelling unit.
   (B)   Sewerage. In every dwelling plumbing fixtures shall be properly
installed and connected to the water supply and sewer systems and maintained in
good working order.
   (C)   Sanitary equipment. Every dwelling unit shall contain a sink, tub, or
shower, lavatory, and water closet.
   (D)   Sink. Every dwelling unit shall contain a kitchen sink therein,
properly connected to the water supply and sewer system.
   (E)   Tub or shower and lavatory. Every dwelling unit shall contain therein,
in a room affording privacy, a tub or shower and a lavatory, properly connected
to the water supply and sewer systems. This tub or shower and lavatory may be
shared by two dwelling units if:
      (1)   The habitable area of each of the dwelling units shall equal not
more than 250 square feet of floor area;
      (2)   The fixtures are placed in a room used for toilet purposes only,
and that the room is accessible without passing through the other dwelling
units, or outside the dwelling; and
      (3)   A person is designated to clean and does clean the room every 24
hours.
   (F)   Water closets. Every dwelling shall have a flush type water closet,
located therein, in a room affording privacy, and properly connected to the
water supply and sewer system. This water closet may be shared by two dwelling
units if divisions (A), (B), and (C) of this section are satisfied.
   (G)   Hopper type water closets, water closets outside the dwelling, and
privies. Hopper type water closets, water closets outside the dwelling, and
privies are declared to be public nuisances and shall be eliminated upon notice
after failure to maintain in a sanitary condition, but in any case not later
than five years after the effective date of this chapter.
   (H)   Requirement. Every dwelling shall have water heating facilities
properly connected to the water piping system, and the facilities shall have a
capacity to supply a sufficient quantity of water to each fixture connected at
a minimum temperature of 120°F.
(Prior Code, § 151.07)
§ 151.08 BASEMENTS AND CELLARS.
   (A)   No cellar space shall be used as a habitable room.
   (B)   Basement space may be used as a habitable room if:
      (1)   The windows are sufficiently above the lot’s ground level so as to
allow the room to meet requirements of habitable rooms as to light and
ventilation;
      (2)   The floors below grade level of the lot are impervious to water and
free from dampness at all times; and
      (3)   The clear inner height is at least six feet eight inches, and no
pipes or beams are below six feet from floor level.
(Prior Code, § 151.08)
§ 151.09 SPACE REQUIREMENTS.
   The number of persons occupying any dwelling unit shall be limited by the
following requirements.
   (A)   Size of dwelling unit. The total of all habitable rooms in the
dwelling unit shall be such as to provide at least 150 square feet of floor
space for the first occupant and 100 square feet of floor space per additional
occupant.
   (B)   Minimum height of habitable rooms. Every habitable room shall be not
less than seven feet in height from the floor to the ceiling throughout one-
half of the area of the room. Any portion of the room having a ceiling height
of less than five feet shall not be considered in computing the total floor
area for the room.
   (C)   Minimum square footage. No habitable room shall contain less than 70
square feet of floor area, nor shall the least horizontal dimension of a room
be less than seven feet.
(Prior Code, § 151.09)
§ 151.10 EGRESS.
   (A)   (1)   Every dwelling unit shall have a safe, unobstructed means of
egress to a safe and open space at ground level. All structures of three or
more stories with a dwelling unit occupying the third or higher story shall be
provided with two separate usable, unobstructed means of egress for each
dwelling unit located above the second story.
      (2)   The exit facilities from the dwelling units shall lead to a public
thoroughfare either directly or through a court or yard, and passage to the
exits shall not lead through any other dwelling unit or through a space that
might reasonably be locked by anyone who is not a member of that household. An
escape hatch or scuttle to a flat roof for escape through adjoining buildings
may be considered as a usable means of egress for the dwelling unit occupying
the top floor.
   (B)   Dual egress will not be required of structures that are of fully
fireproof construction.
(Prior Code, § 151.10)
§ 151.11 INFESTATION.
   (A)   During that portion of each year extending from May l through
September 30, and as protection against mosquitoes, flies, and other insects,
every door opening directly from a dwelling unit to outdoor space shall be
equipped with screens and a self-closing device; and every window or other
device with opening to outdoor space used or intended to be used for
ventilation shall likewise be equipped with screens or other insect deterrents.
   (B)   Every basement or cellar window used or intended to be used for
ventilation, and every other opening to a basement which might provide an entry
for rodents, shall be permanently equipped with screens or such other device as
will effectively prevent their entrance.
   (C)   During the summer months, there shall be no standing pools of water
which might provide an entry for rodents.
   (D)   Dwellings should be free from rodents and other vermin at all times.
Responsibility for extermination rests with the occupant or owner as set forth
in §
151.12(B) and §
151.13(D).
(Prior Code, § 151.11)
§ 151.12 RESPONSIBILITIES OF OCCUPANT.
   (A)   The responsibilities of the occupant are as follows:
      (1)   To keep dwelling and premises he or she controls and occupies in a
clean and sanitary condition;
      (2)   To dispose of rubbish and garbage in a clean and sanitary manner as
prescribed by city regulation;
      (3)   To hang and remove screens provided by the owner except where the
owner has agreed to supply those services;
      (4)   To keep plumbing fixtures therein in a clean and sanitary condition
and to exercise reasonable care in the proper use and operation thereof; and
      (5)   To exterminate in the following cases:
         (a)   Occupant of single dwelling is responsible for extermination of
any insects, rodents, or other pests therein or on premises; and
         (b)   Occupant of a dwelling unit in a multiple-unit structure is
responsible for extermination of any insects, rodents, or other pests, if his
or her unit is the only unit infested.
   (B)   Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this section, whenever
infestation is caused by the failure of the owner to maintain the dwelling in a
rat-proof or reasonably insect-proof condition, the occupant is not responsible
for extermination of any insects, rodents, or other pests therein.
(Prior Code, § 151.12)
§ 151.13 RESPONSIBILITIES OF OWNER.
   The responsibilities of the owner are as follows:
   (A)   To let no dwelling to anyone for occupancy unless it meets minimum
standards set forth in §§
151.04 through
151.14 herein;
   (B)   To have the dwelling in a clean, sanitary, habitable condition; to
free the dwelling from infestation before renting; to paint the walls and
ceilings; and to clean, repair, and exterminate if needed to meet aforestated
requirements before offering for rent;
   (C)   To provide screens to be hung; and
   (D)   To exterminate in the following cases:
      (1)   When infestation exists in two or more units of multiple-unit
structure;
      (2)   When infestation exists in shared or public areas of a multiple-
unit structure; and
      (3)   When infestation exists in a single-unit or multiple-unit structure
or in a single-unit structure when infestation is due to the failure of the
owner to maintain the dwelling in a rat-proof and reasonably insect-proof
condition.
(Prior Code, § 151.13)
§ 151.14 CONDITION OF STRUCTURE.
   (A)   All dwelling structures shall be watertight, weatherproof, rodent- and
insect-proof and in good repair.
   (B)   Every foundation, exterior wall, and roof shall be reasonably
watertight, weathertight, and rodent-proof; shall adequately support the
building at all times; and shall be in a workmanlike state of maintenance and
repair.
   (C)   Every interior partition, wall, floor, and ceiling shall be reasonably
tight, capable of affording privacy and maintained in a workmanlike state of
repair and in a clean and sanitary condition.
   (D)   All rainwater shall be so drained and conveyed from every roof, and
the lot shall be so graded and drained as not to cause dampness in the walls,
ceilings, floors, or basement of dwellings.
   (E)   Every window, exterior door, and basement hatchway shall be reasonably
weathertight and rodent-proof; and shall be maintained in sound condition and
repair.
   (F)   Every inside and outside stairway, every porch and every appurtenance
thereto shall be so constructed as to be safe to use and capable of supporting
the load that normal use may cause to be placed thereon. It shall be maintained
in sound condition and repair.
   (G)   Every supplied plumbing fixture and water and waste pipe shall be
properly installed and maintained in a sanitary working condition, free from
defect, leaks, and obstruction.
   (H)   Every toilet, bathroom, and kitchen floor shall be constructed and
maintained so as to be reasonably impervious to water, and the floor shall be
kept in a clean and sanitary condition.
   (I)   Every supplied facility, piece of equipment, or utility which is
required under this chapter shall be so constructed and installed that it will
function safely and effectively, and shall be maintained in good working
condition.
(Prior Code, § 151.14)
§ 151.15 MINIMUM STANDARDS FOR ROOMING HOUSES.
   No person shall operate a rooming house or shall let to another for
occupancy any room unless the rooming house or room complies with the following
requirements.
   (A)   Every rooming house and room shall be in compliance with the minimum
standards set forth in §§
151.04,
151.05,
151.06, and
151.09 as to light, ventilation, heating, and space requirements.
   (B)   Every rooming house shall be equipped with at least one flush water
closet, one lavatory, and one tub or shower for each eight persons or fraction
thereof within the rooming house, including members of the family if they are
to share the use of the facilities. In rooming houses in which rooms are let
only to males, flush urinals may be substituted for not more than one-half of
the required number of water closets. All facilities shall be properly
connected to the water supply and sewer system.
   (C)   Every flush water closet, flush urinal, lavatory, tub, or shower
required above shall be located within the rooming house in a room or rooms,
which:
      (1)   Affords privacy;
      (2)   Is accessible by a common hall without going outside the rooming
house;
      (3)   Is accessible from a common hall without going through the sleeping
quarters of others; and
      (4)   Is not more than one story removed from the room of an occupant
intended to share the facilities.
   (D)   Where bedding, bed linen, or towels are supplied, the operator shall
maintain the bedding in a clean and sanitary manner, shall furnish clean bed
linen and towels at least once each week and prior to the letting of any room
to an occupant.
(Prior Code, § 151.15)
§ 151.16 DUTIES AND POWERS OF CITY BUILDING INSPECTOR REGARDING HOUSING CODE.
   In addition to the duties and powers vested in the City Building Inspector
by §
153.29 or by any other section of the city’s code of ordinances, the City
Building Inspector is hereby authorized to exercise such powers as are
necessary or convenient to carry out and effectuate the purposes and provisions
of this chapter, including the following powers in addition to others herein
granted:
   (A)   To investigate the conditions of structures in the city in order to
determine which structures therein are unfit and unsafe for human habitation,
occupancy, or use;
   (B)   To administer oaths, affirmations, examine witnesses, and receive
evidence;
   (C)   To enforce the provisions of this chapter, and he or she, or his or
her duly authorized representative upon presentation of proper identification
to the owner, agent, or tenant in charge of such property, may enter any
building, structure, dwelling, apartment, apartment house, or premises, during
all reasonable hours, except in cases of emergency where extreme hazards are
known to exist which may involve the potential loss of life or severe property
damage, in which case the above limitations shall not apply;
   (D)   To make or cause to be made inspections to determine the condition of
residential and commercial buildings and premises in the interest of
safeguarding the health and safety of the occupants of such buildings and of
the general public. For the purpose of making such inspections, the City
Building Inspector, or his or her agent, is hereby authorized to enter,
examine, and survey at all reasonable times all residential and commercial
buildings and premises. The owner or occupant of every residential or
commercial building or the person in charge thereof shall give the City
Building Inspector free access to such residential or commercial buildings and
his or her premises, at all reasonable times for the purpose of such
inspection, examination, and survey; and
   (E)   To delegate any of his or her functions and powers under this chapter
to subordinate officers and agents.
(Prior Code, § 151.16) (Ord. FY 88-89, #18, passed 4-18-1989)
§ 151.17 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Inspector is authorized to make and adopt written rules and regulations
as may be necessary for the proper enforcement of the provisions of this code;
provided that the rules and regulations shall not be in conflict with the
provisions of this code. The Inspector shall file a certified copy of all rules
and regulations which he or she may adopt in the office of the City Clerk. The
rules and regulations shall have the same force and effect as the provisions of
this code and the penalty for violation thereof shall be the same as the
penalty for violation of the provisions of this code.
(Prior Code, § 151.17)
§ 151.18 EMERGENCY POWERS.
   The Inspector is granted certain emergency powers. Whenever the Inspector
finds that a condition exists which requires immediate action to protect the
public health and safety, he or she may, without notice or hearing, issue an
order citing the existence of an emergency and requiring that action be taken
as he or she deems necessary to meet the emergency. Notwithstanding the other
provisions of this code, the order shall be effective immediately. Any person
on whom such an order is directed shall comply therewith immediately, but upon
a petition shall be afforded a hearing by the Board of Housing Appeals as soon
as possible. After the hearing, depending upon the findings as to whether the
provisions of this code have been complied with, the Board shall continue the
order in effect, or modify it, or revoke it.
(Prior Code, § 151.18)
§ 151.19 COMPLAINT PROCEDURE, HEARING, AND APPEAL.
   The following procedures shall be followed with regard to the issuance of
complaints, the conducting of hearings, and the manner of appealing orders
entered pursuant hereto.
   (A)   Whenever a petition is filed with the City Building Inspector by at
least three residents of the city charging that any structure is unfit and
unsafe for human habitation, occupancy, or use, or whenever it appears to the
City Building Inspector that any structure is unfit and unsafe for human
habitation, occupancy or use, or whenever said petition alleges or it appears
to the City Building Inspector that conditions exist in the structure which are
dangerous or injurious to the health or safety of the occupants of the
structure, the occupants of neighboring structures, or other residents of the
city, the City Building Inspector shall, if his or her preliminary
investigation discloses a basis for such allegation, issue and cause to be
served upon the owner of and parties in interest in such structure a complaint
stating the allegations in that respect.
   (B)   The complaint shall state that a hearing will be held before the Board
of Housing Appeals at a place fixed in the complaint not less than ten days nor
more than 30 days after the serving of the complaint; that the owner and
parties in interest may file an answer to the complaint and appear in person,
or otherwise, and give testimony at the time and place stated in the complaint;
and that the Kentucky Rules of Civil Procedure shall not be controlling to the
hearing.
   (C)   If, after the notice and hearing, the Board of Housing Appeals
determines that the structure under consideration is unfit and unsafe for human
habitation, occupancy, or use, or that conditions exist in the structure which
are dangerous or injurious to the health or safety of the occupants of the
structure, the occupants of neighboring structures, or other residents of the
city, according to this chapter of the city’s code of ordinances or in the
State Building Code as promulgated in 815 KAR 7:120 by the state’s Board of
Housing, Buildings and Construction, as appropriate, it shall state in writing
its findings of fact in support of such determination and shall issue and cause
to be served upon the owner thereof an order requiring the owner, within the
time specified:
      (1)   To repair, alter, or improve the structure to render it fit for
human habitation, occupancy, or use, or, at the option of the owner, to vacate,
demolish, and remove the structure; or
      (2)   To remove or demolish the structure, if the removal or demolition
is deemed necessary by the Board of Housing Appeals.
   (D)   If the owner fails to comply with an order to repair, alter, or
improve or, at the option of the owner, to vacate, demolish, and remove the
structure, the City Building Inspector may cause the structure to be repaired,
altered, or improved, or to be vacated and closed. The City Building Inspector
may cause to be posted on the main entrance of any structure so closed, a
placard with the following words: “This building is unfit and unsafe for human
habitation, occupancy or use; the use or occupation of this building for human
habitation, occupancy, or use is prohibited and unlawful.”
   (E)   If the owner fails to comply with an order to remove or demolish the
structure, the City Building Inspector may cause such structure to be removed
or demolished; provided, however, that if the city hires an independent
contractor to perform the removal or demolition, such contractor shall supply
the city with proof of good and sufficient insurance to cover any damages to
persons or property which might result from the removal or demolition and
provided that the contractor shall sign a written agreement indemnifying and
holding the city harmless from any and all liability whatsoever resulting from
the contractor’s actions.
   (F)   The amount of the cost of repairs, alterations, or improvements, or of
vacating and closing, or of removal or demolition shall be a lien upon the real
property upon which the cost was incurred. If the structure is removed or
demolished by the City Building Inspector or at his or her direction, he or she
shall sell the materials of the structure remaining thereafter and shall credit
the proceeds of such sale against the cost of the removal or demolition. Any
balance remaining shall be deposited in a trust fund by the City Building
Inspector, until such time as the identity of the proper persons who are
entitled thereto may be ascertained, at which point the City Building Inspector
shall disburse the proceeds to those persons.
   (G)   The City Building Inspector shall execute a written affidavit which
shall constitute prima facie evidence of the amount of the lien provided for in
division (F) of this section, and the regularity of the proceedings pursuant to
this section and to KRS 65.8840 and shall record same in the real property
records in the office of the Bell County Court Clerk. The lien shall be notice
to all persons from the time of its recording and shall bear interest at the
maximum legal interest rate set forth in KRS 360.010 thereafter until paid. The
lien created shall take precedence over all other subsequent liens, except
state, county, school board, and city taxes, and may be enforced by judicial
proceedings instituted by the city, in which case the owner shall also be
liable for any and all costs incurred in the process of collection of the
amount secured by the lien, including court costs and a reasonable attorney
fee. In addition, the owner of a property upon which a lien has been attached
pursuant hereto shall be personally liable for the amount of the lien,
including all interest, civil penalties, and other charges, including costs of
collection, court costs and a reasonable attorney fee, and the city may bring a
civil action against the owner and shall have the same remedies as provided for
the recovery of a debt owed.
   (H)   When the City Building Inspector has condemned as unfit and unsafe for
human habitation, occupancy, or use, any structure in accordance with this
chapter and has ordered same to be vacated, the City Building Inspector may,
upon ten days’ written notice to the occupants, apply to Bell District Court
for an order of eviction directing the sheriff to remove the occupants and
their belongings from the structure.
   (I)   Complaints or orders issued by the City Building Inspector or Board of
Housing Appeals, as applicable, pursuant to this chapter shall be served upon
persons either personally or by certified mail; however, if the whereabouts of
such person are unknown and cannot be ascertained in the exercise of reasonable
diligence, or if the person is so conducting himself or herself as to avoid
service personally or by certified mail, and the City Building Inspector makes
an affidavit to that effect, service of such complaint or order shall be by
newspaper publication for three successive weeks pursuant to KRS Chapter 424. A
copy of such complaint or order shall also be posted in a conspicuous place on
the premises affected by the complaint or order, and shall be recorded in the
real property records in the office of the Bell County Court Clerk.
   (J)   Any person affected by an order issued by the Board of Housing
Appeals, may, within three days after the posting and service of the order,
petition the Bell Circuit Court for an injunction restraining the City Building
Inspector pending the final disposition of the cause. Hearings shall be had by
the court on such petition within 20 days, or as soon thereafter as possible.
In all such proceedings the findings of the Board of Housing Appeals as to
facts, if supported by substantial evidence, shall be conclusive.
(Prior Code, § 151.19) (Ord. FY 88-89, #18, passed 4-18-1989; Ord. FY 90-91,
#1, passed 7-31-1990)
§ 151.20 BOARD OF HOUSING APPEALS.
   (A)   There is created and established a Board of Housing Appeals
hereinafter referred to as the Board, which shall consist of five members
appointed by the Mayor and approved by a majority vote of the City Council. The
City Building Inspector shall not be appointed as a member of the Board of
Housing Appeals. All appointed members shall be registered voters of the city
and shall not receive any remuneration for their services. Two members shall be
appointed for two-year terms, and three for three-year terms, who may be
reappointed at the expiration of their terms; all future appointments shall be
for two-year terms. The appointed members shall not be candidates for public
office at the time of their appointment, and if later they become candidates
they must retire from the Board. A vacancy shall be filled by the Mayor
appointing a person qualified as provided herein with approval of the City
Council to fill the unexpired term of the member whose term becomes vacant. The
members shall be removable for cause by the appointing authority upon written
charges and after a public hearing.
   (B)   The Board shall meet within ten days after its appointment and shall
elect a Chairperson from among its membership; the elected member shall be
Chairperson until the expiration of his or her term. A Vice-Chairperson shall
be elected; his or her duties are to assume the responsibility of the
Chairperson in the latter’s absence. The duties of the Chairperson are to
preside over the hearings and to question the parties involved; provided,
however, that other members of the Board may also question the parties. The
Chairperson may vote on all matters. The rules of evidence prevailing in courts
of law and equity, as well as the Kentucky Rules of Civil Procedure, shall not
be controlling on hearings. The Board shall adopt rules and regulations as it
may deem necessary to carry into effect the provisions of this chapter.
   (C)   The Chairperson shall call meetings and shall notify Board members; in
open meetings, the Board shall hear evidence presented by the City Building
Inspector and by the property owner or other party respondent regarding the
allegations contained in the complaint. The presence of three members shall
constitute a quorum and the concurring vote of three members shall be necessary
to enter any order granting the relief sought in the complaint, granting any
part of the relief sought therein, or to dismiss the complaint. The proceedings
at the hearings, including the findings and decisions of the Board, shall be
summarized, reduced to writing, and entered as a matter of public record in the
office of the City Clerk.
(Prior Code, § 151.20) (Ord. FY 88-89, #18, passed 4-18-1989)
§ 151.21 INDEPENDENCE OF SECTIONS.
   Each section of this chapter shall be deemed independent of all other
provisions herein, and, if any provision is declared invalid, it shall not
affect other provisions which shall remain in force and effect.
(Prior Code, § 151.21) (Ord. FY 88-89, #18, passed 4-18-1989)
§ 151.22 RELATION OF THIS CHAPTER 151 TO CHAPTER 160: HISTORIC DISTRICTS.
   Notwithstanding the provisions of the city’s code of ordinances §
160.50 or any other provisions of
Chapter 160, neither the City Building Inspector nor the Board of Housing
Appeals shall be required to acquire a certificate of appropriateness from the
Historic District Commission prior to issuing any complaint or entering any
order in accordance with this
Chapter 151. Furthermore, the Historic District Commission may not issue a stop
work order pursuant to §
160.51 to prevent the actions of the City Building Inspector or the Board of
Housing Appeals undertaken pursuant to authority vested in them by this
Chapter 151. However, the Historic District Commission shall be invited to
attend all hearings before the Board of Housing Appeals and shall be free to
render its opinion regarding complaints issued by the City Building Inspector
or orders proposed to be entered by the Board of Housing Appeals prior to the
entry of such orders.
(Prior Code, § 151.22) (Ord. FY 88-89, #18, passed 4-18-1989)
§ 151.23 CONFLICT WITH OTHER ORDINANCES AND LAWS.
   In any case where a provision of this chapter is found to be in conflict
with a portion of any other chapter, the provision which establishes the higher
standard for the promotion and protection of the health and safety of the
people shall prevail.
(Prior Code, § 151.23)
§ 151.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   The owner of any structure which is determined to be unfit and unsafe
in accordance with this chapter who shall fail to comply with any notice or
order to repair, vacate, or demolish said structure issued pursuant to this
chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be fined
not less than $10 nor more than $500 for each offense. Every day such failure
to comply continues shall be considered a separate offense.
   (B)   The occupant or lessee in possession who fails to comply with any
notice to vacate and who fails to repair said building in accordance with any
notice given as provided for in this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor
and, upon conviction, shall be fined not less than $10 nor more than $500 for
each offense. Every day such failure to comply continues shall be considered a
separate offense.
   (C)   The right to impose the penalties set out in divisions (A) and (B) of
this section, are in addition to all other rights of the city set forth in this
chapter.
(Prior Code, § 151.99) (Ord. FY 88-89, #18, passed 4-18-1989)
CHAPTER 152: FALLOUT SHELTERS
Section
   
152.01   Definition
   
152.02   Fallout shelters permitted
   
152.03   Joint shelters
   
152.04   Yard requirements
   
152.05   Building permit required
   
152.06   No fee required
   
152.07   Inspections
   
152.08   No increase in property assessments
§ 152.01 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definition shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   FALLOUT SHELTER. A structure or portion of a structure intended to provide
protection to human life during periods of danger to human life from nuclear
fallout, air raids, storms, or other emergencies.
(Prior Code, § 152.01)
§ 152.02 FALLOUT SHELTERS PERMITTED.
   Fallout shelters are permitted as principal or accessory uses in any
district. These shelters may contain or be contained in other structures or may
be constructed separately, and in addition to shelter use may be used for any
principal or accessory use permitted in the district, subject to the district
regulations on such use, but shall not be used for principal or accessory uses
prohibited expressly or by implication in the district within which the shelter
is to be located.
(Prior Code, § 152.02)
§ 152.03 JOINT SHELTERS.
   (A)   The Board of Zoning Adjustment may permit as a special exception
construction of joint shelters by two or more property owners. Where joint
shelters are permitted, the Board may waive the side and rear yard requirements
on the property or properties directly involved in the construction of the
joint shelter to the extent necessary to permit practical and efficient
location and construction however, side and rear yard requirements shall be met
where property involved in the joint proposal abuts or adjoins property not
included in the proposal.
   (B)   The Board of Zoning Adjustment may also permit a fallout shelter to be
used for other purposes permissible by special exception in the district in
which the shelter is located if the Board finds that all of the general
requirements of the zoning code concerning special exceptions are satisfied,
and in addition establishes that:
      (1)   The use other than a shelter is compatible with the proposed
shelter;
      (2)   The function as a shelter would not be materially impaired by the
proposed use; and
      (3)   The special exception as to use would have been granted regardless
of whether the shelter was involved.
(Prior Code, § 152.03)
§ 152.04 YARD REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Front yards. No shelter shall be constructed nearer to the front
property line than the minimum front yard building setback required for other
uses in the district, except that the Board of Zoning Adjustment may issue a
variance from the conditions of this section where they determine the
topography dictates and makes it feasible to permit fallout shelters in the
front yards.
   (B)   Side yards. No fallout shelter shall be constructed closer than five
feet to the nearest property line.
   (C)   Rear yards. No fallout shelter shall be constructed closer than five
feet to the rear property line.
(Prior Code, § 152.04)
§ 152.05 BUILDING PERMIT REQUIRED.
   A building permit shall be required for construction of any type of fallout
shelter whether within or outside of an existing building or structure.
(Prior Code, § 152.05)
§ 152.06 NO FEE REQUIRED.
   No building fee shall be required in connection with a permit for a fallout
shelter.
(Prior Code, § 152.06)
§ 152.07 INSPECTIONS.
   The Building Inspector shall make inspections to determine the safety of the
structure to ensure that all shelters constructed by contractors or individuals
meet structural standards of safety as specified by the city’s building
regulations.
(Prior Code, § 152.07)
§ 152.08 NO INCREASE IN PROPERTY ASSESSMENTS.
   There shall be no increase in property assessments due to the construction
of a fallout shelter meeting city specifications.
(Prior Code, § 152.08)

§ 153.01 ADOPTION OF THE NATIONAL BUILDING CODE.
   The 1967 National Building Code, and all amendments thereto, copies of which
are on file in the City Clerk’s office, are adopted and incorporated by
reference, and made part of this code as though fully set out herein.
(Prior Code, § 153.01)
§ 153.02 PERMITS AND INSPECTION.
   (A)   No walls, structure, building, or part thereof shall hereafter be
built, enlarged, or altered until a plan of the proposed work, together with a
statement of the kind of materials to be used and an estimate of approximate
cost of same, shall have been submitted in duplicate to the City Council who
shall, if in accordance with the provisions herein contained, issue a permit in
writing for the proposed construction or alterations.
   (B)   Structures hereafter erected without a permit or not in conformity
with this chapter shall be removed if so ordered by the City Building
Inspector.
   (C)   No building or structure shall be moved until a permit has been
obtained from the City Council, and the permit shall not be issued if in the
judgment of the City Building Inspector the proposed new location would create
a hazard.
   (D)   The City Building Inspector shall, as often as practicable, inspect
all buildings or structures during construction for which a permit has been
issued in order to ascertain that the provisions of law are complied with and
that construction is prosecuted safely. Whenever, in his or her opinion, the
building operation is contrary to public welfare, he or she may require
suspension of work until the condition in violation has been remedied.
   (E)   No building permit shall be in force until the fee hereinafter set
forth has been paid and receipted on the permit.
(Prior Code, § 153.02)
§ 153.03 FEES FOR PERMITS AND INSPECTION.
   (A)   Generally. The fees for permits and inspection shall be as follows:

   (B)   Elevators.
      (1)   All elevators operated within the city shall be inspected at
intervals of approximately two years.
      (2)   The fees for inspection of elevators, except the initial
inspection, shall be $5 for each elevator. This amount shall be paid by the

operated within the city without an inspection certificate.
      (3)   The word ELEVATOR shall be construed to mean those used for
carrying passengers and/or freight from floor to floor.
(Prior Code, § 153.03)
§ 153.04 PERMISSIBLE WOODEN STRUCTURES.
   No frame or wooden structure shall hereafter be built within the city except
the following:
   (A)   A building of frame construction or of unprotected metal construction
occupied exclusively as a private garage or a stable, not more than one story
in height nor more than 750 square feet in area;
   (B)   Outhouses not more than eight feet in height, nor more than 100 square
feet in area;
   (C)   Greenhouses not more than 15 feet in height, erected according to the
rules of good building practice;
   (D)   Sheds open on the long side, not more than 15 feet in height nor more
than 500 square feet in area;
   (E)   Builders’ shanties not more than one story in height, for use only in
connection with duly authorized building operations;
   (F)   Piazzas or balconies on dwellings not exceeding ten feet in width;
provided that no such structure shall extend to within two feet of a lot or
line to be joined to a similar structure on another building;
   (G)   Coal tipples, ice houses, material bins, tressels, and water tanks,
when built of planking and timbers of the dimensions acceptable for heavy
timber construction;
   (H)   Fences not exceeding ten feet in height;
   (I)   Display signs as elsewhere provided in this chapter; and
   (J)   Frame dwellings not exceeding two stories in height and separated by
at least five feet from lot line adjoining property.
(Prior Code, § 153.04)
§ 153.05 BUILDING PROHIBITED.
   No building shall hereafter be erected for use as a public garage, coffee
roaster, bakery, dry cleaning establishment, welding shop, or other hazardous
activity not approved by the City Building Inspector and the Chief of the Fire
Department, unless it be of fire-proof construction.
(Prior Code, § 153.05) Penalty, see §
153.99
§ 153.06 REMOVAL OR REPAIR OF UNSAFE BUILDINGS.
   (A)   A building or structure or part thereof, that may be or shall at any
time hereafter become dangerous or unsafe, shall, unless made safe and secure,
be taken down and removed.
   (B)   A building or structure or part thereof declared structurally unsafe
or hazardous by duly constituted authority may be restored to safe condition;
provided that if the damage or cost of reconstruction or restoration is in
excess of 50% of the value of the building or structure exclusive of
foundations. The building or structure if restored or reconstructed shall be
made to conform with respect to materials and type of construction, to the
requirements for buildings and structures hereafter erected; but no change of
use or occupancy shall be compelled by reason of this reconstruction or
restoration.
(Prior Code, § 153.06) Penalty, see §
153.99
§ 153.07 LIMITS OF HEIGHT AND AREA.
   (A)   Buildings of unprotected metal construction shall not be more than one
story high; provided that this requirement shall not prohibit mezzanine
stories, the aggregate floor area of which does not exceed 25% of the area of
the building.
   (B)   Public garages of fireproof, semi-fireproof and heavy timber
construction shall not exceed 10,000, 7,500, and 6,000 square feet
respectively; and business buildings and storage buildings, if of semi-
fireproof construction, shall not exceed 10,000 square feet, but if of ordinary
wood joint and masonry wall construction, they shall not exceed 5,000, 6,000,
and 7,500 square feet, when fronting on one, two, and three streets
respectively. Buildings of heavy timber construction may have areas 33% in
excess of those allowed for ordinary construction. Buildings of frame
construction shall not exceed 5,000 square feet.
   (C)   The limiting areas fixed in this section may be increased 100% if the
building is sprinklered and by 200% if the building is sprinklered and does not
exceed one story nor an average of 25 feet in height to the roof, or to a
ceiling which is unpiered.
   (D)   When a hazardous condition is not created thereby, the area of a
public building, a business building, or a storage building, not over two
stories high, may be increased in excess of the areas fixed by this section, in
the discretion of a Board consisting of the Mayor, the Chief of the Fire
Department, and the City Building Inspector; provided that buildings of
combustible occupancy shall be sprinklered.
(Prior Code, § 153.07)
§ 153.08 FOUNDATIONS.
   (A)   All foundations shall be built upon solid natural ground. Where solid
natural ground does not occur at the foundation depth, the foundation shall be
extended down to solid natural ground, or piles shall be used. Ground which has
been filled solid with earth shall not be used for building purposes until two
years time has elapsed or until the new fill has been properly packed by a
sheepsfoot roller or other packing device and has been determined by proper
tests to be solid enough to support the contemplated building. Fills over trash
dumps may not be used for the construction of buildings until such time as they
have been properly tested and shown to be suitable for the buildings, the tests
being submitted for examination and approval by the Building Inspector.
   (B)   An excavation shall extend to a level which will provide adequate
bearing and not less than eight inches below finish grade. If excavation is
made too deep, it shall be filled with concrete to bring it to the desired
level.
   (C)   The bottom of the footing shall be level. Where steps are required,
the vertical connection between footings at the steps shall be constructed of
concrete four inches thick and the same width as the footings. The footing and
steps shall be poured in one continuous unit.
   (D)   All footings shall be designed for proper distribution of superimposed
loads.
   (E)   Before any concrete is poured, the Building Inspector shall make an
inspection.
   (F)   Material shall be poured concrete, mixed not less than one part
cement, two parts sand, and four parts gravel.
   (G)   The thickness and width of footings shall be determined in accordance
with sound engineering practice. In no case shall footings be less than eight
inches thick and 16 inches wide.
   (H)   In buildings where loads are greater in the center, the footings shall
be determined in accordance with sound engineering practice. In no case shall
the footings in the center of the building be less than the outside footings.
   (I)   For chimneys and flues, footings shall be not less than 12 inches
thick and shall extend beyond the chimney on all sides a minimum of not less
than six inches.
   (J)   Where footings are required to cross pipe trenches or similar unstable
areas, they shall be reinforced with sufficient supporting steel bars.
   (K)   These minimum foundation requirements shall be in addition to other
minimum safety requirements in other chapters and are not intended to supplant
or repeal any other safety requirements.
(Prior Code, § 153.08)
§ 153.09 WALLS.
   Walls of all buildings erected or remodeled shall conform to the
requirements as set forth in publications of the American Society for Testing
Materials and the American Concrete Institute.
(Prior Code, § 153.09)
§ 153.10 QUALITY OF MATERIALS.
   (A)   All buildings shall be of good quality materials and shall conform to
specifications which the City Building Inspector approves.
   (B)   For the purposes of this chapter, the accepted standard specifications
for quality of materials shall be those of the American Society for Testing
Materials.
(Prior Code, § 153.10)
§ 153.11 CONCRETE CONSTRUCTION.
   The Building Regulations for Reinforced Concrete as adopted by the American
Concrete Institute shall constitute the accepted good practice in reinforced
concrete construction.
(Prior Code, § 153.11)
§ 153.12 PROTECTION OF ENDS OF WOOD BEAMS.
   Wooden joists, beams, and girders resting on opposite sides of a masonry
wall shall be separated from one another by at least six inches of solid
masonry. The separation may be obtained by corbelling the wall or staggering
the beams, or the beams may be supported by metal wall hangers, but no wall
shall be corbelled more than two inches for this purpose.
(Prior Code, § 153.12)
§ 153.13 PROTECTION OF WALL OPENINGS.
   (A)   The aggregate width of all openings in a fire wall at any level shall
not exceed 25% of the length of the wall.
   (B)   The requirements for fire doors as set forth in the code of the
National Board of Fire Underwriters for exposed openings, stairways, elevators,
and other shafts shall be considered a proper basis for practice and
installation.
(Prior Code, § 153.13)
§ 153.14 SKYLIGHTS.
   (A)   Skylights which are inclined more than 60 degrees from the vertical
hereafter placed on a building shall have the sashes and frames thereof
constructed of metal; except that skylights in foundries or buildings where
acid fumes are present may be of wood by special permission of the City
Building Inspector.
   (B)   Every skylight in which plain glass is used shall be protected by a
substantial wire screen placed not less than four inches or more than ten
inches above the glazed portion of the skylight at all points. The screen shall
extend beyond the glazing on all sides a distance of not less than the height
of the screen above the glazing.
   (C)   When a skylight is located over a stairway, passageway, public
hallway, or a room of public resort a similar screen shall also be placed below
the skylight unless there is an intermediate ceiling light.
(Prior Code, § 153.14)
§ 153.15 ROOF COVERING.
   The codes as published by the National Board of Fire Underwriters and the
Underwriters Laboratories, Inc. shall be the basis for specifications of all
roof covering.
(Prior Code, § 153.15)
§ 153.16 EXITS REQUIRED.
   Exits shall consist of interior stairways, fire towers, horizontal exits,
exterior stairways, passageways, or doorways and such exits shall conform to
the requirements of the code of the National Board of Fire Underwriters.
(Prior Code, § 153.16)
§ 153.17 FIRE STOPS.
   (A)   Fire stopping in all classes of buildings shall be arranged to cut off
all concealed draft openings, such as at floors, ceilings, roofs, and attic
spaces and shall form effectual barriers horizontally and vertically.
   (B)   In buildings of ordinary construction and frame construction, wood two
inches in thickness, nominal dimension, may be used; in other types of
construction approved noncombustible material may be used.
(Prior Code, § 153.17)
§ 153.18 AREAWAYS.
   (A)   All areaways shall be guarded with suitable railings, or be protected
by incombustible coverings or gratings. If gratings are used they shall have a
wire screen of not more than one-half-inch mesh securely attached to the under
side.
   (B)   Open areaways shall not project beyond the lot line.
(Prior Code, § 153.18)
§ 153.19 ELECTRICAL INSTALLATIONS.
   All electrical wiring, apparatus, or appliances for furnishing light, heat,
or power shall be in strict conformity with approved methods and practices for
safety to life and property. Compliance with the code as published by the
National Board of Fire Underwriters shall be adhered to.
(Prior Code, § 153.19)
§ 153.20 CHIMNEYS, FLUES, AND SMOKE PIPES.
   All chimneys, flues, and smoke pipes shall be in strict conformity with
approved methods and practices as to fire hazards and the code of the National
Board of Fire Underwriters shall be adhered to.
(Prior Code, § 153.20)
§ 153.21 DUCTS OF WARM AIR HEATING SYSTEMS.
   (A)   Ducts of warm air heating systems shall be constructed and installed
in accordance with generally accepted good practice, having due regard to
clearance, air temperature controls, and to other matters necessary to avoid
overheating of combustible material under any condition of operation.
   (B)   The provisions of the Building Code of the National Board of Fire
Underwriters shall be deemed to be the generally accepted good practice for
ducts.
(Prior Code, § 153.21)
§ 153.22 STEAM AND HOT WATER PIPES.
   (A)   Where steam or hot water pipes pass through combustible floors,
partitions, or other combustible construction there shall be an open space of
not less than one inch on all sides of the pipe, which opening shall be capped
with incombustible material.
   (B)   Pipes passing through stock shelving or similar places shall be
covered with not less than one inch of approved insulation.
   (C)   Wooden boxes or casings enclosing steam or hot water pipes, or wooden
covers to recesses in walls in which the pipes are placed shall be lined with
metal or asbestos.
   (D)   Coverings or insulation on steam or hot water pipes shall be
incombustible.
(Prior Code, § 153.22)
§ 153.23 FURNACES AND HEATING APPLIANCES.
   The codes as published by the National Board of Fire Underwriters shall be
the basis for installation of all furnaces and heating appliances.
(Prior Code, § 153.23)
§ 153.24 GAS PIPING AND APPLIANCES.
   Piping for any and all types of gas used for lighting or fuel purposes, and
gas appliances of all types in buildings and structures shall be installed to
conform with generally accepted good practices. The recommended good practice
requirements for the installation, maintenance, and use of piping and fittings
for city gas and gas systems for welding and cutting and liquified petroleum
gas of the National Board of Fire Underwriters shall be deemed to be the
generally accepted good practice.
(Prior Code, § 153.24)
§ 153.25 VENT FLUES.
   Vent flues or ducts for the removal of foul or vitiated air, in which the
temperature of the air cannot exceed that of the rooms, shall be constructed of
metal or other incombustible material and shall not be placed nearer than one
inch to any woodwork, and no flue shall be used for any other purpose.
(Prior Code, § 153.25)
§ 153.26 SUPPLEMENTARY REQUIREMENTS.
   The current edition of the Building Code, recommended by the National Board
of Fire Underwriters shall be deemed to be the generally accepted good practice
for fireproof, semi-fireproof, and heavy timber construction, safeguards during
construction of theaters, other special occupancies, and all other matters not
covered in this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 153.26)
§ 153.27 STANDARDS OF SAFETY.
   (A)   The 1963 Kentucky Standards of Safety as adopted and approved by the
Department of Insurance, is adopted as part of the Building Code of the city,
and reference is made to the 1963 Kentucky Standards of Safety, and all
articles contained therein, and are made a part of this chapter as if fully
copied herein.
   (B)   The Chief of the Fire Department along with all other officers,
agents, and employees of the city, be and they are charged with the enforcement
of the provisions of the standards of safety.
(Prior Code, § 153.27)
Statutory reference:
   Statutory standards, see KRS 227.200 et seq.
§ 153.28 CODE PUBLICATIONS.
   The various codes referred to herein shall be kept on file in the office of
the City Clerk for reference and will be available to all concerned.
(Prior Code, § 153.28)
§ 153.29 DUTIES OF ENFORCING OFFICER.
   The City Building Inspector is authorized and empowered:
   (A)   To enforce all ordinances relating to the construction, equipment,
management, and condition of all property within the city;
   (B)   To supervise the construction or reconstruction of all buildings and
structures; and
   (C)   To report monthly to the Mayor and the Board of Commissioners
regarding the condition of the city on all matters pertaining to building
construction.
(Prior Code, § 153.29)
§ 153.30 LIABILITY FOR DAMAGE.
   This chapter shall not be construed to relieve from, or to lessen the
responsibility or liability of any party owning, constructing, or controlling
any of the activities or devices mentioned within this chapter for damage to
persons or property, nor shall the city or any official thereof be held as
assuming any liability by reason of the inspections authorized herein, or any
permit or certificate of approval as herein provided.
(Prior Code, § 153.98)
§ 153.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any and all persons who shall violate any of the provisions of this
chapter or fail to comply therewith or who shall violate any order or
regulation made thereunder, who shall build in violation of any detailed
statement or specification or plan submitted and approved thereunder, shall
severally for each and every violation and noncompliance respectively be fined
in the sum of not less than $5 nor more than $25.
   (B)   The imposition of one penalty for any violation of this chapter shall
not excuse the violation or permit it to continue; and all persons shall be
required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable
time. When not otherwise specified, each ten days that prohibited conditions
are maintained shall constitute a separate offense.
   (C)   The imposition of the penalty herein prescribed shall not preclude the
city from instituting an appropriate section or proceeding to prevent an
unlawful erection, repair, construction, reconstruction, conversion,
maintenance, or use; or to restrain, correct, or abate a violation; or to
prevent the occupancy of a building, structure, or premises; or to prevent an
illegal act, conduct, business, or use in or about any premises.
   (D)   Any person who violates any provisions of KRS 227.200 to KRS 227.400
or any provision of a lawful order, rule, or regulation made under the
provisions of KRS 227.200 to KRS 227.400, or induces another to violate any
provisions of KRS 227.200 to KRS 227.400 or of any lawful order, rule, or
regulation made thereunder, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined
not less than $10 nor more than $500, or confined in the county jail for not
more than 60 days, or both. Each day the violations exist shall, in the
discretion of the courts, be considered a separate offense. The imposition of
the penalties herein prescribed shall not preclude the city from instituting an
appropriate action or proceeding to prevent an unlawful erection, construction,
reconstruction, alteration, repair, conversion, maintenance, or use; or to
restrain, correct, or abate a violation; or to prevent the occupancy of a
building, structure, or premises; or to prevent an illegal act, conduct,
business, or use in or about any premises.
(Prior Code, § 153.99)

STATUTORY AUTHORIZATION, FINDINGS OF FACT,
PURPOSE, AND OBJECTIVES
§ 156.001 STATUTORY AUTHORIZATION.
   The Legislature of the Commonwealth of Kentucky has in the Kentucky Revised
Statutes Chapter 100 delegated to local governmental units the authority to
adopt regulations designed to promote the public health, safety, and general
welfare of its citizenry. Therefore, the Council of the City of Middlesboro,
Kentucky, has ordained the following provisions.
(Prior Code, § 156.01) (Ord. 92-93, #17, passed 5-4-1993; Ord. 06-07, #4,
passed 9-19-2006)
§ 156.002 FINDINGS OF FACT.
   (A)   The flood hazard areas of the city are subject to periodic inundation
which results in loss of life and property, health, and safety hazards,
disruption of commerce and governmental services, extraordinary public
expenditures for flood protection and relief, and impairment of the tax base,
all of which adversely affect the public health, safety, and general welfare.
   (B)   These flood losses are caused by the cumulative effect of obstructions
in floodplains causing increases in flood heights and velocities, and by the
occupancy in flood hazard areas by uses vulnerable to floods or hazardous to
other lands which are inadequately elevated, flood-proofed, or otherwise
unprotected from flood damages.
(Prior Code, § 156.02) (Ord. 92-93, #17, passed 5-4-1993; Ord. 06-07, #4,
passed 9-19-2006)
§ 156.003 STATEMENT OF PURPOSE.
   It is the purpose of this chapter to promote the public health, safety, and
general welfare and to minimize public and private losses due to flooding by
provisions designed to:
   (A)   Restrict or prohibit uses which are dangerous to health, safety, and
property due to water erosion hazards, or which result in damaging increases in
erosion or in flood height or velocity;
   (B)   Require that uses vulnerable to floods, including facilities which
serve such uses, be protected against flood damage at the time of initial
construction;
   (C)   Control the alteration of natural floodplains, stream channels, and
natural protective barriers which are involved in the accommodation of flood
waters;
   (D)   Control filling, grading, dredging, and other development which may
increase erosion or flood damage; and
   (E)   Prevent or regulate the construction of flood barriers which will
unnaturally divert flood waters or which may increase flood hazards to other
lands.
(Prior Code, § 156.03) (Ord. 92-93, #17, passed 5-4-1993; Ord. 06-07, #4,
passed 9-19-2006)
§ 156.004 OBJECTIVES.
   The objectives of this chapter are:
   (A)   To protect human life and health;
   (B)   To minimize expenditure of public money for costly flood control
projects;
   (C)   To minimize the need for rescue and relief efforts associated with
flooding and generally undertaken at the expense of the general public;
   (D)   To minimize prolonged business interruptions;
   (E)   To minimize damage to public facilities and utilities such as water
and gas mains, electric, telephone and sewer lines, streets and bridges located
in areas of special flood hazard;
   (F)   To help maintain a stable tax base by providing for the sound use and
development of areas of special flood hazard or other flood-prone areas in such
a manner as to minimize flood blight areas caused by flooding;
   (G)   To ensure that potential home buyers are notified that property is in
a special flood hazard area; and
   (H)   To ensure that those who occupy a special flood hazard area assume
responsibility for their actions.
(Prior Code, § 156.04) (Ord. 92-93, #17, passed 5-4-1993; Ord. 06-07, #4,
passed 9-19-2006)
DEFINITIONS
§ 156.015 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   A ZONE. Portions of the special flood hazard areas (SFHA) in which the
principle source of flooding is runoff from rainfall, snowmelt, or a
combination of both. In A ZONES, floodwaters may move slowly or rapidly, but
waves are usually not a significant threat to structures. Areas of 100-year
flood, base flood elevations, and flood hazard factors are not determined.
   A1-30 AND AE ZONES. Special flood hazard areas inundated by the 1% annual
chance flood (100-year flood), base flood elevations (BFEs) are determined.
   A99 ZONE. That part of the SFHA inundated by the 100-year flood which is to
be protected from the 100-year flood by a federal flood protection system under
construction. No base flood elevations are determined.
   ACCESSORY STRUCTURE (APPURTENANT STRUCTURE). A structure located on the same
parcel of property as the principle structure, the use of which is incidental
to the use of the principal structure. ACCESSORY STRUCTURES should constitute a
minimal initial investment, may not be used for human habitation, and should be
designed to have minimal flood damage potential. Examples of ACCESSORY
STRUCTURES are detached garages, carports, storage sheds, pole barns, and hay
sheds.
   ACCESSORY USE. A use which is incidental and subordinate to the principal
use of the parcel of land on which it is located.   
   ADDITION TO AN EXISTING BUILDING. Any walled and roofed expansion to the
perimeter of a structure in which the addition is connected by a common load-
bearing wall other than a fire wall. Any walled and roofed addition which is
connected by a fire wall or is separated by independent perimeter load-bearing
walls is new construction.
   AH ZONE. An area of 100-year shallow flooding where depths are between one
and three feet (usually shallow ponding). Base flood elevations are shown.
   AO ZONE. An area of 100-year shallow flooding where water depth is between
one and three feet (usually sheet flow on sloping terrain). Flood depths are
shown.
   APPEAL. A request for a review of the Floodplain Administrator’s
interpretation of any provision of this chapter or from the Floodplain
Administrator’s ruling on a request for a variance.
   AR/AL - A30, AR/AE, AR/ALL, AR/AO, AND AR/A ZONES. Special flood hazard
areas (SFHAs) that result from the decertification of a previously accredited
flood protection system that is in the process of being restored to provide a
100-year or greater level of flood protection. After restoration is complete
these areas will still experience residual flooding from other flooding
sources.    
   AREA OF SHALLOW FLOODING. A designated AO Zone on a community’s flood
insurance rate map (FIRM) with base flood depths from one to three feet, there
is no clearly defined channel the path of flooding is unpredictable and
indeterminate, and velocity flow may be evident. Such flooding is characterized
by ponding or sheet flow.
   B AND X ZONES (SHADED). Areas of the 0.2% annual chance (500-year) flood,
areas subject to the 100-year flood with average depths of less than one foot
or with contributing drainage area less than one square mile, and areas
protected by levees from the base flood.
   BASE FLOOD. The flood having a 1% chance of being equaled or exceeded in any
given year (also called the 100-YEAR FLOOD). BASE FLOOD is the term used
throughout this chapter.
   BASE FLOOD ELEVATION (BFE). The elevation shown on the flood insurance rate
map (FIRM) for Zones AE, AH, A1-30, AR, AR/A, AR/A1-A30, AR/AH, and A1/AO that
indicates the water surface elevation resulting from a flood that has a 1% or
greater chance of being equaled or exceeded in any given year.
   BASEMENT. That portion of a building having its floor subgrade (below ground
level) on all four sides.
   BUILDING. A walled and roofed structure that is principally above ground,
including a manufactured home, a gas or liquid storage tank, or other human-
made facilities or infrastructures. See definition for STRUCTURE.
   C AND X (UNSHADED) ZONES. Areas determined to be outside the 500-year
floodplain.
   COMMUNITY. A political entity having the authority to adopt and enforce
floodplain ordinances for the area under its jurisdiction.
   COMMUNITY FLOOD HAZARD AREA (CFHA). An area that has been determined by the
Floodplain Administrator (or other delegated, designated, or qualified
community official) from available technical studies, historical information,
and other available and reliable sources, which may be subject to periodic
inundation by floodwaters that can adversely affect the public health, safety,
and general welfare. Included are areas downstream from dams.
   COMMUNITY RATING SYSTEM (CRS). A program developed by the Federal Insurance
Administration to provide incentives to those communities in the regular
program to go beyond the minimum floodplain management requirements to develop
extra measures for protection from flooding.
   CRITICAL FACILITY. Any property that, if flooded, would result in severe
consequences to public health and safety or a facility which, if unusable or
unreachable because of flooding, would seriously and adversely affect the
health and safety of the public. CRITICAL FACILITIES include, but are not
limited to: housing likely to contain occupants not sufficiently mobile to
avoid injury or death unaided during a flood; schools, nursing homes,
hospitals, police, fire and emergency response installations, vehicle and
equipment storage facilities, emergency operations centers likely to be called
upon before, during and after a flood, public and private utility facilities
important to maintaining or restoring normal services before, during and after
a flood, and those facilities or installations which produce, use or store
volatile, flammable, explosive, toxic and/or water-reactive materials,
hazardous materials or hazardous waste.
   D ZONE. An area in which the flood hazard is undetermined.
   DEVELOPMENT. Any human-made change to improved or unimproved real estate,
including, but not limited to, buildings or other structures, mining, dredging,
filling, grading, paving, excavating, drilling operations, or permanent storage
of materials or equipment.
   ELEVATED CERTIFICATE. A statement certified by a registered professional
engineer or surveyor on the FEMA-approved form in effect at the time of
certification that verifies a structure’s elevation and other related
information to verify compliance with this chapter.
   ELEVATED STRUCTURE. A non-basement structure built to have the lowest floor
elevated above ground level by means of fill, solid foundation perimeter walls,
piling, columns (post and piers), shear walls, or breakaway walls. (See
freeboard requirements for residential and nonresidential structures.)
   EMERGENCY PROGRAM. The initial phase under which a community participates in
the NFIP, intended to provide a first layer amount of insurance at subsidized
rates on all insurable structures in that community before the effective date
of the initial FIRM.
   ENCLOSURE. That portion of a structure below the base flood elevation (BFE)
used solely for parking of vehicles, limited storage, or access to the
structure.
   ENCROACHMENT. The physical advance or infringement of users, plant growth,
fill, excavation, structures, permanent structures or development into a
floodplain, which may impede or alter the flow capacity of a floodplain.
   EXISTING CONSTRUCTION. Any structure for which the “start of construction”
commenced before the effective date of the FIRM or before January 1, 1975, for
FIRMS effective before that date. EXISTING CONSTRUCTION may also be referred to
as EXISTING STRUCTURES.
   EXISTING MANUFACTURED HOME PARK OR SUBDIVISION. A manufactured home park or
subdivision for which the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on
which the manufactured homes are to affixed (including at a minimum the
installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and either final site
grading or the pouring of concrete pads) is completed before the effective date
of the first floodplain management chapter adopted by the city based on
specific technical base flood elevation data which established the area of
special flood hazards.
   EXPANSION TO AN EXISTING MANUFACTURED HOME PARK OR SUBDIVISION. The
preparation of additional sites by the construction of facilities for servicing
the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed (including the
installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and either final site
grading or the pouring of concrete pads).
   FIVE-HUNDRED YEAR FLOOD. The flood that has a 0.2% chance of being equaled
or exceeded in any year. Areas subject to the 500-YEAR FLOOD have a moderate to
low risk of flooding.
   FLOOD, FLOODING, or FLOOD WATER.
      (1)   A general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation
of normally dry land areas from the overflow of inland or tidal waters; the
unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source;
and/or mudslides (i.e., mudflows). See MUDSLIDE.
      (2)   The condition resulting from flood-related erosion. See FLOOD-
RELATED EROSION.
   FLOOD BOUNDARY AND FLOODWAY MAP (FBFM). A map on which the Federal Emergency
Management Agency (FEMA) or Federal Insurance Administration (FIA) has
delineated the areas of flood hazards and the regulatory floodway.      
   FLOOD HAZARD/BOUNDARY MAP (FHBM). A map on which the boundaries of the flood
mudslide (i.e., mudflow), and flood-related erosion areas having special
hazards have been designated as Zones A, M, and/or E by the Federal Emergency
Management Agency (FEMA) or Federal Insurance Administration (FIA).
   FLOOD INSURANCE RATE MAY (FIRM). A map on which the Federal Emergency
Management Agency (FEMA) or Federal Insurance Administration (FIA) has
delineated special flood hazard areas and risk premium zones.
   FLOOD INSURANCE STUDY. The report provided by the Federal Emergency
Management Agency (FEMA) or Federal Insurance Administration (FIA) containing
flood profiles, the flood insurance rate map (FIRM), and/or the flood boundary
floodway map (FBFM), and the water surface elevation of the base flood.
   FLOODPLAIN or FLOOD-PRONE AREA. Any land area susceptible to being inundated
by flood waters from any source.
   FLOODPLAIN ADMINISTRATOR. The individual appointed by a NFIP participating
community to administer and enforce the floodplain management ordinances.
   FLOODPLAIN MANAGEMENT. The operation of an overall program of corrective and
preventive measures for reducing flood damage and preserving and enhancing
natural resources in the floodplain, including, but not limited to, emergency
preparedness plans, flood control works, floodplain management ordinances, and
open space plans.
   FLOODPLAIN MANAGEMENT REGULATIONS. This chapter and other zoning ordinances,
subdivision regulations, building codes, health regulations, special purpose
ordinances (such as grading and erosion control), and other applications of
police power, which control development in flood-prone areas. This term
describes federal, state, and/or local regulations, in any combination thereof,
which provide standards for the purpose of flood damage prevention and
reduction.
   FLOOD-PROOFING. Any combination of structural and nonstructural additions,
changes, or adjustments to structures which reduce or eliminate flood damage to
real estate or improved real property, water and sanitation facilities,
structures, and their contents.
   FLOOD-PROOFING CERTIFICATE. A certification by a registered professional
engineer or architect, on a FEMA-approved form in effect at the time of
certification stating that a nonresidential structure, together with attendant
utilities and sanitary facilities is watertight to a specified design elevation
with walls that are substantially impermeable to the passage of water and all
structural components are capable of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic
flood forces, including the effects of buoyance and anticipated debris impact
forces.
